questions.text: Match the following types of synovial joints with their characteristics:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

1. Hinge Joints - D. Uniaxial; Flexion, Extension

  • Movement: Uniaxial (only Flexion and Extension).
  • Examples: Elbow joints, ankle joints, interphalangeal joints.

 

2. Pivot Joints - B. Uniaxial; Rotation

  • Movement: Uniaxial (Rotation).
  • Examples: Median atlantoaxial joint, superior and inferior radioulnar joints.

 

3. Condylar Joints - C. Biaxial; Flexion, Extension, Limited rotation

  • Movement: Biaxial (Flexion, Extension, Limited rotation).
  • Examples: Knee joints, temporomandibular joints.

 

4. Ellipsoid Joints - A. Biaxial; Flexion, Extension, Abduction, Adduction, Circumduction

  • Movement: Biaxial (Flexion, Extension, Abduction, Adduction, Circumduction).
  • Examples: Wrist joint (radiocarpal joint), metacarpophalangeal joint, atlanto-occipital joint (head nodding).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The types of synovial joints are classified based on their movement and structure:

choices.text: Citrate utilization as sole carbon source

questions.text: A microbiology laboratory receives a stool sample from a 28-year-old man with bloody diarrhea and fever. Initial culture grows gram-negative bacilli on MacConkey agar. To identify the organism, the technologist performs the triple sugar iron (TSI) test, along with several other biochemical tests. Which of the following bacterial properties cannot be determined using the TSI test alone?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Citrate utilization as sole carbon source

 

  • The triple sugar iron (TSI) test cannot determine citrate utilization, which requires a separate Simmons citrate test. 
  • TSI agar is specifically designed to test three key characteristics: fermentation of three sugars (glucose, lactose, and sucrose), gas production (visible as bubbles or cracks in the medium), and hydrogen sulfide production (visible as black precipitate). 
  • Citrate utilization, which indicates an organism's ability to use citrate as its sole carbon source, requires a different medium containing citrate as the only carbon source.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Production of carbon dioxide gas: TSI can detect gas production through visible bubbles or cracks in the medium, typically produced during glucose fermentation.

 

Option C. Fermentation of multiple sugars: TSI contains three sugars (glucose, lactose, and sucrose) and can detect their fermentation through pH indicators that show acid production.

 

Option D. Production of hydrogen sulphide: TSI contains ferrous sulfate and can detect H₂S production through the formation of black ferrous sulfide precipitate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Triple sugar iron (TSI) test is designed to detect sugar fermentation, gas production, and H₂S production, but cannot determine citrate utilization, which requires a separate Simmons citrate test.

questions.text: What is the antihypertensive drug of choice for chronic hypertension in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Labetalol

 

  • Labetalol is the first-line antihypertensive due to its efficacy and safety profile in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic effects.

 

Option C and D. Nifedipine and Methyldopa: Nifedipine and methyldopa are alternative options but are not the first choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Labetalol is the antihypertensive of choice for chronic hypertension and hypertensive emergencies in pregnancy.

questions.text: A hospital infection control team is evaluating a new quaternary ammonium compound for use in the surgical ward. The compound shows excellent activity in initial testing, but after three weeks of use, several surfaces show bacterial contamination. Which of the following testing methods would have best predicted this outcome before implementation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Modified Kelsey-Sykes capacity test

 

  • The Kelsey-Sykes capacity test is specifically designed to evaluate a disinfectant's ability to maintain its effectiveness under repeated microbial challenges. 
  • This test assesses whether the disinfectant can retain its antimicrobial activity when repeatedly exposed to increasing microbial loads, simulating real-world conditions where disinfectants must maintain efficacy over multiple uses and increasing bacterial contamination.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Phenol coefficient test: This test only compares the disinfectant's activity to phenol under controlled conditions and cannot predict long-term effectiveness or performance under repeated use.

 

Option C. Chick Martin test: While this test evaluates performance in the presence of organic matter, it doesn't assess the disinfectant's capacity to maintain effectiveness over repeated microbial challenges.

 

Option D. In-use test with weekly monitoring: This is a surveillance method to detect contamination after implementation rather than a predictive test of the disinfectant's capacity to maintain effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Kelsey-Sykes capacity test is essential for predicting a disinfectant's ability to maintain effectiveness under repeated microbial challenges in real-world settings.

questions.text:
Match the Following (Scales in Dermatology):

 

Column A:

  1. Branny/Furfuraceous
  2. Mica like
  3. Silvery white
  4. Fish-like

 

Column B: 

  1. Psoriasis
  2. Pityriasis versicolor
  3. Ichthyosis vulgaris
  4. Pityriasis lichenoides chronica
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Branny/Furfuraceous (1-b): Associated with Pityriasis versicolor, which presents with fine, scaly, branny lesions.
  • Mica-like (2-d): Describes the scale pattern seen in Pityriasis lichenoides chronica.
  • Silvery white (3-a): Classical of Psoriasis due to the hyperkeratotic scaling.
  • Fish-like (4-c): Characteristic of Ichthyosis vulgaris.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Branny/Furfuraceous: Pityriasis versicolor
  • Mica like: Pityriasis lichenoides
  • Silvery white: Psoriasis chronica
  • Fish-like: Ichthyosis vulgaris

questions.text:
A 9-month-old infant is being assessed for fine motor development. Which of the following statements regarding developmental milestones are true? 

 

  1. Grasp reflex disappears by 9 months.
  2. Immature Pincer grasp develops at 9 months.
  3. Transferring objects from one hand to another is possible by 7 months.
  4. Mature pincer grasp is achieved by 12 months.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4 are correct.

 

Statement 2. Immature Pincer grasp develops at 9 months: Correct. The immature pincer grasp is a fine motor milestone that develops around 9 months, allowing infants to pick up small objects with their thumb and index finger and assisted fingers

 

Statement 3. Transferring objects from one hand to another is possible by 7 months: Correct. By 6-7 months of age, infants can transfer objects from one hand to another, marking the development of coordinated hand movements.

 

Statement 4. Mature pincer grasp is achieved by 12 months: Correct. Mature pincer grasp is also achieved at 12 months, signifying advanced fine motor control.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 1. Grasp reflex disappears by 9 months: Incorrect. Grasp reflex disappears earlier, by 3 months of age, as it is a primitive reflex and not present at 9 months.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The immature pincer grasp is a fine motor milestone that develops around 9 months, By 6-7 months of age, infants can transfer objects from one hand to another, Mature pincer grasp is also achieved at 12 months, Grasp reflex disappears earlier, by 3 months of age.

choices.text: Use of vancomycin, as it is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections
Use of β-lactam antibiotics, as the presence of the blaZ gene is likely conferring resistance to penicillin
Use of tetracycline, as the tetM gene would confer protection against the infection
Use of alternative antibiotics, as the mecA gene indicates methicillin resistance and requires an alternative treatment approach

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the hospital with a fever and increasing shortness of breath. Blood cultures reveal Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), and a molecular assay identifies the presence of the mecA gene. Based on the resistance profile of the pathogen, which of the following treatment strategies would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Use of vancomycin, as it is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections

 

  • Vancomycin remains the first-line treatment for Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections, despite the presence of the mecA gene. 
  • The mecA gene confers resistance to methicillin, but vancomycin is typically still effective against MRSA. 
  • Therefore, vancomycin is the appropriate choice for treating this infection, as it targets the cell wall synthesis of MRSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Use of β-lactam antibiotics, as the presence of the blaZ gene is likely conferring resistance to penicillin: β-lactam antibiotics are ineffective for MRSA infections due to the presence of the mecA gene, which confers resistance to methicillin and related antibiotics.

 

Option C. Use of tetracycline, as the tetM gene would confer protection against the infection: Tetracycline resistance is not relevant to MRSA treatment in this case, as MRSA requires antibiotics specifically effective against its resistance mechanisms.

 

Option D. Use of alternative antibiotics, as the mecA gene indicates methicillin resistance and requires an alternative treatment approach: Although mecA gene confers resistance to methicillin, vancomycin is still an appropriate treatment for MRSA, and no alternative antibiotics are necessarily required unless the infection is resistant to vancomycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections, even in the presence of the mecA gene, which confers resistance to methicillin.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the effects of estrogen is/are incorrect? 

 

  1. Estrogen increases sensitivity to oxytocin in the uterus and reduces uterine excitability.
  2. Estrogen has no role in stimulation of ductal growth in the breast 
  3. Estrogen has a cardioprotective effect by inhibiting platelet activation and lowering serum cholesterol.
  4. Estrogen promotes neuroprotection by preventing apoptosis in the central nervous system.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Statement 1. Estrogen increases sensitivity to oxytocin in the uterus and reduces uterine excitability: Incorrect. Estrogen increases both uterine excitability and sensitivity to oxytocin, which aids in uterine contractions during labor.

 

Statement 2. Estrogen has no role in stimulation of ductal growth in the breast: Incorrect. Estrogen stimulates ductal growth in the breast, it directly enhances secondary sexual characteristics and not solely through ductal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 3. Estrogen has a cardioprotective effect by inhibiting platelet activation and lowering serum cholesterol: Correct. Estrogen has a dual cardioprotective effect by lowering serum cholesterol levels through its actions on the liver and reducing platelet activation, thereby preventing cardiovascular disease.

 

Statement 4. Estrogen promotes neuroprotection by preventing apoptosis in the central nervous system: Correct. Estrogen provides neuroprotection by inhibiting neuronal apoptosis, reducing the risk of neurodegenerative diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Is the widest and most dilatable part
Lies closer to anterior surface of prostate
Receives prostatic ductules along its posterior wall

questions.text: Prostatic urethra is characterized by all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presents a concavity posteriorly

 

  • The prostatic urethra does not present a posterior concavity. Instead, it has an anterior concavity, which becomes more pronounced in the membranous urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Is the widest and most dilatable part: The prostatic urethra is indeed the widest and most dilatable part of the urethra. This feature allows for easier passage of instruments like catheters through this segment during medical procedures.

 

Option C. Lies closer to the anterior surface of the prostate: The prostatic urethra runs more anteriorly through the prostate and is situated closer to its anterior surface. It passes at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rds of the prostate gland.

 

Option D. Receives prostatic ductules along its posterior wall: Multiple prostatic ductules open into the posterior wall of the prostatic urethra, contributing to the ejaculate during ejaculation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with a centrally located lung mass. Biopsy of the tumor shows cells with high mitotic activity and the presence of dense-core neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy. Immunohistochemistry reveals chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 positivity. Which of the following markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) INSM-1

 

Clinical clues:

 

  • 65-year-old male
  • 40 pack-year smoking history
  • Centrally located lung mass
  • High mitotic activity
  • Dense-core neurosecretory granules (EM)
  • Chromogranin+, Synaptophysin+, CD56+ (IHC)

 

These findings are classic for Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (SCLC), a neuroendocrine tumor of the lung.

 

INSM-1 is an intra-nuclear marker for the diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. PTHrP: Seen in squamous cell carcinoma, which is also centrally located but not neuroendocrine.

 

Option B. CEA: Marker for adenocarcinomas, not neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Option D. Calretinin: Marker for mesothelioma and mesothelial cells, not relevant here.

choices.text: The substrate and the modifiers (activator and inhibitor) bind to the same site on the enzyme.
The substrate and the modifiers are structural analogues of each other.
The enzyme exhibits cooperative binding, indicative of allosteric modulation.
The enzyme regulation depicted involves changes in the quantity of enzyme molecules.

questions.text: Refer to the provided diagram displaying an enzyme with distinct sites for substrate, an allosteric activator, and an allosteric inhibitor. Given this arrangement, which statement accurately describes the behavior exhibited by the enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The enzyme exhibits cooperative binding, indicative of allosteric modulation.

 

  • The diagram illustrates an enzyme where allosteric sites (activator and inhibitor sites) distinct from the substrate-binding site influence the enzyme's activity. 
  • This configuration supports cooperative binding, a hallmark of allosteric modulation, where the binding of one molecule (activator or inhibitor) alters the enzyme's affinity for the substrate or additional regulatory molecules. 
  • This mechanism enhances or diminishes the enzyme's activity by inducing conformational changes that either favor or disfavor the substrate's optimal binding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The substrate and the modifiers (activator and inhibitor) bind to the same site on the enzyme: Incorrect. The substrate and modifiers bind to different sites, as clearly indicated by separate allosteric activator and inhibitor sites in the diagram.

 

Option B. The substrate and the modifiers are structural analogues of each other: Incorrect. There is no indication that the substrate and modifiers are structural analogues; they affect the enzyme through different mechanisms at distinct sites.

 

Option D. The enzyme regulation depicted involves changes in the quantity of enzyme molecules: Incorrect. The regulation shown pertains to the activity of the enzyme through conformational changes, not the quantity of enzyme molecules.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Understand the principles of allosteric regulation in enzymes, particularly how cooperative binding at allosteric sites can significantly influence enzyme activity, enhancing or inhibiting the enzyme's function based on the presence of regulatory molecules.

choices.text: Increase dose and extend dosing interval
Reduce dose and maintain standard dosing interval
Maintain dose and reduce dosing interval
Reduce dose and extend dosing interval

questions.text: In managing a complicated urinary tract infection in an 80-year-old man with declining renal function (creatinine clearance of 20 mL/min), how would the Vancomycin nomogram suggest adjusting the dosing strategy to maintain effective plasma concentrations without exacerbating renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduce dose and extend dosing interval

 

  • For elderly patients with significantly reduced creatinine clearance, the Vancomycin nomogram typically recommends reducing the dose and extending the dosing interval. 
  • This strategy helps maintain effective drug levels while reducing the risk of accumulating toxic levels due to impaired renal clearance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Adjust vancomycin dosing in elderly patients with severe renal impairment to achieve therapeutic drug levels safely.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, erythema nodosum, and uveitis. Which of the following statements about her condition are true?

 

  1. It is associated with a multisystem inflammatory disorder.
  2. The diagnosis is made clinically based on characteristic findings.
  3. It is more common in men than women.
  4. Arthritis is a common feature.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

1. It is associated with a multisystem inflammatory disorder: True. Behçet syndrome is a multisystem inflammatory disorder involving mucocutaneous, ocular, and articular systems.

 

2. The diagnosis is made clinically based on characteristic findings: True. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings, including recurrent oral/genital ulcers and uveitis.

 

4. Arthritis is a common feature: True. Arthritis is a recognized feature of Behçet syndrome.

 

Other Option:

 

3. It is more common in men than women: False. Behçet syndrome is more common in women than men.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Behçet syndrome is a multisystem disorder diagnosed clinically by recurrent oral/genital ulcers, uveitis, and associated arthritis.

choices.text: Improvement in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF).
Reduction in the frequency of anginal attacks.
Changes in myocardial fatty acid uptake on PET scans.

questions.text: In a clinical trial assessing the efficacy of Trimetazidine in patients with ischemic heart disease, researchers are examining the secondary outcomes related to its metabolic effects. Considering its mechanism of action, which of the following would be an important secondary outcome to monitor in this trial?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Changes in myocardial fatty acid uptake on PET scans.

 

  • Given that Trimetazidine modulates myocardial energy metabolism by reducing fatty acid oxidation and increasing glucose utilization, monitoring changes in myocardial fatty acid uptake using PET scans provides direct insight into the biochemical efficacy of the drug. 
  • This outcome would help validate the metabolic shift hypothesized to underlie the clinical benefits observed in patients with ischemic heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improvement in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF): Incorrect because Trimetazidine does not directly improve cardiac contractility or LVEF.

 

Option B. Reduction in the frequency of anginal attacks: Relevant but does not directly measure the metabolic effect.

 

Option D. Decrease in overall patient mortality: While important, mortality is a broader outcome that may not directly reflect the metabolic effects of the drug.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Analyze the specific metabolic effects of Trimetazidine in clinical research, particularly how it alters myocardial substrate utilization, to understand its mechanism of action in ischemic heart disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is found dead in his home under suspicious circumstances. The authorities suspect foul play and request an autopsy. During the procedure, the forensic expert notices a small stain on the victim's clothing. To confirm its nature,  he performs a test and observes pink feathery crystals under the microscope after heating the sample. Which test was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takayama test

 

  • The Takayama test, also known as the hemochromogen test, is a confirmatory test for blood. 
  • The reagent used in this test includes sodium hydroxide (NaOH), pyridine, and glucose. 
  • When a blood sample is mixed with this reagent and heated, it forms pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin). 
  • This test can be performed on small quantities of blood stains, is effective on aged stains, and is generally more dependable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teichmann test: The Teichmann test, also known as the hemin test, uses sodium chloride (NaCl) and acetic acid as reagents. It produces brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride. However, this test often yields negative results on old stains or those that have been washed or treated with chemicals.

 

 

Option C. Barbario’s test: Barbario’s test is used to detect the presence of semen, specifically spermine secreted from the prostate gland. The reagent used is picric acid, which forms yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. This test is not related to blood detection.

 

 

Option D. Xanthoproteic test: The xanthoproteic reaction detects the presence of proteins soluble in a solution, using concentrated nitric acid. It gives a positive result for amino acids with aromatic groups (phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan), forming a yellow-colored product known as xantho protein. This test is unrelated to blood detection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

  • Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

  • Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)

choices.text: Both the assertion and reasoning are correct, and the reasoning is the correct explanation of the assertion.
Both the assertion and reasoning are correct, but the reasoning is not the correct explanation of the assertion.
The assertion is correct, but the reasoning is incorrect.
Both the assertion and reasoning are incorrect.

questions.text:
Assertion: Luminal A breast cancer is characterized by hormone receptor positivity (ER+, PR+) and a low Ki67 index, indicating a more favorable prognosis.

 

Reasoning: The low Ki67 index suggests that the tumor has low proliferative activity, which contributes to the slower growth and expression of hormone receptors would have better response to hormonal therapies.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both the assertion and reasoning are correct, and the reasoning is the correct explanation of the assertion.

 

  • Luminal A breast cancer is characterized by ER+ and PR+ with a low Ki67 index, reflecting low proliferative activity. 
  • The low Ki67 index indicates slower tumor growth, contributing to the favorable prognosis of Luminal A. This tumor has expression of ER and PR and so has better response to anti-hormonal therapies. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Luminal A breast cancer is marked by ER+, PR+, and low Ki67, indicating lower proliferation rates and a more favorable prognosis.

 

Breast cancers are classified into molecular subtypes based on the expression of receptors and proliferation markers:

questions.text: A 32-year-old researcher is working in a laboratory to evaluate the environmental conditions affecting the thermal comfort of workers exposed to radiant heat. To measure the mean radiant temperature (MRT), the researcher uses an instrument that accounts for the radiation absorbed by its surface. Which of the following instruments is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Image C

 

Globe thermometer

 

  • The Globe thermometer is specifically designed to measure the mean radiant temperature (MRT) by capturing the heat absorbed by a black surface.
  • It is widely used in environmental studies to assess the effect of radiant heat on individuals in a specific setting. 
  • The globe surface mimics the radiation absorbed by the human body, making it ideal for measuring MRT and thermal comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Image A. The wet and dry bulb thermometer measures the humidity and air temperature but does not assess radiant heat.

 

Option Image B. Six’s maximum and minimum thermometer is used for measuring maximum and minimum air temperatures over time and is not designed for measuring mean radiant temperature.

 

Option Image D. The Kata thermometer is used to measure temperature but does not account for radiation, making it inappropriate for MRT measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Instruments:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI). She is allergic to penicillin. Given the biochemical pathways shown in the diagram, which antibiotic would be most appropriate to prescribe, considering its mechanism involves inhibition of step 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fosfomycin

 

  • Fosfomycin targets step 1 of the bacterial cell wall synthesis pathway, where it inhibits the enzyme enolpyruvate transferase, preventing the formation of N-acetylmuramic acid (NAM), a critical precursor in peptidoglycan synthesis.
  •  Its mechanism makes it an effective choice for treating UTIs, particularly in patients who have allergies to beta-lactams.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacitracin: Incorrect because Bacitracin acts at step 2 and is not typically used for UTIs.

 

Option C. Vancomycin: Incorrect as Vancomycin targets step 3 and is generally reserved for more severe infections.

 

Option D. Beta-lactams: Incorrect because Beta-lactams, which act at step 4, are avoided due to her penicillin allergy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fosfomycin inhibits enolpyruvate transferase, blocking N-acetylmuramic acid (NAM) synthesis in bacterial cell walls. It is effective for UTIs, especially in beta-lactam-allergic patients.

choices.text: Activates secondary messengers to increase gene transcription.
Binds directly to DNA at hormone response elements to initiate gene transcription.
Triggers degradation of transcription inhibitors to enhance gene expression.
Causes phosphorylation of transcription factors that act on specific genes.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female with newly diagnosed hypothyroidism is prescribed levothyroxine. Given that levothyroxine mimics natural thyroid hormone, which action does it primarily perform at the genomic level when bound to its nuclear receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Binds directly to DNA at hormone response elements to initiate gene transcription.

 

  • Thyroid hormones, including levothyroxine, exert their effects by entering cells, binding to thyroid hormone receptors in the nucleus, and directly interacting with hormone response elements (HREs) on DNA. 
  • This direct interaction promotes the transcription of genes involved in metabolic processes, growth, and development. 
  • This mechanism highlights the role of thyroid hormone therapy in managing hypothyroidism by compensating for the body’s insufficient hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activates secondary messengers to increase gene transcription: Incorrect, as thyroid hormones do not primarily function through secondary messenger pathways for gene transcription.

 

Option C. Triggers degradation of transcription inhibitors to enhance gene expression: Incorrect, thyroid hormones do not promote proteosomal degradation of transcription inhibitors.

 

Option D. Causes phosphorylation of transcription factors that act on specific genes: Incorrect, direct phosphorylation of transcription factors is not the primary mechanism by which thyroid hormones operate at the genomic level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thyroid hormone receptors are intracellular and intranuclear receptors. 
  • They primarily function as transcription factors and directly interact with the genomic DNA to regulate gene expression.
  • Other examples of intranuclear receptors include Vitamin A and Vitamin D receptors.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man from Kolkata presents with persistent headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness for the past month. He also reports low-grade fever and weight loss over the same period. Neurological examination reveals a positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski sign.

 

A lumbar puncture (CSF analysis) reveals:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (lymphocyte predominance)
  • Low glucose (hypoglycorrhachia)
  • High protein
  • Cobweb-like coagulum formation on standing

 

MRI brain is shown below. What is the therapy of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HRZE (Isoniazid, Rifampin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol)

 

  • The chronic presentation of headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness, combined with CSF findings of mononuclear pleocytosis, low glucose, and cobweb coagulum formation, is highly suggestive of tuberculous meningitis (TBM). 
  • The MRI findings of basal exudates with meningeal enhancement further support the diagnosis.

 

First-line treatment for TB meningitis includes:

 

  • Antitubercular therapy (ATT) with HRZE for 2 months, followed by continuation of Isoniazid and Rifampin for at least 9–12 months.
  • Adjunctive corticosteroids (Dexamethasone or Prednisolone) to reduce inflammation and intracranial pressure (ICP), improving outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin:

 

  • This combination is used for bacterial (pyogenic) meningitis, especially for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • TBM has a more chronic course and presents with lymphocytic pleocytosis and low glucose, unlike the polymorphonuclear (neutrophilic) predominance seen in bacterial meningitis.

 

Option C. Cefepime + Vancomycin + Ampicillin:

 

  • This regimen is used in empirical treatment of bacterial meningitis when Listeria monocytogenes is suspected (e.g., elderly, immunocompromised patients).
  • TBM does not respond to standard antibiotics and requires prolonged antitubercular therapy.

 

Option D. Liposomal Amphotericin B + Flucytosine:

 

  • This is the treatment for cryptococcal meningitis, commonly seen in HIV/AIDS and immunocompromised patients.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis presents with very high CSF opening pressure and India ink-positive encapsulated yeast, which were not described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculous meningitis should be suspected in a patient with chronic headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness, along with CSF findings of lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, and cobweb-like coagulum. 
  • The treatment of choice is antitubercular therapy (HRZE) along with corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is undergoing routine blood work for diabetes management. The phlebotomist uses different vacutainer tubes to collect blood samples for various tests. Which of the following tubes contains an anticoagulant and is commonly used for a complete blood count?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lavender -top tube

 

  • The lavender (purple)-top tube is the standard tube for Complete Blood Count (CBC) because it contains ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) as an anticoagulant. 
  • EDTA binds calcium, preventing clotting and preserving blood cell morphology for hematological analysis, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. It is also used for peripheral blood smears.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red-top tube: Incorrect. This tube contains no anticoagulant and is used for serum collection (e.g., chemistry tests, serology).

 

Option B. Light-blue top tube: Incorrect. This tube contains sodium citrate and is used for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, PTT).

 

Option D. Grey-top tube: Incorrect. This tube contains sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate, which is used for blood glucose estimation and not CBC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lavender (purple)-top tubes contain EDTA, an anticoagulant that prevents blood clotting and preserves blood cells for CBC and peripheral blood smears.
  • Red-top tubes are for serum collection, light-blue tubes are for coagulation studies, and grey-top tubes are used for glucose testing.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for eclampsia.


Reason (R): Magnesium sulfate reduces blood pressure effectively in eclampsia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false

 

  • Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for eclampsia due to its anticonvulsant properties, not its ability to lower blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Magnesium sulfate is used for seizure prevention in eclampsia, not as an antihypertensive agent.

choices.text: BRAF mutations leading to excessive activation of the MAPK pathway
Autoimmune destruction of the endothelial cells lining blood vessels
T-cell mediated lymphocyte infiltration and cytokine release
Abnormal activation of histiocytes and macrophages leading to granuloma formation

questions.text: A 5-year-old male with a history of failure to thrive, exophthalmos, and seborrheic dermatitis is diagnosed with Letterer-Siwe Disease. What is the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for the systemic manifestations seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BRAF mutations leading to excessive activation of the MAPK pathway 

 

  • Letterer-Siwe Disease results from Langerhans cell proliferation due to mutations in the BRAF gene, which leads to abnormal activation of the MAPK pathway. 
  • This causes granuloma formation in various organs, including the bones, liver, and skin, leading to hepatosplenomegaly, seborrheic dermatitis, and bony lytic lesions. 
  • The granulomas contribute to the systemic manifestations of the disease, including failure to thrive and exophthalmos.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autoimmune destruction of the endothelial cells lining blood vessels: T-cell mediated mechanisms are more commonly associated with diseases like autoimmune disorders or lymphomas, not Langerhans cell proliferation.

 

Option C. T-cell mediated lymphocyte infiltration and cytokine release: Histopathology in Letterer-Siwe Disease shows granuloma formation due to macrophage and histiocyte activation, not T-cell mediated destruction.

 

Option D. Abnormal activation of histiocytes and macrophages leading to granuloma formation: Although LCH involves Langerhans cells (specialized dendritic cells), it does not form true granulomas like tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. Instead, LCH is characterized by clonal proliferation, eosinophilic infiltration, and Birbeck granules on electron microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Letterer-Siwe Disease is caused by Langerhans cell proliferation due to BRAF mutations, leading to granuloma formation and systemic manifestations like bony lytic lesions and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, Mr. Ravi from Mumbai, presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his jaw and left arm. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, heart rate is 88/min. ECG is shown below. What is the most likely site of ischemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior wall

 

  • Posterior wall myocardial infarction (MI) is often identified by reciprocal changes on the standard 12-lead ECG, as the posterior wall isn’t directly visualized. 
  • ST depressions in leads V1–V3 with tall R waves and upright T waves are characteristic. A posterior ECG (with leads V7–V9) can confirm ST elevations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior wall: Typically presents with ST elevations in leads V1–V6, not isolated ST depressions.

 

Option B. Inferior wall: Involves ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF, reflecting right coronary artery ischemia.

 

Option C. Lateral wall: Shows ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior wall MI presents with reciprocal changes on the ECG—ST depressions in V1–V3 with tall R waves. 
  • Recognizing these patterns is crucial as posterior infarctions can be easily missed on a standard ECG.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with headaches, vision changes, and hormonal imbalances. Imaging finding is shown below. The lesion is likely originating from which of the following embryonic structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rathke's pouch

 

  • The lesion described is most likely a craniopharyngioma, which arises from Rathke’s pouch. 
  • It is a cystic lesion commonly located in the suprasellar region with calcification, and it extends near the pituitary stalk. 
  • Rathke's pouch is an embryological remnant that gives rise to the anterior pituitary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neural tube: The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system structures, not craniopharyngiomas.

 

Option C. Adenohypophysis: This is the anterior part of the pituitary gland, but craniopharyngiomas are not derived from this structure.

 

Option D. Mesodermal layer: This layer does not give rise to the structures seen in craniopharyngiomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Craniopharyngiomas arise from Rathke’s pouch and are characterized by cystic formation and calcifications on imaging.

questions.text: During a population health assessment, a survey identifies an adult female who is a construction worker. The researcher needs to compute the energy requirements for this individual. Which Consumption Unit Coefficient (CUC) should be applied for this calculation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1.2

 

  • An adult female performing heavy work has a CUC of 1.2 according to the table. This reflects higher energy expenditure due to the intensity of the physical activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consumption Unit Coefficients (CUC)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a chronic infection in the foot. The lesion has been present for several months and contains a yellowish purulent discharge. Upon examination, the lesion has a raised inflamed opening and is accompanied by osteolytic lesions. Based on the presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomycetoma

 

Explanation:

 

Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection involving the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones, often presenting with swelling, draining sinuses, and granules in the discharge. 

 

It can be classified into Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma, based on the causative organism.

 

  • Actinomycetoma is caused by bacterial species like Nocardia, Actinomyces, and Streptomyces.
  • Eumycetoma is caused by fungi such as Madurella and Exophiala.

 

The given clinical case describes a chronic foot infection with a yellowish purulent discharge, inflamed opening, and osteolytic lesions, which strongly suggests Actinomycetoma. Actinomycetoma tends to have more rapid progression, bone involvement, and produces yellow-white granules in the purulent discharge. In contrast, Eumycetoma progresses more slowly and is associated with black or white granules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eumycetoma: Though it presents with similar chronic swelling and sinus tracts, eumycetoma is less aggressive than actinomycetoma and typically involves black or white granules in the discharge. In Bone Osteosclerotic lesions is seen.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis affecting the foot (tuberculous osteomyelitis) can cause chronic osteolytic lesions but does not usually present with discharging sinuses containing granules.

 

Option D. Leprosy: Leprosy mainly causes nerve involvement, skin patches, and sensory loss. It does not typically present with chronic purulent discharge or bone destruction in this manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomycetoma is a chronic bacterial infection characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, purulent discharge containing yellow granules, and osteolytic lesions. It progresses more rapidly than Eumycetoma, which is fungal in origin and presents with black or white granules.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with an undiagnosed protein disorder. His physician orders a detailed analysis of the protein's molecular mass and amino acid sequence to identify possible mutations or modifications. Which of the following techniques would be the most effective for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mass Spectrometry

 

  • Mass spectrometry (MS) is the gold standard for determining molecular mass and the primary amino acid sequence of peptides and proteins. 
  • Advanced techniques like tandem MS (MS/MS) allow precise protein sequencing and post-translational modification analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colorimetry: Incorrect. Colorimetry measures the concentration of a substance based on color intensity but cannot determine molecular mass or amino acid sequence. It is often used for protein estimation methods like the Biuret, Lowry, or Bradford assays.

 

Option B. Spectrophotometry: Incorrect. Spectrophotometry assesses protein concentration by measuring absorbance at specific wavelengths (e.g., 280 nm for aromatic amino acids). However, it does not provide molecular mass or sequence information.

 

Option C. X-ray Crystallography: Incorrect. X-ray crystallography is used to determine the 3D structure of proteins at atomic resolution but does not provide molecular mass or amino acid sequence information. It requires high-quality crystals, which can be difficult to obtain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mass spectrometry is the most powerful technique for determining molecular mass and primary amino acid sequence, making it essential for proteomics research and clinical diagnostics.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with anemia and is found to have an abnormal form of the β-globin chain, which is 168 amino acids long instead of the normal 123. Genetic analysis reveals a point mutation affecting the stop codon, leading to an abnormally elongated protein. Which of the following point mutations is most likely responsible for this abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UAA → CAA

 

  • UAA is a stop codon (one of the three stop codons: UAA, UAG, UGA).
  • A mutation from UAA (stop) to CAA (glutamine) removes the normal termination signal, causing the ribosome to continue translating past the normal stop site, elongating the β-globin chain to 168 amino acids instead of 123.
  • This is an example of a stop codon loss leading to an abnormally long β-globin chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. UAA → UAG: Incorrect. 

 

  • Both UAA and UAG are stop codons, so this mutation would not affect protein length. The translation would still terminate at the same point, producing a normal-length protein.

 

Option C. CGA → UGA: Incorrect.

 

  • CGA codes for arginine, and changing it to UGA creates a premature stop codon.
  • This would shorten the β-globin chain rather than elongating it. This is an example of a nonsense mutation, which leads to a truncated, nonfunctional protein.

 

Option D. GAU → GAC: Incorrect.

 

  • Both GAU and GAC code for aspartic acid, meaning this is a silent mutation that does not change the protein structure.
  • This mutation would not cause elongation of the β-globin chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A stop codon mutation (UAA → CAA) causes loss of the normal stop signal, leading to an elongated β-globin chain. This stop codon loss can lead to unstable hemoglobin, which may contribute to anemia.

choices.text: Elevated FSH levels relative to LH

questions.text: Which of the following is a biochemical feature of Stein-Leventhal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG)

 

  • In PCOS, SHBG levels decrease due to hyperinsulinemia, which increases free testosterone and exacerbates hyperandrogenic features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased plasma testosterone levels: Plasma testosterone is elevated in PCOS, contributing to hirsutism and acne.

 

Option C. Elevated FSH levels relative to LH: PCOS is characterized by elevated LH relative to FSH, not vice versa.

 

Option D. Normal insulin sensitivity: Insulin resistance is a hallmark of PCOS and contributes to hyperinsulinemia and metabolic abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCOS is associated with decreased SHBG, hyperandrogenism, insulin resistance, and an elevated LH: FSH ratio.

questions.text:
Match the following hormones with their primary functions or characteristics during the menstrual cycle.

 

Column A:

  1. LH Surge
  2. Estrogen
  3. Progesterone
  4. FSH

 

Column B:

  1. Supports the corpus luteum during the luteal phase
  2. Stimulates ovulation and release of the oocyte
  3. Stimulates follicular growth in the ovary
  4. Peaks before ovulation to support endometrial proliferation
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C

 

  • LH Surge (1-B): Triggers ovulation and oocyte release from the dominant follicle.
  • Estrogen (2-D): Peaks before ovulation, supporting endometrial proliferation.
  • Progesterone (3-A): Dominates the luteal phase and supports the corpus luteum.
  • FSH (4-C): Promotes follicular growth in the ovary.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • LH Surge : Triggers ovulation and oocyte release from the dominant follicle.
  • Estrogen : Peaks before ovulation, supporting endometrial proliferation.
  • Progesterone : Dominates the luteal phase and supports the corpus luteum.
  • FSH : Promotes follicular growth in the ovary.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes is interested in adding an SGLT-2 inhibitor to her regimen after reading about its benefits in controlling blood glucose and aiding in weight loss. Given the pharmacodynamics of SGLT-2 inhibitors and her diabetes type, what is the most critical risk to discuss with her before initiating therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The development of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

 

  • For patients with type 1 diabetes, the use of SGLT-2 inhibitors can lead to euglycemic DKA, a serious condition where despite normal or near-normal blood sugars, high levels of ketones are produced because of insufficient insulin activity. 
  • This risk needs to be carefully managed by continuing insulin therapy and monitoring for symptoms of DKA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The risk of severe hypoglycaemia: Incorrect because SGLT-2 inhibitors typically do not cause hypoglycemia unless combined with other glucose-lowering drugs.

 

Option B. The potential for weight gain: Incorrect as these drugs generally promote weight loss.

 

Option D. Increased risk of myocardial infarction: Incorrect because there is no direct increase in the risk of myocardial infarction with SGLT-2 inhibitors; in fact, they offer cardiovascular benefits.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Recognize the risk of euglycemic DKA in patients with type 1 diabetes treated with SGLT-2 inhibitors and the importance of continued insulin use.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about placenta accreta is true?

 

  1. The incidence is about 1 in 2500 pregnancies
  2. The incidence has increased in the last decade
  3. It is caused by the absence of decidua basalis
  4. The fibrinoid layer is deficient
  5. It is more common in primigravida
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b, c, d

 

b. The incidence has increased in the last decade: The incidence of placenta accreta has increased significantly over the last decade, largely due to the rise in cesarean sections, which predispose women to abnormal placental adherence in subsequent pregnancies.

 

c. It is caused by the absence of decidua basalis: Placenta accreta occurs when the decidua basalis is absent, allowing the placental villi to attach directly to the myometrium.

 

d. The fibrinoid layer is deficient: The absence or poor development of Nitabuch’s fibrinoid layer further contributes to abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

a. The incidence is about 1 in 2500 pregnancies: This is false. While earlier estimates suggested an incidence of 1 in 2500, recent data show the incidence is closer to 1 in 550 deliveries due to the increasing rates of cesarean sections.

 

e. It is more common in primigravida: This is false. Placenta accreta is more common in women with multiple pregnancies, especially those with a history of placenta previa or prior cesarean deliveries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta accreta is associated with the absence of the decidua basalis and a deficient fibrinoid layer, and its incidence has increased with rising cesarean delivery rates. 
  • It is more common in women with a history of cesarean sections and placenta previa, not in primigravida.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening left-sided pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination:

 

  • Blood pressure: 78/46 mmHg
  • SpO₂: 81% on 8 L/min oxygen via face mask
  • Heart rate: 147 bpm
  • Temperature: 37.3°C

 

Lung auscultation is normal, and ECG shows sinus tachycardia. The patient does not respond to adequate fluid resuscitation. High-flow oxygen is applied. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urgent IV Thrombolysis

 

  • The patient’s hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia) and history are consistent with massive pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • Guidelines recommend thrombolysis in patients with PE and SBP < 90 mmHg who fail to respond to fluid resuscitation.
  • Diagnostic investigations, such as CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) or echocardiogram, should not delay lifesaving thrombolysis in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent Trans-Esophageal Echocardiogram: While echocardiography can detect signs of right heart strain due to PE, it is not definitive and delays treatment.

 

Option C. Rapid initiation of LMWH: LMWH is standard for stable PE, but in hemodynamic instability, thrombolysis is required.

 

Option D. Urgent CT Pulmonary Angiogram: Although CTPA is the diagnostic gold standard for PE, it should not delay thrombolysis in critically unstable patients.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In suspected or confirmed massive PE with SBP < 90 mmHg, thrombolysis should be initiated immediately, even on clinical grounds, to prevent cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Iron absorption primarily occurs in which part of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

Iron is mainly absorbed in the duodenum, where dietary ferric iron (Fe³⁺) is reduced to the ferrous form (Fe²⁺) for absorption through the intestinal mucosa. This process is facilitated by the acidic environment and the presence of reducing agents like vitamin C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stomach: Incorrect. The stomach contributes to iron absorption by providing an acidic environment that helps convert ferric iron (Fe³⁺) into the absorbable ferrous form (Fe²⁺), but no significant absorption occurs here.

 

Option C. Ileum: Incorrect. The ileum is responsible for the absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts but does not play a major role in iron absorption.

 

Option D. Jejunum: Incorrect. While the jejunum absorbs various nutrients, including some trace elements, the majority of iron absorption takes place in the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duodenum is the primary site for iron absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion, hyperventilation, nausea, and ringing in the ears after consuming an unknown quantity of over-the-counter pain relievers. Arterial blood gas shows primary respiratory alkalosis with anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the most effective intervention to enhance salicylate elimination and prevent further toxicity progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate

 

  • Salicylate toxicity causes a mixed respiratory alkalosis (due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center) and metabolic acidosis (due to lactate accumulation and uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation). 
  • The most effective intervention is urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate, which ionizes salicylates in renal tubules, preventing reabsorption and enhancing elimination. 
  • This method is preferred unless severe toxicity requires hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activated charcoal administration: Incorrect. Activated charcoal is only useful within 1-2 hours of ingestion before significant systemic absorption. Late-stage salicylate toxicity requires enhanced elimination strategies.

 

Option B. Acetylcysteine infusion: Incorrect. Acetylcysteine replenishes glutathione for acetaminophen overdose, but it has no role in salicylate poisoning.

 

Option D. Intravenous calcium gluconate: Incorrect. Calcium gluconate is used in hyperkalemia and calcium channel blocker toxicity, but it does not alter salicylate metabolism or excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Salicylate poisoning causes respiratory alkalosis transitioning to anion gap metabolic acidosis. 
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate enhances excretion by trapping ionized salicylates in renal tubules.

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH

 

  • Warfarin is contraindicated in late pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects and potential risks of bleeding complications during delivery.
  • At 36 weeks, warfarin should be stopped, and LMWH (low molecular weight heparin) should be initiated as it is safer and allows better control during delivery.
  • LMWH also has a shorter half-life compared to warfarin, making it easier to discontinue prior to delivery and restart postpartum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: While unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used in pregnancy, LMWH is preferred due to its longer half-life, better bioavailability, and more predictable anticoagulant effects, reducing the need for frequent monitoring.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: Continuing warfarin is incorrect at this stage of pregnancy because it poses a high risk of fetal complications (e.g., fetal hemorrhage and warfarin embryopathy) and maternal bleeding during delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: While LMWH is the preferred option, aspirin is not routinely added unless the patient has a very high risk of thrombosis (e.g., history of recurrent thrombosis or additional prothrombotic disorders). In this case, aspirin is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • At 36 weeks of pregnancy, warfarin therapy should be replaced with LMWH to prevent fetal risks and minimize maternal complications during delivery, ensuring safe anticoagulation management.

choices.text: Pandemic potential due to global spread
High morbidity in healthy adults and elderly
Seasonal endemic outbreaks with peaks in winter

questions.text: A community health surveillance team in an urban area reports a sharp rise in respiratory illness among children, with many presenting with fever, wheezing, and mild cough. Upon further investigation, the team identifies a cluster of cases, and HMPV is confirmed as the causative agent. The team also notes a significant increase in hospital admissions for respiratory complications, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely characteristic of this HMPV outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Seasonal endemic outbreaks with peaks in winter

 

  • HMPV is typically associated with seasonal outbreaks, most often in winter months. 
  • These outbreaks tend to occur in localized regions and primarily affect young children and immunocompromised individuals. 
  • While HMPV can cause severe illness, especially in these vulnerable groups, it does not have pandemic potential.
  • The majority of infections tend to remain localized within regions, with seasonal peaks in respiratory illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pandemic potential due to global spread: HMPV does not have the same pandemic potential as other viruses like influenza or SARS-CoV-2, and its spread is typically regional.

 

Option B. High morbidity in healthy adults and elderly: Healthy adults generally have mild or no symptoms when infected with HMPV, with the highest morbidity observed in children and the elderly.

 

Option D. Nosocomial transmission in healthcare settings: Nosocomial transmission is a concern for respiratory viruses, but HMPV outbreaks are more common in the community, with children being the primary vector.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) typically causes seasonal outbreaks in winter, with the highest burden on young children and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath after experiencing a highly emotional event. She denies a history of coronary artery disease. Her ECG is shown below. Coronary angiography reveals no significant coronary artery obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Takotsubo syndrome

 

  • Takotsubo syndrome, also known as stress cardiomyopathy or "broken heart syndrome," is characterized by transient regional left ventricular dysfunction, typically following a significant emotional or physical stressor. 
  • It mimics acute myocardial infarction with chest pain, ST-segment elevations, and elevated cardiac biomarkers, but coronary angiography reveals no significant obstructive coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myocardial infarction: Typically associated with significant coronary artery occlusion, which is absent in Takotsubo syndrome.

 

Option C. Prinzmetal’s angina: Caused by coronary artery spasm, leading to transient ST-segment elevations that resolve with vasodilator therapy.

 

Option D. Acute pericarditis: Produces diffuse ST-segment elevations and PR-segment depressions, typically without regional wall motion abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Takotsubo syndrome mimics acute myocardial infarction but is triggered by stress, shows transient ST elevations, and lacks obstructive coronary disease on angiography.
  • Recognizing this condition is essential to avoid unnecessary interventions.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): During Phase 2 (plateau phase) of the ventricular action potential, calcium influx through L-type calcium channels occurs simultaneously with potassium efflux.

 

Reason (R): The plateau phase ensures prolonged Absolute Refractory period necessary to prevent premature depolarization by other cardiac tissues.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Assertion: The plateau phase (Phase 2) is characterized by an equilibrium between potassium efflux and calcium influx through L-type calcium channels, resulting in a steady membrane potential. This phase plays a critical role in cardiac muscle contraction.

     

  • Reason: The prolonged depolarization during the plateau phase is vital for ventricular contraction (inotropy). It prevents early repolarization and ensures synchronous contraction of the ventricles, thereby maintaining cardiac output.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the components of pulmonary surfactant with their respective roles:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • 1-A: Lecithin (DPPC) is the major surfactant lipid, reducing alveolar surface tension and preventing collapse.
  • 2-B: Sphingomyelin is a minor component of surfactant but is crucial in fetal lung assessment through the L/S ratio.
  • 3-C: Surfactant proteins SP-B and SP-C are critical for spreading and stabilizing the surfactant layer.
  • 4-D: L/S ratio (Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio) is used to assess fetal lung maturity, with a ratio ≥2 indicating sufficient maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Serum vitamin D levels are normal

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Growth plate healing becomes normal 

 

FOOT DEFORMITY IN RICKETS

 

  • Corrective osteotomy in rickets should only be done once radiological healing has taken place otherwise the osteotomy will not unite due to defective mineralization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum calcium levels are normal. Serum calcium levels are important for bone health, but correcting a foot deformity for 2-year-olds with rickets has more to do with normalizing growth plate healing than serum calcium levels. 

 

Option B. Serum vitamin D levels are normal. While normalizing serum vitamin D is essential for the treatment of rickets, it does not directly address the healing of the growth plate. Correcting the foot deformity has more to do with restoring normal growth plate function.

 

Option D. Serum ALP becomes normal. ALP is an enzyme involved in the mineralization of bone. Elevated ALP levels are commonly seen in rickets due to an increase in bone turnover. However, ALP normalization alone may not be enough to determine the right time for surgical correction of your foot deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate timing for surgical intervention based on the normalization of growth plate healing rather than relying solely on normal serum calcium, vitamin D levels, or alkaline phosphatase levels.

questions.text: Mr. Ramesh, a 60-year-old gentleman from Hyderabad, presents with progressive fatigue, loss of appetite, and a feeling of heaviness in the left upper abdomen for three months. He reports early satiety but denies fever, night sweats, or weight loss. Examination reveals pallor and massive splenomegaly extending below the umbilicus. Laboratory findings show leukocytosis (1.65 lakh/µL) with peripheral smear revealing myeloblasts (45%), promyelocytes (30%), metamyelocytes (15%), along with basophils and eosinophils. Karyotyping image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

 

  • CML typically presents with marked leukocytosis, splenomegaly, and a left shift in the myeloid lineage, as seen in Mr. Ramesh's peripheral smear showing myeloblasts, promyelocytes, and metamyelocytes. 
  • The presence of basophilia and eosinophilia is characteristic of CML. The disease often presents insidiously with symptoms like fatigue, early satiety due to splenomegaly, and weight loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): Usually presents with rapid onset symptoms and >20% myeloblasts without the marked left shift seen in CML.

 

Option C. Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL): Primarily a disease of children, with lymphoblast predominance rather than myeloid precursors.

 

Option D. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL): Characterized by lymphocytosis and smudge cells, without significant myeloid precursor proliferation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Chronic Myeloid Leukemia is marked by leukocytosis with a left-shifted myeloid lineage, basophilia, eosinophilia, and splenomegaly. 
  • The Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) confirms the diagnosis and guides targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

choices.text: An indicator of considerably increased incidence of major malformations of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and nondiabetic mothers

questions.text: During the examination of the umbilical cord after delivery, a single umbilical artery is identified instead of the usual two arteries and one vein. What does the presence of a single umbilical artery indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) An indicator of considerably increased incidence of major malformations of the fetus

 

  • The presence of a single umbilical artery (SUA) is associated with an increased risk of fetal congenital malformations, particularly involving the cardiovascular and genitourinary systems. 
  • It is found in 20–25% of cases with major fetal anomalies. SUA is also linked to an increased risk of abortion, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), prematurity, and perinatal mortality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insignificant: This is incorrect as SUA is a significant finding due to its association with fetal malformations and adverse pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option B. Occurs in 10% of newborns: This is incorrect. SUA occurs in 0.7–0.8% of single pregnancies and about 5% of twin pregnancies, not in 10% of all newborns.

 

Option D. Equally common in newborns of diabetic and nondiabetic mothers: This is incorrect. SUA is more common in diabetic patients and in black populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a single umbilical artery is an important clinical finding associated with a considerably increased risk of major fetal malformations, particularly of the cardiovascular and genitourinary systems, as well as adverse pregnancy outcomes like IUGR and prematurity.

questions.text: A preterm neonate weighing 1.8 kg is receiving the care technique shown in the image below. Which of the following is not a benefit of this care?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protects from neonatal jaundice

 

  • Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) does not directly prevent neonatal jaundice, which requires phototherapy or other treatments to reduce bilirubin levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Protects from hypothermia: KMC helps maintain body temperature by skin-to-skin contact, reducing the risk of hypothermia.

 

Option C. Decreases duration of hospital stay: Studies show KMC is associated with faster weight gain and improved outcomes, reducing hospital stay.

 

Option D. Promotes exclusive breastfeeding: KMC facilitates bonding and improves breastfeeding rates, supporting exclusive breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) provides thermal regulation, promotes exclusive breastfeeding, and reduces hospital stay, but it does not prevent neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: A 40-year-old healthcare worker who has been in contact with several leprosy patients in a high-risk setting, visits the clinic for a check-up. The individual has not yet developed any symptoms but has had significant exposure (around 50 hours per week for 4 months) to multiple known cases. Based on the exposure and the individual’s eligibility for post-exposure prophylaxis, which of the following is the recommended intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single-dose Rifampicin for prophylaxis

 

  • For individuals who have been identified as high-risk contacts of leprosy patients (with exposure of more than 20 hours per week for over 3 months), single-dose Rifampicin is the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis. 
  • This strategy has been shown to be highly effective in preventing the development of leprosy in these individuals, provided they have not yet shown symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6-month course of Dapsone: Is used in the treatment of active leprosy, not for prophylaxis.


Option C. Daily Rifampicin for 12 weeks: Is not a recommended regimen for PEP, as Rifampicin is given as a single dose for prophylaxis.
 

Option D. Immediate initiation of multidrug therapy (MDT): Would be indicated for individuals diagnosed with leprosy, not for high-risk contacts without symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis for leprosy is given as chemoprophylaxis, where Rifampicin single dose is given
  • Inclusion Criteria for PEP Leprosy:
    • Being identified as a contact, i.e. a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours or more per week for more than 3 months
    • Age: more than 2 years; if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria)

choices.text: Decrease total dissolved solids (TDS) and increase pH
Increase calcium concentration and decrease pH
Decrease calcium concentration and increase temperature

questions.text: A researcher at a water quality control lab is assessing the water supply for a manufacturing plant. The water has an LSI value of -0.5, indicating corrosive potential. To mitigate this issue, the researcher considers adjusting the water's characteristics. Which combination of adjustments would most likely help reduce corrosion and bring the LSI to a positive value?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase calcium concentration and alkalinity

 

  • An LSI negative indicates that the water is undersaturated with respect to calcium carbonate, leading to corrosion. 
  • To make the water less corrosive and bring the LSI to a positive value, the researcher should increase the calcium concentration (hardness) and increase the alkalinity. 
  • These adjustments will help saturate the water with calcium carbonate and reduce corrosion, shifting the LSI to positive, indicating a tendency for scaling rather than corrosion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease total dissolved solids (TDS) and increase pH: Decreasing TDS and increasing pH alone may not address the need for calcium saturation, which is crucial to prevent corrosion.

 

Option B. Increase calcium concentration and decrease pH: Decreasing pH increases acidity, worsening corrosion instead of mitigating it.

 

Option D. Decrease calcium concentration and increase temperature: Decreasing calcium concentration would only worsen the undersaturation with calcium carbonate, increasing corrosion potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langlier’s Saturation Index (LSI)

 

  • LSI provides an indicator of the degree of saturation of water with respect to calcium carbonate.
  • LSI is based on estimating Hardness (calcium concentration), Total dissolved solids (TDS), Alkalinity, pH and Temperature.
  • LSI Positive indicates Scaling, LSI negative indicates corrosion.

choices.text: Impaired ATP production due to decreased NADH generation
Disrupted nucleic acid synthesis due to reduced ribose-5-phosphate availability
Accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate, leading to increased glycolysis
Reduced acetyl-CoA production, impairing the citric acid cycle

questions.text: A genetic mutation in the enzyme transketolase leads to inefficient carbon transfer in the pentose phosphate pathway, despite adequate thiamine intake. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this defect, considering the role of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) in the reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Disrupted nucleic acid synthesis due to reduced ribose-5-phosphate availability

 

  • Transketolase is an enzyme in the non-oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway, which helps convert sugar phosphates into ribose-5-phosphate (a precursor for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis).
  • A mutation in transketolase, even with sufficient thiamine (TPP is its coenzyme), would impair the enzyme’s function, leading to reduced ribose-5-phosphate formation.
  • This directly impacts nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) synthesis, making this the most likely outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impaired ATP production due to decreased NADH generation: Incorrect:

 

  • The pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) generates NADPH, not NADH.
  • NADPH is primarily involved in reductive biosynthesis and antioxidant defense, while NADH is produced mainly in glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Therefore, a transketolase defect would not directly affect ATP production through NADH generation.

 

Option C. Accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate, leading to increased glycolysis: Incorrect:

 

  • A transketolase defect occurs in the non-oxidative phase, while glucose-6-phosphate is involved in the oxidative phase of the PPP.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate could accumulate if glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) was defective, not transketolase.
  • This mutation would not directly lead to increased glycolysis.

 

Option D. Reduced acetyl-CoA production, impairing the citric acid cycle: Incorrect: 

 

  • Acetyl-CoA is produced primarily from pyruvate via pyruvate dehydrogenase, fatty acid oxidation, or amino acid metabolism.
  • The pentose phosphate pathway does not produce or regulate acetyl-CoA directly, and a defect in transketolase would not impair the citric acid cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A mutation in transketolase affects the non-oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway, leading to a deficiency of ribose-5-phosphate, which is essential for nucleic acid synthesis. Thus, the correct answer is B. Disrupted nucleic acid synthesis due to reduced ribose-5-phosphate availability.

questions.text:
Mr. Rajesh, a 52-year-old man from Chennai, presents with progressive muscle weakness over the past six months, worsening as the day progresses. He reports intermittent double vision, difficulty chewing and swallowing, and nasal regurgitation of liquids, especially after prolonged meals.  Examination reveals fatigable weakness in proximal muscles, with normal reflexes and sensation and the findings shown in the provided images:

 

 

After application of ice pack:

 

 

The edrophonium test improves his symptoms. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following antibodies will be tested positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-LRP4 antibodies

 

  • Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder primarily associated with antibodies against acetylcholine receptors, but a subset of patients, particularly those who are seronegative for AChR antibodies, may have antibodies against low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4). 
  • LRP4 antibodies interfere with neuromuscular junction signaling, leading to fluctuating muscle weakness, especially involving ocular and bulbar muscles. 
  • The edrophonium test and improvement with an ice pack are supportive diagnostic tools.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies: Seen in Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome, which presents with proximal weakness improving with activity and autonomic symptoms.

 

Option C. Anti-GM1 antibodies: Associated with acute motor axonal neuropathy, a variant of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, presenting with ascending weakness.

 

Option D. Anti-dsDNA antibodies: Specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which presents with multi-system involvement, not isolated muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myasthenia Gravis can be caused by antibodies against acetylcholine receptors or, in some cases, anti-LRP4 antibodies. 
  • Both forms result in fluctuating muscle weakness, often starting with ocular symptoms. 
  • Diagnosis involves antibody testing and bedside assessments like the edrophonium and ice pack tests.

choices.text: Renal TB: Early morning urinary analysis

questions.text: Identify the mismatched disease and its diagnostic test:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal cell carcinoma: Whittaker test 

 

  • Pressure measurement in the pelvicalyceal system is conducted using the Whittaker test, which involves catheterization of the renal pelvis and measurement of pressures to determine the significance of urinary tract obstruction. 
  • It is not used in renal malignancies, where imaging is diagnostic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horse-shoe kidney: USG KUB: Horse shoe kidney is diagnosed on imaging studies like USG.

 

Option C. Renal TB: Early morning urinary analysis: Urine analysis in renal TB shows sterile pyuria. Urine may be subjected to CBNAAT for isolation of organism.

 

Option D. Renal Cysts: CECT abdomen: Renal cysts or polycystic kidneys are seen on imaging like USG or CECT abdomen.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Whittaker test is used for direct pressure measurement in the pelvicalyceal system, particularly to assess for the presence and significance of an obstruction in the upper urinary tract.

questions.text: In this cut section through the ischioanal fossa, correctly identify the pelvic diaphragm.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

  • The pelvic diaphragm is indicated as B in the diagram. 
  • It is primarily composed of the levator ani and coccygeus muscles, which form a muscular partition separating the pelvic cavity from the perineal region.

 

 

Components of the Pelvic Diaphragm:

 

  1. Levator Ani Muscle:
    • Includes three parts:
      • Pubococcygeus
      • Iliococcygeus
      • Puborectalis
      • Functions: Provides support to pelvic organs and plays a role in maintaining continence.
  2. Coccygeus Muscle:
    • Originates from the ischial spine and inserts onto the lower sacrum and coccyx.
    • Provides additional support to the pelvic floor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boundaries of Ischioanal Fossa

 

  1. Lateral Boundary: Fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and the ischial tuberosity.
  2. Medial Boundary: Fascia covering the levator ani and external anal sphincter.
  3. Posterior Boundary: Sacrotuberous ligament, overlain by gluteus maximus.
  4. Anterior Boundary: Posterior border of the perineal membrane.
  5. Floor: Perineal skin.
  6. Roof: Fascia meeting point between the obturator internus and the inferior fascia of the pelvic diaphragm.

choices.text: Administer both medications simultaneously to maximize their absorption.
Take phenytoin 2 hours before sucralfate to avoid absorption interference.
Take sucralfate 2 hours before phenytoin to prioritize ulcer healing.
Administer phenytoin immediately after sucralfate to promote drug binding.

questions.text: For a patient taking both phenytoin and sucralfate, what timing strategy should be implemented to prevent reduced drug efficacy due to interaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Take phenytoin 2 hours before sucralfate to avoid absorption interference.
