  • Administering phenytoin at least 2 hours before sucralfate allows for adequate absorption of phenytoin before the sucralfate forms a barrier in the stomach. 
  • This management strategy helps maintain effective plasma levels of phenytoin, crucial for controlling seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer both medications simultaneously to maximize their absorption: Incorrect as simultaneous administration may lead to reduced absorption of phenytoin.

 

Option C. Take sucralfate 2 hours before phenytoin to prioritize ulcer healing: Incorrect because taking sucralfate first may impair phenytoin absorption.

 

Option D. Administer phenytoin immediately after sucralfate to promote drug binding: Incorrect as administering phenytoin after sucralfate does not promote effective drug binding and can still result in impaired absorption.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Learn to appropriately time the administration of sucralfate and phenytoin to optimize the pharmacokinetic profiles and therapeutic efficacy of both medications.

questions.text: Which of the following cells in the kidney are responsible for releasing adenosine in response to an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Macula densa cells

 

Explanation:

 

  • Macula densa cells are specialized cells located in the thick ascending loop of Henle, near the juxtaglomerular apparatus. These cells sense changes in the sodium chloride (NaCl) concentration in the tubular fluid, which indirectly reflects the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • When there is an increase in GFR, the macula densa detects a higher NaCl concentration in the tubular fluid. In response, the macula densa releases adenosine, which acts locally to constrict the afferent arteriole, thereby reducing GFR as part of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juxtaglomerular cells: Juxtaglomerular cells are responsible for the secretion of renin in response to a decrease in blood pressure or sympathetic stimulation. They do not release adenosine.

 

Option C. Mesangial cells: Mesangial cells provide structural support to the glomerulus and help in modulating the filtration surface area by contracting or relaxing. They do not release adenosine.

 

Option D. Podocytes: Podocytes are specialized cells of the visceral layer of Bowman's capsule that help maintain the filtration barrier in the glomerulus. They do not release adenosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macula densa cells in the kidney release adenosine in response to an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) as part of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, which helps regulate GFR by constricting the afferent arteriole.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic right lower quadrant pain and a history of intermittent fever. CT shows a 3.5 cm cystic mass at the appendix tip with calcifications, suspicious of malignancy. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right hemicolectomy

 

  • Appendiceal neoplasms >2 cm (especially mucinous tumors) require right hemicolectomy due to the risk of malignancy and lymphatic spread.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open appendectomy: Open appendectomy is insufficient for neoplasms >2 cm.

 

Option C. Percutaneous drainage and antibiotics: Percutaneous drainage is for abscesses, not neoplasms.

 

Option D. Follow-up with serial imaging: Observation risks progression of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Mucinous appendiceal neoplasms >2 cm require right hemicolectomy to ensure complete removal and minimize malignancy risks.

questions.text: A healthcare provider is instructing a nursing student on the administration of intramuscular injections using the Z track technique. Which of the following medications is most appropriately administered using this technique due to its potential for causing severe local reactions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron dextran.

 

  • Iron dextran, used for treating iron deficiency anemia, is known for its potential to cause staining and irritation when injected. 
  • The Z track method is particularly useful for such medications as it prevents the medication from tracking back to the surface, thereby minimizing staining and local irritation. 
  • This technique ensures that the injection remains deep within the muscle, reducing the likelihood of leakage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rapid-acting insulin: Incorrect as insulin is typically administered subcutaneously and does not usually cause severe local reactions.

 

Option B. Vaccine adjuvants: Incorrect because vaccines are generally not administered using the Z track technique unless specifically indicated due to their content.

 

Option D. Heparin: Incorrect as heparin is typically given subcutaneously and does not require Z track technique for its administration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Recognize the application of the Z track technique for medications like iron dextran that are prone to causing local discoloration and irritation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman in an urban area is brought to the hospital with symptoms of fever, chills, and unilateral swelling on her arm. She mentions that she recently visited a rural area where there was a suspected bioterrorism event involving an infected animal. On examination, the patient has buboes in her axilla and the diagnostic test confirms the presence of Yersinia pestis. Given the potential of this pathogen for large-scale dissemination, which bioterrorism agent classification best fits this agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A 

 

  • Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent due to its high mortality, ease of dissemination (especially via aerosolized transmission), and its ability to cause significant public panic.
  • Plague can lead to bubonic, septic, or pneumonic forms, and the buboes seen in this patient’s axilla are a classic sign of bubonic plague. 
  • Given its potential for widespread impact, plague is a serious concern for bioterrorism preparedness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: Category B agents, such as salmonella, cause moderate morbidity but low mortality, and do not match the high fatality seen with plague.
 

Option C. Category C: Category C agents like Nipah virus are emerging pathogens but do not have the same historical precedent or immediate threat as plague for bioterrorism.
 

Option D. Category D: Category D does not exist in the classification system for bioterrorism agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Category A bioterrorism agents can be easily disseminated, have high mortality rates and lead to public panic & disruption. Agents include Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Small pox, Plague, Viral haemorrhagic fevers
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are moderately easy to disseminate, cause moderate morbidity with low mortality, require enhanced diagnostic capacity with enhanced surveillance
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are new emerging pathogens that are available, have ease of production and exhibit high morbidity and mortality

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with menstrual irregularities, obesity, and infertility presents with an ovarian mass. Imaging reveals a solid tumor with fluid-filled cystic areas. Histopathology shows coffee bean nuclei and Call Exner bodies. Which of the following markers would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibin B

 

  • The presence of coffee bean nuclei and Call Exner bodies on histopathology is characteristic of Granulosa cell tumors, which are commonly seen in elderly females. 
  • The inhibin B marker is specific for these tumors, as they secrete inhibin B, which is involved in regulating the gonadotropin levels.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. AFP: AFP is a marker for Yolk Sac tumor, not Granulosa cell tumor.
 

Option C. HCG: HCG is elevated in gestational trophoblastic disease or choriocarcinoma, not Granulosa cell tumors.
 

Option D. CA-125: CA-125 is not specific for Granulosa cell tumors and is used for other ovarian malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Granulosa cell tumors are associated with inhibin B production and are characterized by Call Exner bodies and coffee bean nuclei on histology.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with a history of diabetes and myocardial infarction (MI) was admitted to the ICU one day ago for sepsis due to pneumococcal pneumonia with bacteremia. He was started on antibiotics, fluids, and noradrenaline to stabilize his blood pressure. Over the past 2 hours, he has developed worsening abdominal pain, distension, and bloody stools. His vital signs include:

 

  • Blood pressure: 100/50 mmHg
  • Heart rate: 100/min
  • Respiratory rate: 22/min
  • SpO₂: 93% on high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO)

 

On examination, his abdomen is diffusely tender with no audible bowel sounds. An CT image showed air fluid levels.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia

 

  • This patient’s presentation is most consistent with nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia (NOMI). 
  • NOMI is a form of intestinal ischemia caused by decreased mesenteric perfusion in the absence of arterial occlusion. 
  • Contributing factors in this patient include:
    • Sepsis and shock requiring noradrenaline, which reduces splanchnic perfusion.
    • Bloody stools, abdominal pain, and radiographic findings of bowel air-fluid levels are typical for intestinal ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial embolism: This typically presents with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain and is often associated with embolic risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation). However, this patient’s symptoms developed in the setting of systemic hypoperfusion, favoring NOMI.

 

Option B. Clostridium difficile colitis: While this can cause abdominal pain and bloody stools, it is less likely in this setting, as there is no history of recent antibiotic use beyond sepsis treatment, and radiographs would show colonic thickening, not small bowel air-fluid levels.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): IBD is unlikely in an older patient with no prior history of chronic diarrhea or inflammatory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia is a common cause of intestinal ischemia in critically ill patients with systemic hypoperfusion. 
  • It should be suspected in patients with risk factors like sepsis, vasopressor use, and abdominal pain.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man presents with a 5-week history of progressive dyspnea and intermittent fever. Blood tests show the following:

 

  • Total leukocyte count (TLC): 18,000/µL
  • Elevated CRP and ESR

 

A chest X-ray reveals bilateral areas of consolidation. Empirical antibiotics are started, but the patient shows no improvement. A CT chest image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryptogenic organising Pneumonia

 

  • This case represents the classic presentation of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP), where patients initially appear to have community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) but fail to respond to multiple courses of antibiotics.
  • A lung biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test, revealing organizing pneumonia without organisms or positive cultures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA): Requires a background of asthma or wheezing, which this patient lacks. Additionally, ABPA typically presents with bronchiectasis rather than consolidations.

 

Option B. Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: Presents with progressive dyspnea and dry cough over months to years, with chest X-ray findings of interstitial reticulonodular patterns, not new consolidations.

 

Option C. Goodpasture Syndrome: Involves pulmonary-renal syndrome with hemoptysis and renal dysfunction (hematuria, proteinuria). This patient lacks renal involvement and hemoptysis.

 

Educational Objective:


When a patient with suspected pneumonia fails to improve with antibiotics and develops new consolidations, COP should be suspected, confirmed by lung biopsy.

choices.text: Low hunger levels, indicating effective measures for food security and nutritional health.
Moderate hunger levels, suggesting the country faces some challenges but manageable food insecurity.
Alarming hunger levels, requiring immediate intervention due to widespread food insecurity and malnutrition.
Extremely alarming hunger levels, indicating a severe food crisis requiring urgent global intervention.

questions.text: A researcher studying global hunger indicators analyzes data on the Global Hunger Index (GHI) for a country with a reported GHI score of 42.3. The score places the country in a critical range. Based on the GHI classification system, how would the hunger situation in this country be described?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alarming hunger levels, requiring immediate intervention due to widespread food insecurity and malnutrition.

 

  • A GHI score of 35-49.9 is classified as Alarming, indicating that food insecurity is a pressing concern. 
  • Immediate measures are needed to address the growing malnutrition and the increasing risk of hunger crises in the country.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Global Hunger Index (GHI)

 

  • The Global Hunger Index is a tool designed to comprehensively measure and track hunger at the global, regional, and country levels.
  • The International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) calculates GHI scores each year to assess progress, or the lack thereof, in combating hunger.

 

GHI Classification and Interpretation:

choices.text: Go for screw fixation of L1 vertebra

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady got compression fracture of L1 vertebra. There is no neurological deficit to this patient. What advise will you give for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start Anti-osteoporotic treatment

 

  • Osteoporotic compression fractures are common in elderly patients, particularly in postmenopausal women.
  • Osteoporosis weakens bones, making them more prone to fractures, especially in the spine. 
  • In the absence of neurological deficit, the primary treatment is to address osteoporosis itself to prevent further fractures.
  • Anti-osteoporotic treatment typically includes medications like bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate), denosumab, or selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) to improve bone density and reduce the risk of future fractures. 
  • The patient may also be advised to take calcium and vitamin D supplements.
  • This approach focuses on improving bone health to prevent more fractures in the future, which is crucial for older patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Do MRI scan: An MRI scan is typically used to evaluate soft tissues or identify spinal cord involvement or other structural abnormalities. However, in this patient, there is no neurological deficit, so an MRI is not immediately necessary for assessing the compression fracture. MRI could be considered if there were signs of neurological involvement, or if there was concern about a more complex pathology (e.g., malignancy or infection), but in the absence of these symptoms, this option is not needed.

 

Option C. Go for screw fixation of L1 vertebra: Screw fixation or surgical intervention is typically reserved for cases with significant neurological deficit, severe deformity, or instability. Since the patient has no neurological symptoms and the compression fracture is likely osteoporotic, surgery is generally not required. Most compression fractures in elderly patients are managed conservatively with pain management, bracing, and osteoporosis treatment. Surgical intervention may be necessary if the fracture is unstable, causing significant pain, or if there is a risk of further collapse.

 

Option D. To take Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for reducing inflammation and swelling. It is typically used in cases of severe inflammation, conditions like spinal cord compression with inflammation, or other inflammatory diseases. If there is no evidence of inflammation, and corticosteroids this would not be appropriate. In fact, long-term use of corticosteroids can increase the risk of osteoporosis and further fractures, so it would not be advisable for the patient. The focus should be on anti-osteoporotic treatment rather than steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate action is to start anti-osteoporotic treatment to address the underlying bone weakness that led to the compression fracture. 
  • This will help in preventing further fractures and managing the patient's bone health.

choices.text: Painful, soft ulcers with marked swelling

questions.text: Which of the following features is characteristic of donovanosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Painless beefy-red ulcer

 

  • Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with a painless, beefy-red ulcer.
  • It is characterized by progressive ulceration and granulomatous inflammation. 
  • The lesion often has a red, moist appearance and may develop fleshy granulomatous tissue around it.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Painful, soft ulcers with marked swelling:  Painful, soft ulcers with marked swelling with marked swelling are more typical of chancroid.
 

Option C. Multiple, painful, vesicular lesions: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) typically causes painful, vesicular lesions that rapidly ulcerate.
 

Option D. Single, indurated, painless ulcer: Syphilis usually presents with a single, painless indurated ulcer (chancre), not the beefy-red appearance of donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Differential diagnoses

questions.text: A patient presents with joint deformities and pain reminiscent of rheumatoid arthritis, as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Farber's Disease

 

  • Farber’s disease, a rare lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in acid ceramidase, characteristically presents with joint swelling and deformities, subcutaneous nodules, and progressive arthritis that may mimic rheumatoid arthritis. 
  • These symptoms are due to the accumulation of ceramide in the lysosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tay-Sachs Disease: Incorrect, as it primarily affects the central nervous system in infants, leading to neurodegeneration, not joint deformities.

 

Option C. Fabry's Disease: Incorrect, while it involves lysosomal storage, its main symptoms include pain, kidney failure, and heart issues, not arthritis-like joint deformities.

 

Option D. Gaucher's Disease: Incorrect, primarily involves hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and marrow infiltration, but does not typically present with joint deformities that mimic rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Identify and differentiate between lysosomal storage disorders based on symptomatology, focusing on Farber's disease and its unique presentation with arthritis-like symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of 4th and 5th distal interphalangeal joint and was not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. The nerve likely to be injured lies in relation to which part of the bone as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

  • The ulnar nerve passes posterior to the medial epicondyle (marked D) of the humerus. This is the most common site of injury leading to weakness in the 4th and 5th fingers, as described.
  • Ulnar nerve injury affects the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus and medial lumbricals, resulting in a claw hand. The inability to hold a piece of paper (Froment’s sign) occurs due to weakened adductor pollicis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: Refers to the humeral head. This part is not related to ulnar nerve injury but may involve axillary nerve injury in shoulder dislocations.

 

Option B. B: Refers to the humeral shaft. The radial nerve lies in the spiral groove here, and its injury causes wrist drop, not claw hand.

 

Option C. C: Refers to the lateral epicondyle. It is related to the origin of the extensor muscles and does not involve the ulnar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with metastatic melanoma has progressed despite initial therapy with targeted agents. Which immune checkpoint inhibitor, known for its effectiveness in melanoma, should be considered next in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ipilimumab

 

  • Ipilimumab is another immune checkpoint inhibitor like Nivolumab but targets CTLA-4, another regulatory protein on T cells. 
  • It is particularly known for its use in melanoma, often in combination with PD-1 inhibitors like Nivolumab, to enhance immune response against advanced stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infliximab: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor, primarily used for inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease. It is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor and is not used in the treatment of melanoma.

 

Option B. Trastuzumab: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 protein, primarily used in HER2-positive breast cancer and some gastric cancers. It is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor and is not used in the treatment of melanoma.

 

Option D. Denosumab: Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets RANKL (receptor activator of nuclear factor-kappa B ligand). It is primarily used to prevent skeletal-related events in patients with bone metastases from various cancers and to treat osteoporosis. It is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor and is not used as a primary systemic treatment for melanoma itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Ipilimumab, a CTLA-4 inhibitor, enhances T-cell activation and is effective in metastatic melanoma. It is often used alone or with PD-1 inhibitors like nivolumab for advanced disease.

choices.text: Monthly complete blood counts for the first six months, then biannually.
Weekly complete blood counts for the first six months, then biweekly thereafter.
Daily neutrophil monitoring for the first month, then weekly.
Complete blood counts every visit without a defined schedule.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is reviewing a 37-year-old female patient with schizophrenia on clozapine therapy during a routine follow-up. To prevent the severe adverse effect of agranulocytosis, which of the following monitoring strategies should be implemented?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weekly complete blood counts for the first six months, then biweekly thereafter.

 

  • The monitoring protocol for patients on clozapine requires weekly complete blood counts for the first six months due to the high risk of agranulocytosis, followed by biweekly monitoring if the initial six months are uneventful. 
  • This stringent monitoring helps in early detection of neutropenia, allowing for prompt intervention to prevent progression to agranulocytosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Apply the appropriate monitoring protocol for neutrophil counts in patients treated with clozapine to detect early signs of agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a history of fever, malaise, and fatigue. A blood smear reveals parvovirus B19 infection, which can cause erythema infectiosum. Which of the following is the receptor that Parvovirus B19 uses to enter host cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P antigen on RBCs

 

  • Parvovirus B19 binds to the P antigen found on red blood cells (RBCs) to enter the host cell. 
  • This receptor binding is essential for the virus’s ability to infect and replicate in erythroid progenitor cells, which is why parvovirus B19 often causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) in children.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Nicotinic AChR: This is the receptor used by Rabies, not Parvovirus B19.
 

Option C. CD21: This is used by EBV, not Parvovirus B19.
 

Option D. ACE2: This is the receptor for SARS-CoV-2, not Parvovirus B19.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a history of asthma presents with lesions localized to the flexural areas of the elbows and knees as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis often occurs in children with a history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis). 

  • The characteristic features include pruritic, erythematous lesions in flexural areas, frequently exacerbated by environmental factors.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scabies: Presents with burrows and intense itching, often in interdigital spaces.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Typically involves extensor surfaces with silvery scales, not flexural areas.

 

Option C. Impetigo: A bacterial infection characterized by honey-colored crusts, not scaly plaques.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis presents with pruritic, erythematous, scaly lesions in flexural areas, often associated with a history of atopy.

choices.text: Production of enterotoxins leading to chloride ion secretion in the intestines
Preformed toxins causing gastrointestinal upset shortly after ingestion
Ingestion of spores that activate toxin production after colonization
Severe inflammation due to bacterial invasion and cytotoxicity

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramping after eating seafood at a beach resort. Symptoms began 6 hours after ingestion and have progressively worsened. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of Vibrio cholerae. Which of the following factors is most important in explaining the rapid onset and severity of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Production of enterotoxins leading to chloride ion secretion in the intestines

 

  • Vibrio cholerae is known for producing cholera toxin, which stimulates the secretion of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen. 
  • This causes massive fluid loss, resulting in watery diarrhea. 
  • The rapid onset (within 6 hours) of symptoms is characteristic of Vibrio cholerae infection, typically associated with seafood or water contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preformed toxins causing gastrointestinal upset shortly after ingestion: This description applies to Bacillus cereus or Staphylococcus aureus, which cause vomiting and diarrhea within 1–6 hours but do not cause the severe watery diarrhea seen in cholera.


Option C. Ingestion of spores that activate toxin production after colonization: This describes the pathophysiology of Clostridium perfringens or Bacillus cereus, which have longer incubation periods and do not cause cholera-like diarrhea.


Option D. Severe inflammation due to bacterial invasion and cytotoxicity: This fits Shigella species, which cause inflammatory diarrhea but not watery diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, leading to massive chloride ion secretion and watery diarrhea within 6 hours after ingestion of contaminated seafood or water.

choices.text: It appears as an echo-free structure
It is seen with increased echoes in deeper structures
It produces echoes in all regions

questions.text: Which of the following is true about bile on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It appears as an echo-free structure

 

  • Bile is a homogeneous fluid, meaning it does not produce echoes on ultrasound, and it appears as an echo-free structure. 
  • This is a key characteristic of homogeneous fluids like bile, urine, and cyst contents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It causes acoustic shadowing: Incorrect. Acoustic shadowing is typically caused by solid or calcified structures, not fluid.

 

Option C. It is seen with increased echoes in deeper structures: Incorrect. Posterior enhancement may occur with homogeneous fluids, not increased echoes.

 

Option D. It produces echoes in all regions: Incorrect. Bile does not produce echoes in general.

 

Educational Objective:


Bile appears as an echo-free structure on ultrasound due to its homogeneous nature.

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A

  1. Japanese encephalitis vaccine schedule
  2. Contraindication to pertussis vaccination
  3. Mission Indradhanush vaccine coverage
  4. Universal birth vaccines

 

Column B

  1. Two doses 1 month apart with a booster 1-2 years later
  2. Includes DPT, OPV, Hepatitis B, but not Japanese encephalitis
  3. BCG, OPV, Hepatitis B
  4. Encephalopathy within 7 days after previous dose
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-A, 2-D, 3-B, 4-C

 

  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine schedule (1-A): Administered as two doses 1 month apart, with a booster 1-2 years later.
  • Contraindication to pertussis vaccination (2-D): Absolute contraindication includes encephalopathy within 7 days of the prior dose of DPT.
  • Mission Indradhanush vaccine coverage (3-B): Includes seven life-threatening diseases (DPT, Hepatitis B, OPV) but excludes Japanese encephalitis as a routine vaccine.
  • Universal birth vaccines (4-C): At birth, vaccines include BCG, OPV zero dose, and Hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine schedule : Administered as two doses 1 month apart, with a booster 1-2 years later.
  • Contraindication to pertussis vaccination : Absolute contraindication includes encephalopathy within 7 days of the prior dose of DPT.
  • Mission Indradhanush vaccine coverage : Includes seven life-threatening diseases (DPT, Hepatitis B, OPV) but excludes Japanese encephalitis as a routine vaccine.
  • Universal birth vaccines : At birth, vaccines include BCG, OPV zero dose, and Hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoes renal transplantation. Within minutes of vascular anastomosis, the transplanted kidney becomes mottled and cyanotic. What is the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Donor-specific antibody-mediated injury

 

  • Hyperacute rejection occurs due to preformed donor-specific antibodies activating the complement system, leading to immediate graft failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity: Acute T-cell-mediated rejection occurs days to weeks later.

 

Option C. Ischemia-reperfusion injury: Ischemia-reperfusion injury does not cause immediate mottling.

 

Option D. Cytokine release syndrome: Cytokine release is unrelated to transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed donor-specific antibodies, requiring pre-transplant crossmatch tests to prevent this complication.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a long history of smoking presents with fatigue and intermittent fevers. Laboratory studies show a markedly elevated white blood cell count with characteristic cells as marked in the peripheral smear image. Which of the following is the most likely genetic abnormality associated with this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deletion of 13q

 

  • The most common genetic abnormality in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is the deletion of 13q, which is associated with a better prognosis in CLL. 
  • The presence of smudge cells and the clinical features further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Translocation t(9;22):Translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML), not CLL.

 

Option C. Mutation in p53: p53 mutations are associated with some cancers but are not common in CLL.

 

Option D. Amplification of HER2/neu:HER2/neu amplification is seen in breast cancer, not CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Deletion of 13q is the most common genetic abnormality in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL).

questions.text: During a pesticide training session for agricultural workers, the instructor highlights a pesticide used in rodent control that is classified as extremely toxic and carries a red label. The instructor explains that this pesticide has a high mortality rate and is dangerous if ingested. Which of the following pesticides is most likely being discussed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc phosphide

 

  • Zinc phosphide is extremely toxic and carries a red label. It is used in rodent control, and ingestion can result in severe poisoning.
  • The red label is an indicator of the highest level of toxicity among pesticides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endosulfan: Endosulfan is highly toxic (yellow label) and is more likely to cause neurological symptoms rather than severe gastrointestinal distress.


Option C. Malathion: Malathion is moderately toxic (blue label) and is much less toxic than Zinc phosphide.


Option D. Mosquito repellants: Mosquito repellants are slightly toxic (green label), and are used for insect repellent rather than rodent control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxicity Colour Labels of Pesticides in India:

 

  • Red label: Extremely toxic – Zinc phosphide 
  • Yellow label: Highly toxic – Endosulphan 
  • Blue label: Moderately toxic – Malathion 
  • Green label: Slightly toxic – Mosquito repellents

choices.text: Twin pregnancy precludes the use of oxytocin
Amniotomy decreases the need for oxytocin use
Methods of augmentation do not increase the risk of operative delivery
Associated with a risk of uterine hyperstimulation

questions.text: All of the following are true about augmentation of labor except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Twin pregnancy precludes the use of oxytocin

 

  • Twin pregnancy does not preclude the use of oxytocin. Studies have shown that twin gestations are associated with similar efficacy and safety of oxytocin for labor augmentation compared to singleton pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amniotomy decreases the need for oxytocin use: Correct; artificial rupture of membranes can stimulate labor, reducing the need for oxytocin.

 

Option C. Methods of augmentation do not increase the risk of operative delivery: Correct; augmentation methods are designed to support vaginal delivery without increasing the need for cesarean or instrumental delivery.

 

Option D. Associated with a risk of uterine hyperstimulation: Correct; oxytocin can cause excessive uterine contractions, leading to fetal distress and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Labor augmentation with oxytocin is safe and effective in twin pregnancies. However, it must be used cautiously due to potential risks, such as uterine hyperstimulation.
  • Amniotomy is another augmentation method that can reduce the need for oxytocin.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Succinylcholine are true? 

 

  1. It is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase.
  2. It is associated with post-operative myalgia.
  3. It can be safely used in patients with burns older than 6 months.
  4. It acts by non-competitive blockade of the acetylcholine receptor.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

1. It is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase: Pseudocholinesterase metabolizes succinylcholine, leading to its short duration.

 

2. It is associated with post-operative myalgia: Post-operative myalgia is a common side effect due to muscle fasciculations.

 

4. It acts by non-competitive blockade of the acetylcholine receptor: Succinylcholine acts via a non-competitive blockade at the acetylcholine receptor.

 

Other Option:

 

3. It can be safely used in patients with burns older than 6 months: Succinylcholine is contraindicated in burn patients even after 6 months due to persistent risk of hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Succinylcholine acts via non-competitive acetylcholine receptor blockade, is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase, and is contraindicated in burn patients due to hyperkalemia risk, even after 6 months.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a recent diagnosis of chickenpox and is at high risk due to a history of immunocompromised family members. The child is eligible for post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent the disease. What is the appropriate dose of varicella immunoglobulin to prevent the development of chickenpox?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 15-25 units /kg BW

 

  • For varicella post-exposure prophylaxis, 15-25 units /kg BW of varicella immunoglobulin (VZIG) is the appropriate dose. 
  • This immunoglobulin provides passive immunity, reducing the severity or preventing the onset of chickenpox in high-risk individuals, such as those with immunocompromised conditions or infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMMUNOGLOBULIN DOSAGES

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A

  1. Social Smile
  2. Baby can walk backwards 
  3. Immature pincer grasp
  4. Mature Pincer Grasp

 

Column B

  1. Develops at 9 months
  2. Seen by 2 years 
  3. Appears at 2 months of age
  4. Achieved at 12 months of age
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

 

  • Social Smile (1-C): Social smile is a milestone that first appears around 2 months of age, as a response to social interactions.
  • Baby can walk backwards (2-B): A baby can walk backwards by two years
  • Immature pincer grasp (3-A): Immature Pincer Grasp comes by nine months
  • Mature Pincer Grasp (4-D): Mature pincer grasp comes by 12 months.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Social Smile : Social smile is a milestone that first appears around 2 months of age, as a response to social interactions.
  • Baby can walk backwards : A baby can walk backwards by two years
  • Immature pincer grasp : Immature Pincer Grasp comes by nine months
  • Mature Pincer Grasp : Mature pincer grasp comes by 12 months.

questions.text: In a nutrition-focused health survey, a significant portion of the population reports low dietary intake of protein, leading to muscle wasting and generalized weakness. Biochemical testing reveals deficient levels of methionine. Considering the nutritional implications, which of the following amino acids is now conditionally essential for these individuals?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cysteine

 

  • When methionine intake is deficient, cysteine becomes conditionally essential because cysteine is synthesized from methionine. 
  • Without adequate methionine, the body cannot produce sufficient cysteine, which leads to deficiency and necessitates supplementation through diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is conditionally essential when phenylalanine is deficient, not related to methionine deficiency.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is essential and not dependent on methionine metabolism.

 

Option D. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved in nitrogen metabolism but is not directly related to methionine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Conditionally Essential Amino Acids (CEAA): Nonessential amino acids may turn essential if their precursors are limited in the body 
  • There are 2 CEAA, namely, Tyrosine (derived from Phenylalanine) and Cysteine (derived from methionine)

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Assertion is false, but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: Peristalsis always moves from the oral end to the anal end of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Reason: The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, but Reason is false.

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Peristalsis always moves from the oral end to the anal end of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

  • This statement is true. Peristalsis is a coordinated, rhythmic contraction and relaxation of smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal tract that propels food and other materials forward. The movement is unidirectional, from the oral end to the anal end, ensuring the proper progression of digestive contents.

 

Reason: The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).

 

  • This statement is false. Nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) are responsible for relaxation in the relaxation segment of peristalsis. These neurotransmitters help reduce muscle tone to allow the bolus to pass.

     

  • The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by acetylcholine (ACh) and substance P, which cause localized contraction of the smooth muscles behind the bolus to push it forward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by acetylcholine and substance P, while nitric oxide and VIP mediate the relaxation segment.

choices.text: Bilateral cataracts and sensorineural hearing loss
Ventricular septal defect and single umbilical artery
Coarctation of the aorta and choanal atresia

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with congenital rubella syndrome. Which of the following features are most likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral cataracts and sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Congenital rubella syndrome commonly presents with the triad of bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and PDA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular septal defect and single umbilical artery: VSD is less common than PDA, and single umbilical artery is not associated with rubella.

 

Option C. Coarctation of the aorta and choanal atresia: Coarctation of the aorta and choanal atresia are unrelated to rubella.

 

Option D. Unilateral cataract and craniosynostosis: Cataracts in rubella are bilateral, not unilateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and PDA.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins is most likely to cause luminescent stools that may appear yellowish or greenish due to phosphorescence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

 

  • Phosphorus poisoning leads to yellowish-green luminescent stools due to its phosphorescent nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Lead poisoning → Causes constipation, dark stools, and bluish gum lines.

 

Option B. Iron: Iron poisoning → Causes black or dark green stools due to iron sulfide formation.

 

Option D. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning → Causes greenish or blackish stools but does not glow.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A (Conditions):

  1. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)
  2. Down Syndrome
  3. Fragile X Syndrome
  4. Congenital Rubella Syndrome

 

Column B (Key Features):

  1. Continuous machinery murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus
  2. Gower’s sign and pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles.
  3. Intellectual disability, large ears, and prominent square jaw.
  4. Intellectual disability, flat facial profile, and single palmar crease.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

  • 1-B (Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy): Hallmarked by Gower’s sign and pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to dystrophin deletion.
  • 2-D (Down Syndrome): Flat facial profile, single palmar crease, and intellectual disability are key features.
  • 3-C (Fragile X Syndrome): Intellectual disability with prominent jaw and large ears.

  • 4-A (Congenital Rubella Syndrome): PDA causes a continuous machinery murmur.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • (Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy): Hallmarked by Gower’s sign and pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to dystrophin deletion.
  • (Down Syndrome): Flat facial profile, single palmar crease, and intellectual disability are key features.
  • (Fragile X Syndrome): Intellectual disability with prominent jaw and large ears.
  • (Congenital Rubella Syndrome): PDA causes a continuous machinery murmur.

questions.text: Match the following causes of antepartum hemorrhage with their clinical features:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • 1-B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa typically causes painless bleeding due to placental implantation near the cervical os.
  • 2-A. Abruptio placentae: Painful bleeding is a hallmark of placental abruption due to separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.
  • 3-C. Uterine rupture: Fetal bradycardia and maternal shock are key findings in uterine rupture.
  • 4-D. Vasa previa: Vaginal bleeding after membrane rupture, with fetal blood loss, is characteristic of vasa previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa: Placenta previa typically causes painless bleeding due to placental implantation near the cervical os.
  • Abruptio placentae: Painful bleeding is a hallmark of placental abruption due to separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.
  • Uterine rupture: Fetal bradycardia and maternal shock are key findings in uterine rupture.
  • Vasa previa: Vaginal bleeding after membrane rupture, with fetal blood loss, is characteristic of vasa previa.

questions.text: In a research setting, you are asked to measure the adequacy of pasteurization in milk. You use the Standard Plate Count method to determine the bacterial load. What is the maximum bacterial count permissible in pasteurized milk according to the regulatory standards?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30,000 bacteria per ml(cfu/ml)

 

  • The Standard Plate Count method measures the total bacterial count in milk, and the regulatory standard for pasteurized milk is that the bacterial count should not exceed 30,000 bacteria per ml(cfu/ml). 
  • This ensures that pasteurization is effective in reducing the microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The angle formed between the lesion and the chest wall

questions.text: Which radiological feature best differentiates a pleural lesion from a parenchymal lesion on a chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The angle formed between the lesion and the chest wall

 

  • Pleural lesions form an obtuse angle with the chest wall, while parenchymal lesions form an acute angle. 
  • This distinction is key for differentiating between the two on a chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The size of the lesion: Size alone cannot definitively differentiate pleural from parenchymal lesions.

 

Option B. The location of the lesion: The location of the lesion is not the primary factor in differentiation.

 

Option D. The density of the lesion: The density of the lesion may vary, but the angle formed with the chest wall is the distinguishing feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pleural lesions create an obtuse angle with the chest wall, while parenchymal lesions form an acute angle.

choices.text: The overlapping confidence intervals indicate that the differences in survival between the two groups are statistically significant.
The overlapping confidence intervals suggest that there is a high degree of uncertainty about the true survival estimates for both groups.
The log-rank test should be used to determine if the observed overlap in the confidence intervals is significant.
The study results suggest that the Kaplan-Meier estimator is not appropriate for this type of analysis.

questions.text: In a study examining the effect of two interventions on patient survival, the Kaplan-Meier survival curve is plotted for both groups. The curves show similar trends, but confidence intervals around the survival curves overlap significantly throughout the study period. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The overlapping confidence intervals suggest that there is a high degree of uncertainty about the true survival estimates for both groups.

 

  • When the confidence intervals around Kaplan-Meier survival curves overlap significantly, it indicates that there is substantial uncertainty regarding the differences in survival between the two groups. 
  • This overlap suggests that no clear evidence supports one treatment being superior to the other, as the true survival functions for both groups may be very similar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The overlapping confidence intervals indicate that the differences in survival between the two groups are statistically significant:  Overlapping confidence intervals typically indicate lack of statistical significance and should be interpreted with caution, not as evidence of significance.


Option C. The log-rank test should be used to determine if the observed overlap in the confidence intervals is significant: While the log-rank test can assess survival differences, the overlap of confidence intervals itself does not directly indicate a need for the test; it simply reflects uncertainty.


Option D. The study results suggest that the Kaplan-Meier estimator is not appropriate for this type of analysis: The Kaplan-Meier estimator is appropriate for survival analysis and provides valuable insight even in the presence of overlapping confidence intervals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Overlapping confidence intervals around Kaplan-Meier survival curves indicate uncertainty about survival differences between groups and suggest the need for further statistical testing.

questions.text: Match the modifications for intubation with the respective clinical situations:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

 

1-C: Nasal intubation is preferred in oral cancer surgery

 

2-B: The prone position is used for intubation in spine surgeries.

 

3-A: RAMP position helps obese patients by improving alignment of the pharyngeal-laryngeal axis.

 

4-D: MILS is used for airway management in trauma patients with cervical spine injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nasal intubation is preferred in oral cancer surgery
  • The prone position is used for intubation in spine surgeries.
  • RAMP position helps obese patients by improving alignment of the pharyngeal-laryngeal axis.
  • MILS is used for airway management in trauma patients with cervical spine injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an aggressive periosteal reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thick and irregular

 

  • The inner cambium layer of periosteum responds to localized insult or injury by forming a new layer of bone along the surface of the underlying cortex; this new bone formation is called periosteal reaction.
  • Such periosteal reaction can be divided into aggressive and non-aggressive reaction or no reaction at all.
  • Non-aggressive reactions are thin, solid, thick and irregular.
  • Aggressive reactions are spiculated, laminated, hair-on-end, sun burst, disorganised, interrupted and Codman’s triangle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiculated: Spiculated periosteal reactions are aggressive reactions, commonly seen in malignant lesions like osteosarcoma as sunray appearance. 

 

 

Option B. Laminated: Lamellated are aggressive reactions that are seen in malignant or chronic lesions like chronic osteomyelitis, ewing’s sarcoma as onion peel appearance. 

 

 

Option D. Interrupted: Interrupted type of periosteal reaction is seen when the periosteum cannot produce new bone as fast as the growth of the lesion. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • These categories are not synonymous with benign and malignant, as there are benign entities capable of inducing aggressive periosteal reaction (e.g., infection and Langerhans cell histiocytosis) and numerous malignant entities that more commonly manifest with either non-aggressive periosteal.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS-P score of a patient brought into the ER with history of fall from a motorcycle. He is just making incomprehensible sounds, has a completely flexed posture and only opens his eyes to knuckle pressure. On examination, right pupil is unreactive to light?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

  • To calculate the GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils) score for the patient, we will assess the eye, verbal, and motor responses, and then adjust for pupil reactivity.
    1. Eye response: The patient opens eyes to knuckle pressure (pain), which scores a 2.
    2. Verbal response: The patient is making incomprehensible sounds, which scores a 2.

    3. Motor response: The patient has a completely flexed posture, which is consistent with decorticate posturing, which scores a 3.

       

Adding these together:

 

Eye Response + Verbal Response + Motor Response=2+2+3=7

Now, for the pupillary response:

One pupil is unreactive to light, which subtracts 1 from the GCS score.

GCS Score−Pupillary Score=7−1=6

The final GCS-P score is 6.

The correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response. 
  • It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries. 
  • The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer develops symptoms of jaundice and abdominal pain after drinking water from a contaminated river. Stool examination reveals operculated eggs measuring 150 μm x 60–70 μm. Which of the following parasites is most likely the cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrodiscoides hominis

 

  • The presence of operculated eggs measuring 150 μm x 60–70 μm is characteristic of Gastrodiscoides hominis, which is typically transmitted through contaminated water or food. 
  • This parasite can lead to symptoms such as abdominal pain and jaundice when it affects the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Opistorchus viverrini: This parasite’s eggs are also operculated but are smaller, measuring 27 μm x 15 μm, not the larger size observed here.


Option C. Fasciola gigantica: This parasite produces much larger eggs, exceeding 100 microns in length, unlike the eggs in this case.


Option D. Ancylostoma caninum: This parasite does not produce eggs in human stool, and it causes cutaneous larva migrans, not gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 66-year-old man, Mr. Ramesh from Delhi, presents to the emergency department with sudden onset confusion and altered mental status. Earlier in the day, he complained of a severe headache and was later found disoriented. He has a history of poorly controlled hypertension but no prior strokes. On examination, his blood pressure is 210/110 mmHg, and he is lethargic but arousable. Neurological exam reveals right-sided hemiparesis. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shown below. Which of the following is not a common site for hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital lobe

 

  • Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhages commonly occur in deep brain structures due to chronic small vessel damage (lipohyalinosis and microaneurysm formation). 
  • The basal ganglia, thalamus, cerebellum, and pons are the most frequent sites. 
  • The occipital lobe, being part of the cerebral cortex, is rarely involved in hypertensive bleeds and is more commonly associated with lobar hemorrhages due to cerebral amyloid angiopathy in elderly patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal ganglia: The most common site for hypertensive hemorrhages, especially the putamen.

 

Option B. Thalamus: Another frequent site due to its rich small vessel network vulnerable to hypertensive damage.

 

Option C. Cerebellum: Though less common, cerebellar hemorrhages are seen in hypertension and can cause life-threatening brainstem compression.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhages typically affect deep brain structures like the basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, and cerebellum. 
  • Lobar regions, such as the occipital lobe, are uncommon sites and suggest alternative etiologies like amyloid angiopathy.

questions.text: Following penetrating trauma to abdomen, urinary leak from left ureter was noted. Which of these is not a technique of ureteric reconstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nesbitt procedure

 

  • It is used for correction of penile chordee, not for ureteric injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Boari flap: A Boari flap is a surgical technique used to reconstruct the ureter when there is a longer segment loss, particularly in the pelvic ureter. It involves mobilizing the bladder and creating a flap from its wall to lengthen and reposition the ureter, allowing for a tension-free anastomosis.

 

Option B. End to end anastomosis: End-to-end anastomosis involves directly connecting the two ends of the severed ureter to restore continuity. While it may be suitable for shorter segment losses or partial transections, it may not be feasible for cases involving major loss of ureteric length.

 

Option D. Uretero-ureterostomy: Uretero-ureterostomy involves surgically connecting the injured ureter to the contralateral healthy ureter. This technique is particularly useful for managing major loss of ureteric length following penetrating trauma to the abdomen, providing a viable option for restoring urinary flow without the need for complex reconstructive procedures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In cases of partial transection, primary repair over a DJ stent may be performed. 
  • A tension-free spatulated ureteric anastomosis using fine absorbable sutures can be done for short segment loss. 
  • This is usually done in upper ureteric injuries.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic for a routine eye examination. The child appears to have an esotropic appearance, but there is no true misalignment of the eyes. The examiner suspects pseudostrabismus. Which of the following factors can contribute to the appearance of pseudostrabismus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telecanthus

 

  • Telecanthus, which refers to an increased distance between the medial canthi of the eyes, can make the eyes appear misaligned, leading to pseudostrabismus (an apparent squint without actual ocular misalignment). 
  • This condition is often seen in children, and it is important to distinguish it from true strabismus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive angle kappa: A positive angle kappa is a condition where the reflection of light from the cornea is displaced nasally, which can create the appearance of strabismus, but it does not directly lead to pseudostrabismus.

 

Option C. Wide inter-pupillary distance: A wide inter-pupillary distance may cause a slight appearance of misalignment, but it is not a common cause of pseudostrabismus.

 

Option D. Eurblepharon: This refers to a wide palpebral fissure, often associated with eyelid anomalies, but it does not directly contribute to pseudostrabismus.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Telecanthus can lead to pseudostrabismus by creating the appearance of misalignment between the eyes due to an increased distance between the medial canthi.

choices.text: By decreasing lower esophageal sphincter tone.
By stimulating chloride channels in the gut.
By activating 5-HT4 receptors to enhance acetylcholine release.
By inhibiting dopamine receptors in the enteric nervous system.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with a history of chronic constipation is started on Prucalopride. What is the primary mechanism by which Prucalopride improves symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) By activating 5-HT4 receptors to enhance acetylcholine release.

 

  • Prucalopride exerts its prokinetic effects through the selective activation of 5-HT4 receptors on enteric neurons, which leads to an increased release of acetylcholine. 
  • This neurotransmitter plays a crucial role in enhancing colonic motility and promoting the propulsive contractions necessary for improving bowel movements in patients with chronic constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By decreasing lower esophageal sphincter tone: Incorrect as Prucalopride does not specifically target lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Option B. By stimulating chloride channels in the gut: Incorrect because it does not primarily act through stimulation of chloride channels.

 

Option D. By inhibiting dopamine receptors in the enteric nervous system: Incorrect as the drug’s mechanism does not involve inhibition of dopamine receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Identify the action of Prucalopride in enhancing gastrointestinal motility through the specific activation of 5-HT4 receptors and the subsequent increase in acetylcholine release.

choices.text: TTF1 positive, CK7 positive, CK20 negative, napsin A positive
TTF1 positive, CK7 positive, CK20 positive, GATA3 positive
CK20 positive, CK7 negative, TTF-1 negative
TTF1 positive, EMA positive, GFAP positive

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with unintentional weight loss and altered consciousness. CT scan revealed a single big lesion and multiple small lesions in the brain. A biopsy was taken from the brain lesion. Which of the following indicates a metastatic urothelial tumor in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TTF1 positive, CK7 positive, CK20 positive, GATA3 positive

 

  • This 65-year-old woman with a heavy smoking history presents with a single big lesion and multiple small lesions in the brain, suggesting a metastatic malignancy rather than a primary brain tumor. 
  • This IHC profile (TTF-1+, CK7+, CK20+, GATA3+) is characteristic of metastatic urothelial carcinoma.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. TTF1 positive, CK7 positive, CK20 negative, napsin A positive: TTF-1 and napsin A positivity suggest a primary lung adenocarcinoma, not urothelial carcinoma. CK20 negative further argues against urothelial carcinoma.

 

Option C. CK20 positive, CK7 negative, TTF-1 negative: CK20+, CK7−, TTF-1− is highly suggestive of metastatic colorectal carcinoma, not urothelial carcinoma.

 

Option D. TTF1 positive, EMA positive, GFAP positive: GFAP positivity is seen in primary central nervous system tumors (e.g., ependymoma, glioblastoma), not metastatic urothelial carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • IHC profile with TTF-1+, CK7+, CK20+, GATA3+ is characteristic of metastatic urothelial carcinoma

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease presents after receiving a blood transfusion. He develops dyspnea and hypoxia within hours, but his chest X-ray reveals no vascular congestion or pleural effusion. His BNP levels are low, and his Pulmonary Artery Occlusion Pressure (PAOP) is also low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRALI

 

  • The combination of low BNP, low PAOP, no vascular congestion, and no pleural effusion on chest X-ray suggests Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI). 
  • TRALI is caused by a transfusion reaction leading to acute respiratory distress, and the lack of pleural effusion and low BNP levels are key diagnostic features. 
  • TRALI typically presents with hypoxia and respiratory distress within hours of transfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TACO: TACO would show elevated BNP, elevated PAOP, and pleural effusion on chest X-ray, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Aspiration pneumonia: Aspiration pneumonia would show consolidation on chest X-ray, not normal lung fields and no vascular congestion.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: PE would present with sudden-onset dyspnea and might show a normal chest X-ray or small pleural effusions, but would not be associated with low BNP levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TRALI presents with low BNP, low Pulmonary Artery Occlusion Pressure, no vascular congestion, and no pleural effusion, distinguishing it from TACO, aspiration pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the derivatives of the septum transversum and dorsal mesogastrium are correct?

 

  1. The gastro-splenic ligament is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium.
  2. The central tendon of the diaphragm arises from the septum transversum.
  3. The lesser omentum is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.
  4. The ligaments of the liver, including the falciform, triangular, and coronary ligaments, arise from the dorsal mesogastrium.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

1. The gastro-splenic ligament is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium: This is correct. The dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to several structures, including the gastro-splenic ligament.

 

2. The central tendon of the diaphragm arises from the septum transversum: This is correct. The septum transversum plays a major role in forming the central tendon of the diaphragm.

 

3. The lesser omentum is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium: This is correct. The ventral mesogastrium gives rise to the lesser omentum as well as other ligaments like the falciform ligament.

 

Other Option:

 

4. The ligaments of the liver, including the falciform, triangular, and coronary ligaments, arise from the dorsal mesogastrium: This is incorrect. These ligaments arise from the ventral mesogastrium, which originates from the septum transversum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Based on the images, which plant is more commonly associated with cardiotoxic effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Image A 

 

  • White Oleander (Image A) is a highly toxic plant. Its toxic properties are primarily due to oleandrin, a potent cardiotoxin that affects the heart, leading to fatal arrhythmias when ingested. 
  • White Oleander is commonly associated with serious poisoning risks, including cardiac arrest, nausea, vomiting, and hypotension.
  • On the other hand, White Datura (Image B), though also toxic, is primarily known for its anticholinergic effects. 
  • The plant contains alkaloids such as scopolamine and atropine, which can cause symptoms like delirium, hallucinations, dry mouth, and dilated pupils. 
  • While dangerous, it is generally considered less likely to cause immediate death compared to Oleander, whose effects on the cardiovascular system are far more severe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • White Oleander is far more toxic and associated with cardiac poisoning due to its oleandrin content. 
  • White Datura, though also dangerous, primarily causes anticholinergic toxicity, leading to symptoms such as delirium and hallucinations.

choices.text: They can be administered in very low doses.
They are irreversible and highly specific to their target enzyme.
They have minimal side effects due to their rapid clearance from the body.
They enhance the natural activity of enzymes.

questions.text: What is the primary reason why suicide inhibitors are considered an effective therapeutic strategy in drug design?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They are irreversible and highly specific to their target enzyme.

 

  • Suicide inhibitors are particularly effective because they bind irreversibly and specifically to their target enzyme. 
  • This specificity is due to their ability to mimic the natural substrate of the enzyme, ensuring that they selectively inactivate only the intended enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They can be administered in very low doses: Incorrect as dosage levels depend on the drug's pharmacokinetics and desired therapeutic effects.

 

Option C. They have minimal side effects due to their rapid clearance from the body: Incorrect because minimal side effects are not primarily due to rapid clearance but to targeted action.

 

Option D. They enhance the natural activity of enzymes: Incorrect as these inhibitors do not enhance but rather inhibit enzyme activity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Recognize the therapeutic benefits of suicide inhibitors, emphasizing their irreversible and specific nature, which makes them suitable for targeting specific enzymes in disease conditions.

choices.text: Prevention of psychological distress due to peer teasing

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a pre-surgical consultation. The parents are concerned about their child’s prominent ears. Which of the following is the primary indication for performing pinnaplasty at this age?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevention of psychological distress due to peer teasing

 

  • Pinnaplasty at age 6 is performed primarily to prevent psychological distress, as children become more socially aware and interactions with peers increase during school years.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of hearing loss: Prominent ears do not lead to hearing loss.

 

Option B. Prevention of cartilage necrosis: Cartilage necrosis is not a concern in this condition.

 

Option D. Higher surgical success rates: Success rates of pinnaplasty are not dependent on age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the psychosocial rationale for the timing of pinnaplasty in children with prominent ears.

choices.text: It can also treat underlying anxiety that may trigger smoking.
It can provide immediate relief from nicotine withdrawal symptoms.
It has a dual action that both reduces cravings and makes smoking less satisfying.
It can improve lung function directly by protecting against smoke-induced damage.

questions.text: A healthcare provider is considering initiating Varenicline for a patient who has failed multiple attempts at smoking cessation. What unique property of Varenicline should be emphasized to the patient as a major benefit of choosing this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has a dual action that both reduces cravings and makes smoking less satisfying.

 

  • Varenicline’s unique dual action as a partial agonist and an antagonist at α4β2 nicotine receptors is key to its effectiveness. 
  • This dual action not only helps manage withdrawal symptoms by partially stimulating the receptors but also reduces the satisfaction derived from smoking by blocking nicotine’s access to these receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can also treat underlying anxiety that may trigger smoking: Incorrect as Varenicline does not treat anxiety.

 

Option B. It can provide immediate relief from nicotine withdrawal symptoms: Incorrect because the relief from withdrawal symptoms is not immediate but builds up with consistent use.

 

Option D. It can improve lung function directly by protecting against smoke-induced damage: Incorrect as Varenicline does not have direct effects on lung function or protective effects against smoke-induced damage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Highlight Varenicline's dual mechanism of action in reducing nicotine cravings and making smoking less rewarding, key for patient education and compliance.

questions.text: Mr. Ramakrishnan, an 80-year-old man from Hyderabad, is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious in a field on a hot day. His family reports he had been working outdoors for several hours without taking adequate water breaks and became disoriented before collapsing. On arrival, he has altered mental status but no focal neurological deficits. Initial labs reveal normal electrolytes. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating

 

  • This scenario is typical of classic heat stroke, often seen in elderly individuals exposed to extreme heat without proper hydration. Key features include:
    • Core body temperature >41°C (105.8°F)
    • Altered mental status or end-organ dysfunction
    • Absence of sweating (anhidrosis) due to thermoregulatory failure
  • In classic heat stroke, sweating is usually absent, distinguishing it from heat exhaustion, where sweating persists, and core temperature is below 41°C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nausea: Common in heat stroke due to systemic thermoregulatory failure.

 

Option C. Hypotension: Occurs from dehydration and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Headache: A frequent symptom in heat-related illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Classic heat stroke is marked by anhidrosis (absence of sweating) and altered mental status. 
  • Recognizing the lack of sweating helps differentiate it from heat exhaustion. 
  • Rapid cooling and supportive care are critical to reduce morbidity and mortality.

choices.text: Laser ablation can be used for definitive treatment
Both great saphenous and accessary saphenous veins are dilated
Fasciotomy is done as a part of Trendelenberg procedure

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg on the medial aspect. Which of these is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laser ablation can be used for definitive treatment.

 

  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) can be used in management of varicose veins with SF junction incompetence.

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. The CEAP stage is C6: The CEAP stage is C2

 

Option C. Both great saphenous and accessary saphenous veins are dilated: Medially located varicosities arise from GSV. Short saphenous varicosities are present on posterior aspect of leg/calf.

 

Option D. Fasciotomy is done as a part of Trendelenberg procedure: Trendelenberg procedure involves flush ligation of GSV at SF junction. Fasciotomy is done in conditions like compartment syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:
 

EVLA is a definitive treatment of great saphenous venous incompetence.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male undergoes preoperative evaluation for cataract surgery. His axial length is found to be 28 mm. Which formula is most appropriate for calculating the intraocular lens (IOL) power in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Holladay formula

 

  • The Holladay formula is specifically tailored for eyes with an axial length greater than 26 mm, such as in this patient. 
  • It incorporates adjustments for long axial lengths, reducing refractive error post-surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK-II formula: Incorrect. The SRK-II formula is outdated and not ideal for extreme axial lengths.

 

Option B. Hoffer Q formula: Incorrect. The Hoffer Q formula is better suited for eyes with shorter axial lengths (<22 mm).

 

Option D. Haigis formula: Incorrect. The Haigis formula is advanced but typically requires optical biometry, not specified here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Holladay formula is preferred for calculating IOL power in patients with long axial lengths (>26 mm).

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the condition where excessive fetal head molding causes tears in the dura mater and underlying vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade 3+ molding

 

  • Grade 3+ molding involves excessive overlapping of the fetal skull bones, leading to tears in the dura mater and underlying vessels. This can result in severe complications during labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1 molding: Grade 1 molding is minor and involves skull bones touching without overlap.

 

Option B. Grade 2 molding: Grade 2 molding involves overlapping bones that can be separated manually and does not cause underlying tears.

 

Option D. Cephalhematoma: Cephalhematoma involves subperiosteal hemorrhage but does not involve tears in the dura mater.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Severe molding (Grade 3+) can lead to tears in the dura mater and underlying vessels, causing significant complications.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding mild preeclampsia are correct?

 

  1. Diastolic BP is less than 100 mmHg.
  2. Systolic BP is less than 160 mmHg.
  3. IUGR is a common feature.
  4. There are no premonitory symptoms.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statements 1 and 2: Mild preeclampsia is characterized by BP <160/100 mmHg 

 

Statement 4: Premonitory symptoms like severe headache or visual disturbances are absent 

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3: IUGR is more commonly associated with severe preeclampsia, not mild preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mild preeclampsia presents with controlled BP and no significant systemic involvement or fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of sudden chest pain and difficulty swallowing. A contrast study reveals leakage of contrast into the mediastinum. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most appropriate contrast medium for diagnosing esophageal perforation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iohexol

 

  • Iohexol is the preferred contrast medium for esophageal perforation as it is water-soluble and does not cause mediastinal inflammation, unlike barium contrast. 
  • Barium can worsen inflammation in the mediastinum if used in esophageal perforation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Gastrogrffin: Gastrogrffin, although water-soluble, is less preferred due to the risk of aspiration and pneumonitis.
 

Option B. Barium sulfate: Barium sulfate is contraindicated in esophageal perforation due to its potential to cause serious complications like mediastinal inflammation.
 

Option C. Iodine-based contrast: Iodine-based contrast is a broad term and not specific for the condition described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Iohexol is the standard contrast medium used in esophageal perforation due to its water-soluble nature and safety profile.

questions.text:
Match the Following (Alopecia Types and Features) 

 

Column A:

  1. Patchy alopecia
  2. Diffuse alopecia
  3. Patterned alopecia
  4. Systemic alopecia

 

Column B: 

  1. Androgenetic alopecia
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Autoimmune target of anagen hair
  4. Thyroid dysfunction-related hair loss
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

  • Patchy alopecia (1-c): Seen in alopecia areata, where the autoimmune attack targets anagen hair bulbs, leading to patches of complete hair loss.
  • Diffuse alopecia (2-b): Includes telogen effluvium, often caused by stress, pregnancy, or systemic illness.
  • Patterned alopecia (3-a): Typical of androgenetic alopecia, characterized by Hamilton (male) or Ludwig (female) classifications.
  • Systemic alopecia (4-d): Associated with systemic conditions like thyroid dysfunction or lupus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Alopecia types have distinct patterns and etiologies, such as autoimmune (alopecia areata), stress-induced (telogen effluvium), and systemic causes (thyroid dysfunction).

choices.text: Liquid culture in brain-heart infusion broth

questions.text: A clinical microbiologist needs to perform antimicrobial susceptibility testing on a Staphylococcus aureus isolate from a wound infection. Which of the following culture methods would be most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lawn culture using sterile swab

 

  • Lawn culture, also known as carpet culture, is the optimal method for antimicrobial susceptibility testing using the disk diffusion method. 
  • This technique creates a uniform bacterial lawn by spreading the inoculum evenly across the entire agar surface, allowing for consistent growth and clear, measurable zones of inhibition around antibiotic disks. 
  • The uniform distribution of bacteria is crucial for standardized susceptibility testing and accurate interpretation of results.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Stab culture in nutrient agar: This method is used for maintaining stock cultures and performing specific biochemical tests. It cannot provide the uniform surface growth needed for susceptibility testing.

 

Option C. Stroke culture in zigzag pattern: This technique is primarily used for biochemical tests like citrate utilization or TSI. It doesn't provide the uniform bacterial distribution required for susceptibility testing.
