Option D. Liquid culture in brain-heart infusion broth: While useful for blood cultures and sterility testing, liquid cultures cannot be used for disk diffusion susceptibility testing, which requires growth on a solid medium surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lawn culture technique is essential for antimicrobial susceptibility testing as it provides uniform bacterial growth necessary for standardized interpretation of inhibition zones.

questions.text:
A neonate presents with respiratory distress, ground-glass opacities on chest X-ray, and a family history of a sibling who died from a similar condition. Which of the following statements are true regarding the most likely diagnosis?

 

  1. This condition is characterized by intraalveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant.
  2. Surfactant replacement is the definitive treatment for this condition.
  3. Histopathological examination with PAS-positive material is diagnostic.
  4. This condition is associated with a Protein-B component deficiency in surfactant.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4 are correct.

 

Statement 1. This condition is characterized by intraalveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant: Correct. This condition is pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, which is characterized by intraalveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant due to a deficiency in surfactant metabolism.

 

Statement 3. Histopathological examination with PAS-positive material is diagnostic: Correct. Histopathological examination reveals granular, eosinophilic material that is PAS-positive and diastase-resistant, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Statement 4. This condition is associated with a Protein-B component deficiency in surfactant: Correct. The condition is associated with a deficiency of the Protein-B component of surfactant, leading to impaired absorption and distribution of surfactant.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 2. Surfactant replacement is the definitive treatment for this condition: Incorrect: Surfactant replacement therapy is ineffective in pulmonary alveolar proteinosis because the condition involves functional deficiency due to improper metabolism, not absolute deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis presents with respiratory distress, ground-glass opacities, and a positive family history, diagnosed through histopathological evidence of PAS-positive material and associated with surfactant Protein-B deficiency.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with fatigue and hepatomegaly. On biopsy, specialized macrophages in the liver are found, which are involved in the breakdown of aged red blood cells and play an essential role in the immune response. Which of the following cell types is most likely involved in this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kupffer cells

 

  • Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver. They are responsible for the breakdown of aged red blood cells and play a key role in immune responses by phagocytizing pathogens and cellular debris. 
  • This function is specific to Kupffer cells, not the other cell types.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Parietal cells: Parietal cells are found in the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid, not involved in red blood cell breakdown.
 

Option C. Dust cells: Dust cells (alveolar macrophages) are found in the lungs and are involved in clearing inhaled particles, not in the liver.
 

Option D. Clara cells: Clara cells (club cells) are located in the bronchioles and secrete surfactant proteins but are not involved in red blood cell breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Kupffer cells in the liver are specialized macrophages involved in the breakdown of red blood cells and play a vital role in immune responses.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of eye pain, redness, and swelling. She also reports blurred vision and occasional double vision, especially in the evenings. She has a history of hyperthyroidism, which is being treated with methimazole. On examination , Her eyes condition is shown in the image below. She is diagnosed with thyroid eye disease (TED). Which of the following is not considered an appropriate treatment option for TED?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rituximab

 

Although effective in some autoimmune diseases, studies have shown no significant benefit for TED, making it an inappropriate choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Selenium: Effective in reducing inflammation and slowing disease progression in mild TED.

 

Option C. Glucocorticoids: The mainstay treatment for severe TED to reduce inflammation and optic nerve compression.

 

Option D. Teprotumumab: A targeted therapy with proven efficacy in reducing proptosis and inflammation in TED.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management of thyroid eye disease depends on severity.
    • Mild-to-moderate TED: Managed conservatively with selenium (100 mg BID), which reduces oxidative stress and inflammation.
    • Severe TED: Treated with high-dose glucocorticoids, orbital decompression, orbital radiotherapy, or teprotumumab (an IGF-1 receptor monoclonal antibody approved by the FDA in 2020).
  • Rituximab is not recommended for TED, while selenium, glucocorticoids, and teprotumumab are effective treatment options based on disease severity.

choices.text: Continue OHA and reduce long-acting insulin dose by half.
Discontinue OHA and administer short-acting insulin as needed.
Continue OHA and administer long-acting insulin at full dose.
Discontinue OHA, reduce long-acting insulin to one-third, and monitor glucose closely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male on oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) and long-acting insulin is scheduled for an elective hernia repair. His preoperative glucose level is 140 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate perioperative glucose management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discontinue OHA, reduce long-acting insulin to one-third, and monitor glucose closely.

 

  • Long-acting insulin is reduced to one-third to prevent intraoperative hypoglycemia, and OHA is stopped to avoid unpredictable glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue OHA and reduce long-acting insulin dose by half: Reducing insulin by half may still lead to hypoglycemia during fasting.

 

Option B. Discontinue OHA and administer short-acting insulin as needed: Short-acting insulin may be needed postoperatively but is not routinely administered preoperatively.

 

Option C. Continue OHA and administer long-acting insulin at full dose: Continuing full-dose insulin risks severe hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In diabetic patients undergoing surgery, careful preoperative insulin adjustment and glucose monitoring are crucial to prevent hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A forensic expert is performing an autopsy on a body that has been electrocuted, and they observe the presence of molten metal within the soft tissues. This molten metal is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Current pearls

 

  • Current pearls refer to molten metal derived from the electrode during electrocution. 
  • These pearls can be found deep in the soft tissues and are characteristic of electrical injuries. 
  • The current pearls are formed due to the extreme heat generated at the point of contact between the electrode and the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone pearls: Bone pearls are formed from molten calcium phosphate derived from bone and can be detected in radiological investigations, but they are not molten metal from the electrode.
 

Option C. Calcium phosphate droplets: Calcium phosphate droplets are found in bones and represent bone pearls, not molten metal from the electrode.
 

Option D. Electrocution wax: Electrocution wax is not a recognized term in postmortem examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Current pearls are molten metal derived from the electrode during electrocution, which can be found deep in soft tissues.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is hospitalized for gram-negative sepsis secondary to a urinary tract infection and started on intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam. On day 7 of treatment, she develops acute kidney injury (AKI) with rising serum creatinine levels. She reports fatigue and decreased urine output, but no fever or rash. Urine examination reveals eosinophiluria, and blood tests confirm worsening renal function. There is no prior history of kidney disease or known drug allergies. Which of the following is the gold standard diagnostic test for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kidney biopsy

 

  • The clinical picture is consistent with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), most likely drug-induced due to piperacillin-tazobactam. 
  • Kidney biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing AIN. It provides definitive histological evidence, such as interstitial inflammation, edema, and eosinophilic infiltration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound of the kidneys: May show large, swollen kidneys with increased echogenicity, but these findings are nonspecific.

 

Option B. CT of the kidneys: Useful for ruling out other structural causes of AKI, but it does not confirm AIN.

 

Option C. Renal Gallium scan: Once considered for AIN diagnosis, it is neither sensitive nor specific and is no longer commonly used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kidney biopsy is the definitive diagnostic tool for acute interstitial nephritis, especially when clinical and laboratory findings strongly suggest the diagnosis.

choices.text: Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock
Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with severe brain injury exhibits decerebrate posturing. According to the Herrington classification of decerebrate rigidity, which of the following is not a characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

  • According to the Herrington classification of decerebrate rigidity, decerebrate rigidity is primarily characterized by a specific posture resulting from severe brain injury, typically involving the brainstem. 
  • It involves extensor rigidity of the limbs due to the loss of inhibitory control from the higher brain centers. 
  • However, rigidity does not occur in all the muscles of the body; it mainly affects the extensor muscles of the limbs. 
  • The characteristic posture includes extension and internal rotation of the arms, extension of the legs, and plantar flexion of the feet.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: This is true. Unlike spinal cord injury that can cause spinal shock, decerebrate rigidity does not produce an analogous phenomenon. Decerebrate rigidity involves hyperactivity in motor pathways due to the loss of descending inhibitory control.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: This is correct. The increased excitability of the motor neuron pool is a characteristic feature of decerebrate rigidity, where motor neurons become hyperactive due to the loss of upper motor neuron inhibition.

 

Option D. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: This is correct. There is an increased rate of discharge in γ efferent neurons, which contributes to the heightened muscle tone observed in decerebrate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decerebrate rigidity, according to the Herrington classification, is characterized by increased muscle tone primarily in the extensor muscles of the limbs, not all muscles of the body. 
  • This condition results from the loss of descending inhibitory signals from the brain to the spinal cord, leading to hyperactivity in motor pathways and increased discharge of γ efferent neurons.

choices.text: Increased heart rate by 10–15 beats per minute
Increased cardiac output and blood volume

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents for a routine antenatal visit. On examination, her heart rate is noted to be elevated by 15 beats per minute compared to her pre-pregnancy baseline. A systolic ejection murmur is also heard on auscultation, which is soft and grade 2/6. She denies any chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Which of the following cardiovascular findings is considered abnormal during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Loud diastolic murmur

 

  • A loud diastolic murmur is always abnormal in pregnancy and may indicate underlying valvular disease, such as mitral stenosis or aortic regurgitation. It warrants further investigation with echocardiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased heart rate by 10–15 beats per minute: This is a normal physiological change during pregnancy to meet the increased metabolic and circulatory demands of the mother and fetus.

 

Option B. Increased cardiac output and blood volume: Cardiac output increases by 30–50%, and blood volume increases by 40–50% during pregnancy to ensure adequate perfusion of the placenta and maternal organs.

 

Option C. Systolic ejection murmur: A soft systolic ejection murmur is a common and benign finding during pregnancy, caused by increased blood flow through the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Physiological changes in the cardiovascular system during pregnancy include increased heart rate, cardiac output, and blood volume, as well as benign systolic murmurs. 
  • However, a loud diastolic murmur is always abnormal and requires further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with a history of recurrent otitis media presents with chronic ear discharge, hearing loss, and a retracted tympanic membrane with visible keratin debris. Which of the following statements are true?

 

  1. This condition is commonly associated with chronic Eustachian tube dysfunction.
  2. Surgical management is the definitive treatment for this condition.
  3. Antibiotics alone are sufficient for treatment.
  4. Retraction pockets of the TM are the most common precursor to this condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. This condition is commonly associated with chronic Eustachian tube dysfunction: Correct. Chronic Eustachian tube dysfunction leads to negative pressure, causing retraction pockets that develop into cholesteatomas.

 

Statement 2. Surgical management is the definitive treatment for this condition: Correct. Surgical excision is required to remove the cholesteatoma and prevent further complications.

 

Statement 4. Retraction pockets of the TM are the most common precursor to this condition: Correct. Retraction pockets are the most common precursor due to chronic negative pressure.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3. Antibiotics alone are sufficient for treatment: Incorrect. Antibiotics are not sufficient as cholesteatomas require surgical removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that cholesteatomas arise from chronic Eustachian tube dysfunction and retraction pockets, requiring surgical management for definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of severe chest pain that started suddenly while he was watching television. The pain is described as a heavy, squeezing sensation radiating to his right shoulder and neck. He also feels lightheaded and has had one episode of nausea. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, heart rate is 110/min, and jugular venous pressure is elevated. His lungs are clear on auscultation, and no rales are heard. ECG is taken and shown below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous 0.9% saline

 

  • The patient’s presentation suggests an inferior myocardial infarction with possible right ventricular involvement, as indicated by hypotension (BP 90/60 mmHg), elevated JVP, and clear lungs. 
  • Right ventricular infarction leads to reduced preload, and the most appropriate initial treatment is volume resuscitation with intravenous 0.9% saline to restore preload and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement: Not appropriate for isolated right ventricular infarction as it does not address the primary issue of hypovolemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Can exacerbate hypotension if used without addressing hypovolemia first.

 

Option D. Oral metoprolol: Contraindicated in hypotension or shock as it reduces heart rate and cardiac output further.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In cases of inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement, initial treatment should focus on fluid resuscitation to optimize preload and cardiac output. 
  • Avoid beta-blockers and vasodilators in such patients.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding tanycytes and circumventricular organs is/are true?

 

  1. Tanycytes are specialized ependymal cells located in circumventricular organs.
  2. Circumventricular organs lack a blood-brain barrier, allowing direct communication between blood and CSF.
  3. Tanycytes play a role in chemoreception, secretion into the CSF, and transporting neurochemicals.
  4. Circumventricular organs are responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 are true

 

1. Tanycytes are specialized ependymal cells located in circumventricular organs: These cells have unique functions such as chemoreception, secretion into CSF, and transport of neurochemicals between adjacent neurons, glial cells, vessels, and CSF.

 

2. Circumventricular organs lack a blood-brain barrier: This allows them to act as sites for neuroendocrine communication by permitting free exchange of molecules between the bloodstream and cerebrospinal fluid.

 

3. Tanycytes play a role in chemoreception and neurochemical transport: These cells aid in both sensing changes in the environment and transporting neurochemicals to or from the CSF.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Circumventricular organs are responsible for the production of CSF: This is incorrect as the production of CSF is primarily a function of the choroid plexus, not circumventricular organs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A public health officer is conducting a training session on vaccination practices. Which of the following statements about vaccine administration and safety are true?

 

  1. Vaccines like DPT should never be stored in a deep freezer.
  2. Encephalopathy within 7 days of DPT vaccination is an absolute contraindication to further doses.
  3. Vaccines like OPV and BCG can be frozen without harm.
  4. Mission Indradhanush includes the Japanese encephalitis vaccine in all districts.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 are correct.

 

Statement 1. Vaccines like DPT should never be stored in a deep freezer: Correct. Vaccines like DPT are aluminum adjuvant-based and are susceptible to freezing damage, so they should never be stored in a deep freezer.

 

Statement 2. Encephalopathy within 7 days of DPT vaccination is an absolute contraindication to further doses: Correct. Encephalopathy within 7 days of DPT vaccination is a documented absolute contraindication for subsequent doses.

 

Statement 3. Vaccines like OPV and BCG can be frozen without harm: Correct. Vaccines like OPV and BCG are live attenuated and can tolerate freezing without significant harm.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4. Mission Indradhanush includes the Japanese encephalitis vaccine in all districts: Incorrect. Japanese encephalitis is not universally included in Mission Indradhanush and is administered only in selected high-risk districts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Japanese encephalitis is not universally included in Mission Indradhanush and is administered only in selected high-risk districts.

choices.text: MRI of the brain and orbits

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive vision loss in his left eye. B-scan ultrasonography image is shown below. What is the next best diagnostic step in confirming the nature of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA)

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is the next best diagnostic step in patients with suspected choroidal melanoma. 
  • FFA helps evaluate the vascularity of the lesion, which is critical for distinguishing malignant melanomas from benign lesions. 
  • Choroidal melanomas typically exhibit early hyperfluorescence with late leakage on FFA, reflecting the tumor's vascular characteristics. 
  • This information is essential for accurate diagnosis and planning treatment.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Optical coherence tomography (OCT): Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is useful for assessing retinal thickness and macular conditions but does not provide the necessary information to evaluate a choroidal melanoma's vascularity.
 

Option C. Complete blood count (CBC): A complete blood count (CBC) is not useful for diagnosing choroidal melanoma and would not provide relevant information for this patient.
 

Option D. MRI of the brain and orbits: MRI of the brain and orbits can be helpful in assessing the extent of intraocular and orbital involvement but is not the primary tool for diagnosing choroidal melanoma. FFA is more specific for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is essential for assessing the vascular characteristics of suspected choroidal melanoma and is crucial for confirming the diagnosis.

choices.text: Mobile surgical units that bring operating rooms to remote villages for on-site surgeries
NGO-organized eye screening campaigns followed by surgeries at a designated hospital
Establishing partnerships with private hospitals to perform discounted surgeries for rural patients
Government-sponsored cataract surgery programs offering free surgeries through public hospitals

questions.text: A healthcare policy team is evaluating options to expand access to cataract surgery in a low-resource country. After reviewing several options, they want to ensure the strategy minimizes costs while maximizing surgical reach. Which strategy would likely provide the best outcome in terms of accessibility and affordability?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NGO-organized eye screening campaigns followed by surgeries at a designated hospital

 

  • NGO-organized eye screening campaigns paired with surgeries at a designated hospital are cost-effective because they allow for high patient throughput and efficient resource use. 
  • By screening large populations and performing surgeries in centralized settings, economies of scale reduce the per-patient cost. 
  • This approach provides widespread access without the logistical challenges or high costs of traveling to mobile surgical units or relying on private hospitals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mobile surgical units that bring operating rooms to remote villages for on-site surgeries: While mobile surgical units may reach remote areas, they are costly due to travel expenses and the need to transport surgical equipment and staff, making them less efficient for high-volume procedures.

 

Option C. Establishing partnerships with private hospitals to perform discounted surgeries for rural patients: Partnering with private hospitals may not always lead to affordability, especially for rural populations who may still face financial barriers to care despite discounts.

 

Option D. Government-sponsored cataract surgery programs offering free surgeries through public hospitals: Government-sponsored programs are beneficial, but they often face budgetary limitations and might not scale efficiently, especially without adequate community-based outreach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most cost-effective strategy for expanding access to cataract surgeries involves NGO-led screening campaigns and centralized hospital surgeries, ensuring broad reach and minimizing operational costs.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of progressive abdominal distension over the past month. He reports associated mild discomfort but denies fever, significant weight loss, or changes in bowel habits. His medical history includes chronic liver disease due to long-term alcohol use. A diagnostic paracentesis is performed, revealing the following ascitic fluid analysis:

 

  • Ascitic fluid protein: 1.9 g/dL
  • Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG): 1.4 g/dL

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of his ascites?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alcoholic cirrhosis

 

  1. Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):
    • A SAAG >1.1 g/dL suggests sinusoidal hypertension, commonly seen in conditions like cirrhosis and cardiac-related ascites.
    • A SAAG <1.1 g/dL suggests peritoneal causes of ascites (e.g., malignancy, infections).
  2. Ascitic fluid protein levels:
    • Cirrhosis: Low ascitic fluid protein (<2.5 g/dL) due to capillarized sinusoids that leak less protein.
    • Cardiac ascites: High protein (>2.5 g/dL) due to normal sinusoidal function.

 

This patient’s findings of low ascitic fluid protein (<2.5 g/dL) and elevated SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) are characteristic of cirrhotic ascites, most commonly due to alcoholic cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peritoneal malignancy: Typically presents with low SAAG (<1.1 g/dL) and high ascitic protein levels (>2.5 g/dL).

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Causes ascites with high SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) and high protein levels (>2.5 g/dL).

 

Option D. Veno-occlusive disease: Associated with high SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) and ascitic protein levels >2.5 g/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A SAAG >1.1 g/dL with low protein levels (<2.5 g/dL) is characteristic of cirrhotic ascites, most commonly due to alcoholic cirrhosis. 
  • Diagnostic paracentesis is essential in evaluating the cause of ascites and guiding management.

choices.text: Germ cells from the embryonal period

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a testicular mass undergoes immunohistochemistry, and the tumor expresses KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (OCT3/4), and PLAP. What is the most likely source of the tumor’s origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Germ cells from the embryonal period

 

  • The expression of KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (OCT3/4), and PLAP suggests a seminoma, which originates from pluripotent germ cells that maintain an embryonal origin. 
  • OCT 3/4 is a transcription factor essential for maintaining pluripotency in germ cells, and the presence of PLAP further indicates the germ cell lineage of the tumor. 
  • These findings are characteristic of seminomas, a type of germ cell tumor.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Embryonic stem cells: While OCT 3/4 is also associated with embryonic stem cells, in this context, the markers are more specific to seminomas, which are derived from germ cells, not stem cells.
 

Option B. Somatic cells of the testis: Somatic cells, such as Sertoli or Leydig cells, do not express these markers, which are specific to germ cell tumors.
 

Option D. Mature teratomatous tissues: Teratomas are more differentiated and involve a mix of tissues from all three germ layers, but they do not express KIT, OCT 3/4, and PLAP in the same manner as seminomas.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Seminomas arise from pluripotent germ cells from the embryonal period and are characterized by the expression of KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (OCT3/4), and PLAP.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who received a renal transplant two months ago presents for routine follow-up. His renal function appears stable, but there is concern regarding possible urinary leak or obstruction due to post-surgical complications. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to assess renal function and detect any urinary leaks or obstructions in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tc-99m MAG3 scan

 

  • The Tc-99m MAG3 scan is a dynamic renography technique used for assessing renal function and urinary drainage in renal transplant patients. 
  • It helps detect issues such as urinary leaks or obstructions by evaluating glomerular filtration and tubular excretion. 
  • This test is highly sensitive in detecting post-surgical complications that can affect renal function and urinary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ultrasound of the renal transplant: While useful for detecting structural abnormalities, ultrasound cannot assess renal function or detect subtle obstructions or leaks as effectively as a dynamic scan.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine measurement: Serum creatinine levels provide information about renal function but are not specific for detecting urinary leaks or obstructions.

 

Option D. CT scan of the abdomen: A CT scan can detect anatomical issues, but it does not provide the functional assessment required to evaluate kidney performance or urinary drainage issues in the post-transplant setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Tc-99m MAG3 scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for evaluating renal function, urinary drainage, and potential leaks or obstructions in post-renal transplant patients. 
  • It assesses both glomerular filtration and tubular excretion to provide a comprehensive understanding of renal status.

choices.text: Transition to an integrase inhibitor-based regimen.
Supplement with metformin for insulin resistance.
Introduce pioglitazone to reduce central obesity.
Enhance dietary and exercise regimes exclusively.

questions.text: In monitoring a 50-year-old female with HIV treated with Indinavir who develops central obesity and insulin resistance, which therapeutic adjustment is considered optimal to address her metabolic complications without compromising viral control?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transition to an integrase inhibitor-based regimen.

 

  • Shifting to an integrase inhibitor-based regimen might be optimal for managing metabolic side effects like central obesity and insulin resistance associated with Indinavir, as these newer agents have a more favorable metabolic profile. 
  • This adjustment maintains effective HIV control while potentially reducing the risk of diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Supplement with metformin for insulin resistance: Incorrect as while metformin treats insulin resistance, it does not address all the metabolic issues induced by Indinavir.

 

Option C. Introduce pioglitazone to reduce central obesity: Incorrect because pioglitazone could help with obesity but may exacerbate other metabolic issues like lipid abnormalities.

 

Option D. Enhance dietary and exercise regimes exclusively: Incorrect as lifestyle changes alone are often insufficient to counteract medication-induced metabolic disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Optimize HIV treatment regimens in patients experiencing significant metabolic side effects from protease inhibitors by considering transitions to therapies with fewer metabolic burdens.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about dermatopathology are true? 

 

  1. Spongiosis is commonly seen in eczematous dermatitis.
  2. Acanthosis is a hallmark of only psoriasis.
  3. Parakeratosis indicates nucleated cells in the stratum corneum.
  4. Acantholysis is caused by defective hemidesmosomes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. Spongiosis is commonly seen in eczematous dermatitis: True. Spongiosis, or intraepidermal intercellular edema, is a key feature of eczematous dermatitis.

 

Statement 3. Parakeratosis indicates nucleated cells in the stratum corneum: True. Parakeratosis is the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in the stratum corneum, often seen in psoriasis.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 2. Acanthosis is a hallmark of only psoriasis: False. Acanthosis is a thickening of the stratum spinosum, which can occur in conditions like lichen planus also along with psoriasis.

 

Statement 4. Acantholysis is caused by defective hemidesmosomes: False. Acantholysis is due to defective desmosomes, not hemidesmosomes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Spongiosis and parakeratosis are key histological findings in eczematous dermatitis and psoriasis, respectively, while acantholysis results from defective desmosomes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman in her third trimester presents with severe hypertension, proteinuria, and right upper quadrant pain. Her labs show elevated liver enzymes and a platelet count of 90,000/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia characterized by:

 

  • Hemolysis (Hemolysis, as seen with schistocytes on a peripheral smear, elevated lactate dehydrogenase [LDH])
  • Elevated Liver enzymes (AST, ALT)
  • Low Platelets (thrombocytopenia, <100,000/mm3)

 

This patient’s clinical presentation (hypertension, proteinuria, right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, and thrombocytopenia) is highly suggestive of HELLP syndrome.

 

Right upper quadrant pain results from hepatic swelling and microvascular injury leading to Glisson’s capsule distension in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute fatty liver of pregnancy: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy also involves liver dysfunction but is rarer and associated with hypoglycemia.

 

Option B. Gestational hypertension: Gestational hypertension lacks proteinuria and systemic involvement.

 

Option D. Chronic hypertension: Chronic hypertension is present before 20 weeks of pregnancy and lacks associated symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome presents with elevated liver enzymes, low platelets, and right upper quadrant pain in the context of severe preeclampsia.

questions.text:
Match the following: 

 

Column A (Pathological Concepts)

  1. Tympanic membrane perforation
  2. Barotrauma
  3. Cholesteatoma
  4. Eustachian tube dysfunction

 

Column B (Clinical Features)

  1. Chronic foul-smelling ear discharge with white mass behind TM
  2. Severe ear pain and hearing loss during descent in air travel
  3. Negative middle ear pressure causing TM retraction pockets
  4. Rupture of TM due to sudden negative pressure
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C

 

  • Tympanic membrane perforation (1-D): Rupture due to sudden negative middle ear pressure caused by altitude changes during air travel.
  • Barotrauma (2-B): Presents as severe ear pain and hearing loss during descent when the Eustachian tube fails to equalize pressure.
  • Cholesteatoma (3-A): Chronic discharge with a white mass behind the TM in a retraction pocket.
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction (4-C): Chronic negative middle ear pressure causing TM retraction pockets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that tympanic membrane perforation is linked to sudden negative pressure, barotrauma occurs during descent, and cholesteatoma manifests with chronic symptoms and retraction pockets.

questions.text: Considering the wobble hypothesis, which tRNA modification is most critical for maintaining the flexibility of codon recognition during translation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inosine (I)

 

  • Inosine is a modified nucleotide found in the anticodon loop of tRNA and plays a key role in the wobble hypothesis. 
  • The hypothesis explains how a single tRNA can recognize multiple codons for the same amino acid. 
  • Inosine, particularly at the wobble position (the 3rd base of the codon), can pair with A, U, or C in mRNA, providing flexibility in codon recognition and allowing the genetic code to be translated with fewer tRNAs. 
  • This flexibility is crucial for efficient protein synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylguanosine (mG): Methylguanosine is a modified nucleotide found in tRNA, but its primary role is structural, stabilizing the tRNA molecule. It is not directly involved in wobble pairing. Methylation protects tRNA from degradation and enhances the accuracy of codon-anticodon pairing, but it does not provide the flexibility seen with wobble base pairing.

 

Option C. Pseudouridine (ψ): Pseudouridine is another modified nucleotide found in tRNA, but its function is more related to the stability and proper folding of the tRNA molecule. It helps in maintaining the correct 3D structure of tRNA, which is essential for accurate translation, but it does not directly contribute to codon flexibility in the wobble position.

 

Option D. Dihydrouridine (D): Dihydrouridine is a modified base found in the D-loop of tRNA. Its primary function is to influence the flexibility of the tRNA structure, particularly during the folding and interaction with ribosomes. However, it is not involved in the wobble hypothesis or codon recognition flexibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inosine in the anticodon allows tRNA to pair with multiple mRNA bases, increasing the flexibility of codon recognition during translation.

choices.text: Junction of superior vena cava and left brachiocephalic vein
Junction of left internal jugular and left subclavian vein

questions.text: Thoracic duct opens into the systemic circulation at which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Junction of left internal jugular and left subclavian vein

 

  • The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic duct, approximately 45 cm long, and drains lymph from the body below the diaphragm and the left upper quadrant above the diaphragm.
  • It begins at the cisterna chyli near the lower border of the T12 vertebra, enters the thorax through the aortic opening of the diaphragm, and ascends through the posterior mediastinum.
  • At the level of the C7 vertebra, it arches to the left and opens into the systemic circulation at the junction of the left internal jugular vein and the left subclavian vein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of Superior vena cava and left brachiocephalic vein: The thoracic duct does not drain into the superior vena cava or its tributaries other than the left subclavian vein.

 

Option C. Directly into coronary sinus: The coronary sinus is part of the venous drainage of the heart, and the thoracic duct has no anatomical connection with it.

 

Option D. Into azygos vein: Although the thoracic duct passes close to the azygos vein in the posterior mediastinum, it does not drain into it.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Delivery of the baby and placenta

questions.text: What is the definitive treatment of preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Delivery of the baby and placenta

 

  • Delivery is the only definitive cure for preeclampsia, as it resolves the underlying placental pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Magnesium sulfate: Magnesium sulfate is used for seizure prophylaxis but does not treat the underlying condition.

 

Option B and C. Antihypertensive therapy and Bed rest: These are supportive measures but not definitive treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The only definitive treatment for preeclampsia is delivery of the baby and placenta

choices.text: T-cell activation and massive cytokine release
Down-regulation of MHC II expression on APCs

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of frequent sore throats, fever, and joint pain. Further testing shows high levels of C-reactive protein (CRP). His tonsillar culture grows beta-hemolytic streptococci, and a rapid test for SPE-A comes positive. Which of the following is most likely to occur due to this superantigen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T-cell activation and massive cytokine release

 

  • SPE-A (Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin) is a bacterial superantigen that causes massive T-cell activation, bypassing the usual antigen processing. 
  • This leads to a cytokine storm, which contributes to symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and systemic inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down-regulation of MHC II expression on APCs: This is not a typical effect of SPE-A. It generally promotes T-cell activation rather than suppressing MHC II expression.


Option C. Suppression of antigen presentation: Superantigens do not suppress antigen presentation; instead, they bypass normal antigen processing.


Option D. Inhibition of T-cell receptor diversity: Superantigens do not inhibit T-cell diversity but instead stimulate T-cells non-specifically.

 

Educational Objective:


Examples of Superantigens

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. Examination reveals a tender irreducible swelling as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Richter’s hernia

 

  • This condition involves the herniation of only a portion of the circumference of the bowel wall (typically the antimesenteric border), unlike other hernias where the entire bowel wall is involved. 
  • This can lead to ischemia and necrosis of the bowel wall without causing complete bowel obstruction. 

  • The image provided illustrates this partial herniation, characteristic of Richter’s hernia.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl hernia: Involves herniation of two bowel loops through a single defect, with the central portion of the bowel potentially at risk of strangulation (W-loop hernia). This is not consistent with the image.

 

Option B. Littre hernia: Refers to the herniation of a Meckel’s diverticulum, typically seen in inguinal or femoral regions. There is no evidence of Meckel’s diverticulum in this case.

 

Option D. Amyand hernia: Involves the herniation of the appendix into the inguinal canal. This is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Richter’s hernia involves the herniation of part of the bowel wall (antimesenteric border), leading to ischemia and necrosis without complete bowel obstruction. 
  • It presents with localized swelling and tenderness, often without overt signs of intestinal obstruction. 
  • Early surgical intervention is essential to prevent complications like bowel perforation.

questions.text: A geneticist is analyzing a family where a rare trait is not visible in the parents but appears in the child. The child closely resembles a grandparent who had this trait. What is the most likely explanation for this inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atavism

 

  • Atavism refers to the reappearance of traits that have been absent for multiple generations, usually caused by genetic recombination. 
  • In this case, the trait is reappearing in the child after several generations due to the genes having been recombined in a way that brought the trait back, resembling the grandparent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heteroplasmy: Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of more than one type of mitochondrial DNA within a cell, not the reappearance of a trait after generations.
 

Option C. Genetic anticipation: Genetic anticipation refers to a genetic condition becoming more severe or appearing earlier in subsequent generations, which is unrelated to the reappearance of traits.
 

Option D. Genetic mosaics: Genetic mosaics describe individuals with two or more genetically different sets of cells, not the reappearance of an ancestral trait after generations.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Atavism describes the reappearance of ancestral traits after several generations due to genetic recombination, leading to a resemblance to a grandparent.

questions.text:
Match the following concepts with their correct descriptions.

 

Column A:

  1. Capacitation of sperm
  2. Aspermia
  3. Superfetation
  4. Progesterone during luteal phase

 

Column B:

  1. No ejaculate due to ejaculation failure
  2. Physiological changes enabling sperm to fertilize an oocyte
  3. Dominant hormone during the second half of the menstrual cycle
  4. Fertilization of two ova released in two different menstrual cycles
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

  • Capacitation of sperm (1-B): Physiochemical changes in sperm make them capable of fertilizing an oocyte.
  • Aspermia (2-A): Refers to the absence of ejaculate caused by ejaculation failure.
  • Superfetation (3-D): Occurs when two ova are fertilized during different menstrual cycles.
  • Progesterone during luteal phase (4-C): This hormone dominates the second half of the menstrual cycle, maintaining the uterine lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capacitation of sperm : Physiochemical changes in sperm make them capable of fertilizing an oocyte.
  • Aspermia : Refers to the absence of ejaculate caused by ejaculation failure.
  • Superfetation : Occurs when two ova are fertilized during different menstrual cycles.
  • Progesterone during luteal phase : This hormone dominates the second half of the menstrual cycle, maintaining the uterine lining.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study to assess the accuracy of the sample mean as an estimate of the population mean. The researcher is concerned about how much variability exists between the sample mean and the true population mean. Which statistical measure should be calculated to determine how precisely the sample mean approximates the population mean?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Standard error

 

  • The standard error quantifies the precision of the sample mean as an estimate of the population mean. 
  • It reflects how much the sample mean is expected to vary from the population mean due to random sampling. 
  • A smaller standard error indicates that the sample mean is a more reliable estimate of the population mean.
  • The standard error is calculated as the standard deviation of the sample divided by the square root of the sample size (n).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Geometric mean: It is typically used for data that involves multiplicative relationships (e.g., rates of growth), but it does not provide any information about the accuracy of the sample mean.


Option B. Range: It is the difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset and does not address the accuracy of the sample mean as an estimate of the population mean.


Option C. Deviation: Measures the difference between individual data points and the mean but does not give a direct measure of the sample mean’s precision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard error is the statistical measure that evaluates how accurately the sample mean approximates the population mean and is inversely related to sample size.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling in his right thumb after punching a wall. He reports that he hit the wall with a closed fist, and immediately afterward, he noticed pain at the base of his thumb along with difficulty moving it. On examination, there is significant swelling, bruising, and tenderness over the first metacarpal joint. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bennett’s Fracture 

 

Option C)

 

  • The provided clinical history and X-ray are classic for a Bennett's fracture.
  • This is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • It is often caused by an axial load on a partially flexed thumb, such as when punching a wall with a closed fist.
  • The fracture typically involves a small piece of the metacarpal base remaining attached to the trapezial bone, while the rest of the metacarpal is dislocated laterally and proximally due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon.
  • The X-ray image shows this characteristic fracture and dislocation at the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint of the thumb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rolando Fracture: This is also a fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, but it is a comminuted fracture, meaning the bone is broken into three or more pieces, forming a T or Y shape. The provided X-ray does not show this comminution.

 

 

Option B. Boxer's Fracture: A Boxer’s fracture typically refers to a fracture of the distal fifth metacarpal and is most often caused by punching something with a closed fist. This fracture generally involves a single, transverse fracture at the neck of the fifth metacarpal, which is not the case here since the injury is at the base of the first metacarpal.

 

 

Option D. Colles' Fracture: A Colles' fracture is a fracture of the distal radius near the wrist, often caused by falling onto an outstretched hand. This fracture does not involve the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rolando fracture: Comminuted, Y- or T-shaped fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, usually due to forceful trauma like punching.
  • Boxer's fracture: Fracture of the distal fifth metacarpal, often caused by punching.
  • Bennett’s fracture: Fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, often with dislocation but not comminuted.
  • Colles’ fracture: Fracture of the distal radius at the wrist, usually due to falling on an outstretched hand.

choices.text: Percentage of deliveries with skilled assistance
Percentage of JSY claims made to ASHA
Percentage of fever cases that received chloroquine within 1 week in endemic areas

questions.text: During a public health audit, an evaluator is asked to determine the impact of the ASHA program on health outcomes. Which of the following would be the best impact indicator for assessing the program’s long-term effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infant mortality rate (IMR)

 

  • Impact indicators assess the long-term effects of health interventions. 
  • The infant mortality rate (IMR) is an impact indicator because it measures the overall success of the health program in reducing infant mortality, which reflects the effectiveness of multiple health interventions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Percentage of deliveries with skilled assistance: Is an outcome indicator, focusing on the immediate effects of the program on delivery care.


Option C. Percentage of JSY claims made to ASHA: Is a process indicator, measuring administrative aspects of the program rather than its impact on health outcomes.

 

Option D. Percentage of fever cases that received chloroquine within 1 week in endemic areas: Is an outcome indicator, measuring the immediate success of treatment but not the long-term impact.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

choices.text: Pregnancy and lactation - Increase prolactin secretion

questions.text: Which of the following combinations regarding factors influencing prolactin secretion is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bromocriptine - Increases prolactin secretion

 

Explanation:

 

Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist, which inhibits prolactin secretion by mimicking the action of dopamine, a natural inhibitor of prolactin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregnancy and lactation - Increase prolactin secretion: Correct. Prolactin secretion significantly increases during pregnancy and lactation to prepare the mammary glands for milk production.

 

Option B. Dopamine blockers - Increase prolactin secretion: Correct. Dopamine blockers inhibit dopamine's suppressive effect on prolactin, leading to an increase in prolactin levels.

 

Option D. Somatostatin - Inhibits prolactin secretion: Correct. Somatostatin has an inhibitory effect on prolactin secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that decreases prolactin secretion, while dopamine blockers increase it.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation for A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation for A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of adenocarcinoma.
 

Reason (R): The Prague C & M criteria assess the extent of Barrett’s esophagus, with a higher C & M value correlating to a higher cancer risk.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation for A.

 

  • Assertion: Barrett’s esophagus is a known risk factor for adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous to columnar epithelium with intestinal metaplasia.

     

  • Reason: The Prague C & M criteria measure the circumferential (C) and maximum (M) extent of Barrett’s esophagus. Higher values indicate a greater extent and a higher risk of progression to adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Prague C & M criteria measure the circumferential (C) and maximum (M) extent of Barrett’s esophagus.

choices.text: Mattress suture - used for wound edge eversion
Purse-string suture - used in cervical cerclage and to bury the appendicular stump.
Purse string suture - used for cosmetic skin closure.
Interrupted suture - used for individual wound closure points.

questions.text: Identify the type of suture shown in the image and its primary uses:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Purse-string suture - used in cervical cerclage and to bury the appendicular stump.

 

  • The image depicts a purse-string suture, characterized by a continuous circular pattern that tightens when pulled. 

  • It is commonly used in cervical cerclage to prevent preterm labor and to secure the appendicular stump during appendectomy.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mattress suture - used for wound edge eversion: Mattress sutures are used for edge eversion and hemostasis but do not involve a circular pattern.

 

Option C. Purse string suture - used for cosmetic skin closure: Subcuticular sutures are buried within the skin for cosmetic closure and not purse string suture.

 

Option D. Interrupted suture - used for individual wound closure points: Interrupted sutures are discrete and individually tied, lacking the circular continuity of the purse-string technique.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The purse-string suture is a circular technique used in cervical cerclage and appendicular stump closure to achieve tension and secure closure.

questions.text: A new oral drug undergoes pharmacokinetic testing in two patient populations. Group A has significantly lower peak drug concentrations, while Group B exhibits prolonged drug exposure despite similar dosing. Further analysis reveals differences in gastric emptying rates and hepatic enzyme activity. Which parameter best explains the lower peak drug levels observed in Group A?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower Cmax

 

  • Cmax (maximum plasma concentration) represents the peak level of the drug in the bloodstream. 
  • A lower Cmax suggests slower or reduced absorption, which can be due to factors like delayed gastric emptying or increased first-pass metabolism. 
  • In Group A, differences in gastric emptying or hepatic metabolism likely reduce the amount of drug reaching peak concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced AUC: Incorrect. AUC represents total drug exposure over time, which may not necessarily correlate with peak plasma concentration.

 

Option B. Increased Tmax: Incorrect. An increased Tmax means the drug reaches peak levels more slowly, but does not directly explain the lower Cmax.

 

Option C. Decreased half-life: Incorrect. A reduced half-life means the drug is eliminated more quickly, but does not directly impact peak plasma levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cmax reflects the highest drug concentration achieved in plasma, and factors such as gastric emptying, enzyme activity, and first-pass metabolism can significantly alter its value.

questions.text: Which infection during pregnancy leads to periventricular calcifications?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

  • Cytomegalovirus causes periventricular calcifications and is the most common cause of congenital deafness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis leads to intracerebral calcifications.

 

Option C. Rubella: Rubella does not cause calcifications.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: Parvovirus B19 causes hydrops fetalis but no calcifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cytomegalovirus infection in pregnancy is associated with periventricular calcifications and sensorineural hearing loss.

choices.text: Progesterone level on Day 7 before menses

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with regular menstrual cycles but infertility for the past year. She reports mittelschmerz and premenstrual symptoms. What is the most appropriate next step to confirm ovulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progesterone level on Day 7 before menses

 

  • Progesterone level >5 ng/mL 7 days before menses confirms ovulation. This is the most practical and reliable test for confirming ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial biopsy on Day 21–23: Incorrect because endometrial biopsy is invasive and less commonly used.

 

Option B. Serum estrogen levels on Day 12: Incorrect because estrogen levels are not reliable indicators of ovulation.

 

Option D. Serial ultrasonography: Incorrect because serial ultrasonography, while accurate, is resource-intensive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum progesterone >5 ng/mL, 7 days before menses, is the gold standard for confirming ovulation in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male in the ICU following bowel resection develops a high-output jejunostomy. He is unable to tolerate enteral feeds. What is the most appropriate nutritional support?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)

 

  • TPN is indicated when enteral feeding is not feasible due to non-functioning gut (e.g., high-output ileostomy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enteral nutrition via nasogastric tube: Enteral nutrition is not feasible in this case.

 

Option C. Oral supplementation with electrolyte solutions: Oral supplementation is inadequate for nutritional needs.

 

Option D. Intravenous glucose-only solution: IV glucose alone does not provide adequate nutrition.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • TPN is the preferred option when enteral feeding is contraindicated or impossible due to gastrointestinal dysfunction.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with fever and a "slapped-cheek" appearance. She is diagnosed with Parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following complications is most likely in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrops fetalis

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection leads to anemia and hydrops fetalis due to its cytotoxicity to fetal RBCs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital deafness: Congenital deafness is a feature of cytomegalovirus.

 

Option C. Microcephaly: Microcephaly is associated with Zika virus.

 

Option D. Neural tube defect: Neural tube defects are not associated with Parvovirus B19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection in pregnancy primarily causes fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis, not teratogenic anomalies.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman presents for evaluation of worsening symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) at 32 weeks of gestation. She reports increasing joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, particularly in the hands and knees, making daily activities difficult. Her RA was well-controlled before pregnancy on hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) and sulfasalazine, but her symptoms have progressively worsened during the third trimester. She is concerned about the potential impact of her condition on her ability to care for her baby after delivery. She has no history of other autoimmune conditions, drug allergies, or complications in this pregnancy so far. Which drug can be safely added to her treatment at this stage of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Certolizumab

 

  • Certolizumab, an anti-TNF agent, is the safest biologic for use during pregnancy and can be continued throughout gestation without significant risk to the fetus. 
  • Its unique structure lacks an Fc fragment, preventing significant placental transfer, making it ideal for use in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leflunomide: Contraindicated due to teratogenicity.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Contraindicated because of teratogenicity and risk of pregnancy loss. It should be discontinued at least 3 months before conception.

 

Option C. NSAIDs: May be used in the first and second trimesters but must be avoided after 30 weeks due to the risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Certolizumab is a safe and effective treatment option for managing RA in pregnancy, particularly in the later stages, without posing significant risk to the fetus.

questions.text:
Match the types of grafts in Column A with their definitions in Column B:

 

Column A:

  1. Allograft
  2. Xenograft
  3. Orthotopic graft
  4. Heterotopic graft

 

Column B: 

  1. A graft placed in a site other than its natural location.
  2. A graft taken from a donor of a different species.
  3. A graft placed in the same anatomical site as the original tissue.
  4. A graft taken from a genetically non-identical individual of the same species.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

  • Allograft (1-D): This is a graft taken from a genetically non-identical individual of the same species.
  • Xenograft (2-B): This is a graft taken from a donor of a different species, such as porcine skin for burn patients.
  • Orthotopic graft (3-C): A graft transplanted into the same anatomical site as the original tissue.

  • Heterotopic graft (4-A): A graft transplanted into a site other than its natural location.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Allograft : This is a graft taken from a genetically non-identical individual of the same species.
  • Xenograft : This is a graft taken from a donor of a different species, such as porcine skin for burn patients.
  • Orthotopic graft : A graft transplanted into the same anatomical site as the original tissue.
  • Heterotopic graft : A graft transplanted into a site other than its natural location.

choices.text: It considers both mortality and morbidity in its calculation.
It measures the overall disease burden in a population, including premature mortality and disability.
It subtracts years lived with disability from total life expectancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sullivan’s Index is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It measures the overall disease burden in a population, including premature mortality and disability.

 

  • Sullivan’s Index is an epidemiological measure used to calculate Disability-Free Life Expectancy (DFLE) by subtracting the number of years lived with disability from the total life expectancy.
  • This indicator is useful for estimating the proportion of life spent in good health and is widely used in public health planning.
  • Sullivan’s Index does not measure the overall disease burden in a population, which includes both premature mortality and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). Instead, it focuses solely on disability-free years and does not account for diseases causing premature death.
  • DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Years) is the best metric for measuring the overall burden of disease because it includes both Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature mortality and Years Lived with Disability (YLD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It estimates Disability-Free Life Expectancy (DFLE): This is correct, as Sullivan’s Index directly quantifies the number of years a person is expected to live without disability in a given population.

 

Option B. It considers both mortality and morbidity in its calculation: This is correct since Sullivan’s Index integrates both life expectancy and morbidity data to determine how many years are spent without disability.

 

Option D. It subtracts years lived with disability from total life expectancy: This is correct, as Sullivan’s Index uses the formula:

 

DFLE = Total Life Expectancy − Years Lived with Disability 

 

It helps estimate healthy life expectancy, which is an important metric for evaluating public health interventions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sullivan’s Index is the Life Expectancy minus Duration of disability (bed disability and inability to perform major activities). 
  • It is one of the most advanced indicators currently available to measure ‘Disability free life expectancy (DFLE)’

 

Note - Disability Adjusted Life Years [DALYs]

 

  • Is best measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.
  • It expresses years lost to premature death and years lived with disability (adjusted for its’ severity).
  • DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together’.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis, and a smooth, vascular mass in the nasopharynx. Imaging shows bony erosion of the sphenoid sinus. Which of the following statements are true?

 

  1. This condition is common in adolescent males.
  2. The tumor arises from the sphenopalatine foramen.
  3. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.
  4. The tumor is malignant.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

1. This condition is common in adolescent males: True. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is most common in adolescent males.

 

2. The tumor arises from the sphenopalatine foramen: True. The tumor arises from sphenopalatine foramen and grows aggressively.

 

3. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice: True. Surgical resection is necessary due to its local invasion and vascular nature.

 

Other Option:

 

4. The tumor is malignant: False. JNA is a benign tumor, although it can grow aggressively and erode local structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is a benign but aggressive tumor common in adolescent males, requiring surgical resection.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion: Patients with severe systemic disease, classified as ASA IV, have a higher risk of perioperative complications.
 

Reason: ASA IV classification includes patients with life-threatening conditions that compromise organ function.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

 

  • ASA IV patients have systemic conditions like unstable angina or severe heart failure, which lead to compromised outcomes.

     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Patients in ASA IV have life-threatening systemic illnesses, requiring meticulous perioperative planning to mitigate complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with fatigue, pallor, and neurological symptoms, including tingling in his hands and feet. His blood work reveals macrocytic anemia. The physician suspects either a folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. Which of the following laboratory tests would best differentiate between these two deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blood level of methylmalonate

 

  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, an enzyme requiring vitamin B12 (cobalamin), converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA in fatty acid metabolism.
  • In vitamin B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl-CoA accumulates, leading to increased methylmalonate (MMA) levels in the blood.
  • Folate deficiency does not affect methylmalonate levels, making MMA the best test to differentiate between B12 and folate deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood level of cystathionine: Incorrect.

 

  • Cystathionine is an intermediate in the transsulfuration pathway, where homocysteine is converted to cystathionine via cystathionine β-synthase (CBS), a process requiring vitamin B6 (pyridoxine).
  • Folate or B12 deficiencies do not significantly affect cystathionine levels, so this test is not useful for distinguishing between the two.

 

Option B. Blood level of homocysteine: Incorrect

 

  • Both folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies lead to elevated homocysteine levels, because both are involved in its metabolism.
  • Folate deficiency impairs the conversion of homocysteine to methionine, and B12 deficiency prevents methylation of homocysteine by methionine synthase.
  • Since both deficiencies result in homocysteine accumulation, this test cannot differentiate between them.

 

Option C. Blood level of methionine: Incorrect

 

  • Methionine is produced when homocysteine is converted via methionine synthase, a process requiring vitamin B12.
  • However, methionine levels are not a reliable marker for distinguishing folate from B12 deficiency, as multiple metabolic pathways regulate methionine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both B12 and folate deficiencies increase homocysteine levels.
  • Only B12 deficiency elevates methylmalonate levels.
  • A high methylmalonate level confirms vitamin B12 deficiency, while a normal level suggests folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to an emergency with acute onset confusion, visual hallucinations, tremors, profuse sweating, and tachycardia. His wife reports he usually drinks 12-14 drinks daily but hasn't had alcohol for 2 days as he was trying to quit. On examination, he is disoriented, and agitated, with a BP of 160/100 mmHg. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous lorazepam

 

  • The patient presents with acute confusion, visual hallucinations, tremors, autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension), and disorientation after stopping alcohol for 48 hours, which is highly suggestive of alcohol withdrawal delirium (delirium tremens, DTs). 
  • This is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate treatment with intravenous benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam. 
  • Benzodiazepines reduce hyperexcitability of the CNS, prevent seizures, and control agitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: Incorrect. While antipsychotics like haloperidol may help control hallucinations, they do not treat the underlying cause of withdrawal and do not prevent seizures, making them inappropriate as first-line therapy.

 

Option C. Oral chlordiazepoxide: Incorrect.Chlordiazepoxide is a long-acting benzodiazepine used for mild alcohol withdrawal, but it is given orally and is not suitable for severe withdrawal or delirium tremens, where IV benzodiazepines are preferred.

 

Option D. Intravenous phenytoin: Incorrect. Phenytoin is ineffective for alcohol withdrawal seizures. Withdrawal seizures are best prevented and managed with benzodiazepines, not anticonvulsants like phenytoin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%.
  • The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male rescued from a house fire presents with confusion, tachycardia, and SpO2 of 98%. Carboxyhemoglobin levels are 25%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperbaric oxygen therapy

 

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated for severe carbon monoxide poisoning (carboxyhemoglobin >25%) to reduce half-life and prevent neurological complications.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal cannula oxygen: Nasal cannula oxygen is insufficient.

 

Option B. Non-rebreather mask oxygen: Non-rebreather mask oxygen is for mild cases.

 

Option D. Endotracheal intubation: Endotracheal Intubation is only required for respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is the treatment of choice for severe carbon monoxide poisoning with high carboxyhemoglobin levels.

questions.text: A molecular laboratory needs to detect a low-copy bacterial gene with maximum specificity. The sample is precious and limited in quantity. Which of the following PCR modifications would provide the highest sensitivity while maintaining specificity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nested PCR with internal primers

 

  • Nested PCR is ideal for detecting low-copy genes as it involves two rounds of amplification using different primer sets, with the second primer pair targeting a sequence within the first-round product. 
  • This double amplification significantly increases sensitivity, while the use of two specific primer sets targeting the same organism enhances specificity, making it optimal for detecting low-copy genes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiplex PCR with multiple primers: While this allows detection of multiple targets, it may reduce sensitivity due to primer competition and is not optimized for low-copy number detection.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR with SYBR Green: Although quantitative, it doesn't provide the enhanced sensitivity of nested PCR for very low copy numbers and may detect non-specific products.

 

Option D. Conventional PCR with extended cycles: Simply increasing cycle numbers can lead to non-specific amplification and doesn't provide the specificity of nested PCR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nested PCR provides maximum sensitivity through double amplification while maintaining specificity by using two sets of primers targeting the same organism.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with progressive muscle weakness, cataracts, and difficulty relaxing his grip after shaking hands. Genetic testing confirms a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated serum creatine kinase (CK)

 

  • Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is associated with an elevated serum creatine kinase (CK) level due to muscle damage. 
  • Muscle weakness and myotonia lead to muscle breakdown, releasing CK into the bloodstream. 
  • This is a key diagnostic clue in DM1. Unlike other conditions like rhabdomyolysis, where myoglobin is released, DM1 typically shows high CK levels without significantly elevated myoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased urine myoglobin concentration: Myoglobinuria is seen in conditions like rhabdomyolysis, not myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option C. Increased serum calcium levels: Hypercalcemia is not a typical feature of myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option D. Decreased hemoglobin concentration: Anemia is not a prominent feature of myotonic dystrophy, though it may occur secondarily in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elevated serum creatine kinase (CK) is commonly seen in myotonic dystrophy due to muscle damage, aiding in the diagnosis of the condition.

choices.text: Nested case-control studies are typically less costly than cohort studies because fewer participants are needed for analysis.
Nested case-control studies involve the collection of exposure data from participants after the outcome has occurred, making them more efficient than cohort studies.
Nested case-control studies require a cohort study to be already in place, which may limit their feasibility in certain settings.
Nested case-control studies allow for efficient analysis of rare outcomes within large cohorts, without the need for extensive participant recruitment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the misconception about nested case-control studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nested case-control studies involve the collection of exposure data from participants after the outcome has occurred, making them more efficient than cohort studies.

 

  • The misconception is that nested case-control studies involve collecting exposure data after the outcome has occurred, which is not true.
  • In fact, nested case-control studies collect exposure data before the disease occurs, which helps to minimize bias. 
  • These studies can be cost-effective because they utilize existing cohort data, but they are not more efficient than cohort studies in all cases, especially when the cohort is large and follow-up is lengthy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nested case-control studies are typically less costly than cohort studies because fewer participants are needed for analysis: Nested case-control studies are less expensive than cohort studies because only a subset of participants (cases and controls) is required for analysis.


Option C. Nested case-control studies require a cohort study to be already in place, which may limit their feasibility in certain settings: Nested case-control studies are based on existing cohort studies, which may limit their use in new populations.


Option D. Nested case-control studies allow for efficient analysis of rare outcomes within large cohorts, without the need for extensive participant recruitment: These studies are particularly useful in studying rare outcomes by focusing on a subset of the cohort, which can reduce recruitment costs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a nested case-control study, exposure data is collected before the disease develops, and it is more cost-effective than cohort studies due to the use of existing cohort data.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia presents with fatigue, arthralgia, and pleuritic chest pain for the past 3 months. She reports no prior history of autoimmune disease. Physical exam reveals a malar rash, swollen small joints, and mild pleural effusion. Laboratory results show positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-histone antibodies, but anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are negative. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Procainamide

 

  • This patient presents with drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), a condition associated with hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid, and sulfonamides (SHIPP mnemonic). 
  • The hallmark of DILE includes arthralgia, fever, serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis), and positive ANA and anti-histone antibodies, with negative anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies. 
  • Procainamide, an antiarrhythmic, is one of the highest-risk drugs for DILE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyldopa: While methyldopa is associated with autoimmune hemolytic anemia, it is not a common cause of DILE.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone can cause thyroid dysfunction, pulmonary fibrosis, and hepatotoxicity but is not linked to DILE.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin toxicity can lead to drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) rather than lupus-like syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE) is most commonly associated with hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid, and sulfonamides. 
  • It presents with arthralgia, serositis, and positive anti-histone antibodies. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are usually absent.

choices.text: Genomic imprinting results in the silencing of the maternal allele, making the paternal deletion manifest.
The child inherited two active copies of chromosome 15 from the father and mother, resulting in expression of the mutated gene.
Anticipation caused the gene to become more severe as it was passed down through the generations.
Gonadal mosaicism in the father led to a second, unaffected allele being passed on to the child.
