questions.text: A couple presents with a history of recurrent miscarriages and a child with developmental delay. Genetic testing reveals that the child has Prader-Willi syndrome due to a paternal deletion on chromosome 15. What is the most likely reason the child inherited this genetic condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genomic imprinting results in the silencing of the maternal allele, making the paternal deletion manifest.

 

  • Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a paternal deletion on chromosome 15, and the condition manifests due to maternal imprinting, which silences the maternal allele. 
  • Genomic imprinting causes the paternal allele to be expressed while the maternal allele is silenced by DNA methylation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. The child inherited two active copies of chromosome 15 from the father and mother, resulting in expression of the mutated gene: Anticipation involves earlier onset and increased severity of the disorder in successive generations, which is not relevant here.

 

Option C. Anticipation caused the gene to become more severe as it was passed down through the generations: Gonadal mosaicism refers to genetically distinct cell lines within the gonads but is not relevant to Prader-Willi syndrome in this scenario.

 

Option D. Gonadal mosaicism in the father led to a second, unaffected allele being passed on to the child: Gonadal mosaicism refers to mutation in some sperm or egg cells while the rest remain normal, leading to some offspring inheriting a genetic disorder while others do not. While gonadal mosaicism can explain some genetic disorders, Prader-Willi syndrome is not typically caused by this mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Genomic imprinting involves the silencing of one allele (maternal or paternal) through DNA methylation, leading to differential expression based on the parent of origin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain, fever, and significant intercostal muscle tenderness. He works in agriculture, and his symptoms started after eating street food. Upon examination, he shows signs of pleuritic chest pain and muscle stiffness. He reports a recent fever and generalized muscle aches. He also has a past medical history of diabetes. Given the context and clinical presentation, which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Group B Coxsackievirus

 

  • The patient is presenting with pleurodynia (Bornholm disease), which is caused by Group B Coxsackievirus. 
  • This virus is particularly associated with sudden-onset chest pain, pleuritic symptoms, and muscle stiffness, commonly following exposure to contaminated food or water, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes. 
  • The presence of intercostal muscle tenderness and pleuritic chest pain further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group A Coxsackievirus: This virus typically causes Herpangina (oral and throat vesicles), not pleuritic chest pain or muscle stiffness.

 

Option C. Enterovirus: Although Enterovirus can cause similar systemic symptoms, it does not typically cause pleuritic chest pain with muscle tenderness.

 

Option D. Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6): This virus is associated with roseola in children, not with pleuritic chest pain or muscle stiffness in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Group B Coxsackievirus, specifically Coxsackievirus B, causes pleurodynia (Bornholm disease), which presents with pleuritic chest pain and intercostal muscle tenderness, commonly following foodborne exposure, especially in patients with diabetes.

choices.text: The connection between the left abducens nucleus and the right oculomotor nucleus
The connection between the right abducens nucleus and the left oculomotor nucleus
The connection between the left oculomotor nucleus and the left lateral rectus
The connection between the left oculomotor nucleus and the right lateral rectus

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with multiple sclerosis presents with an acute episode of diplopia and difficulty tracking objects to the right. During examination, you find that the left eye does not adduct when the patient looks to the right. The right eye moves normally. MRI reveals demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). Which of the following pathways is most directly disrupted by this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The connection between the right abducens nucleus and the left oculomotor nucleus

 

  • The MLF connects the abducens nucleus on one side with the oculomotor nucleus on the other side to allow conjugate horizontal eye movements. 
  • A lesion in the MLF, such as in multiple sclerosis, disrupts the pathway between the right abducens nucleus (which controls the right lateral rectus) and the left oculomotor nucleus (which controls the left medial rectus). This results in impaired adduction of the left eye during rightward gaze.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. The connection between the left abducens nucleus and the right oculomotor nucleus: The connection between the left abducens nucleus and the right oculomotor nucleus is not disrupted in this case, as the lesion is on the right MLF.
 

Option C. The connection between the left oculomotor nucleus and the left lateral rectus: The left oculomotor nucleus and the left lateral rectus are not connected; the lateral rectus is controlled by the abducens nucleus.
 

Option D. The connection between the left oculomotor nucleus and the right lateral rectus: The left oculomotor nucleus controls the left medial rectus, not the right lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • A lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) disrupts the coordination between the abducens nucleus and the oculomotor nucleus, resulting in internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

A. La belle indifférence → 2. Lack of concern about symptoms: La belle indifférence refers to a paradoxical lack of concern about neurological symptoms, commonly seen in conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder).

 

B. Phobic stimulus → 4. Situation that triggers irrational fear and avoidance despite recognition: A phobic stimulus is an object or situation that triggers irrational fear and avoidance, even though the person recognizes that their fear is excessive (e.g., fear of heights, or flying).

 

C. Panic sensitivity → 1. Fear of experiencing anxiety symptoms: Panic sensitivity refers to heightened fear of experiencing anxiety symptoms (e.g., rapid heartbeat, breathlessness), leading to anticipatory anxiety about having panic attacks.

 

D. Agoraphobia → 3. Fear of situations from where escape may be difficult: Agoraphobia is fear of situations where escape may be difficult (e.g., public places, crowded areas), even in neutral or safe environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • La belle indifférence is characteristic of conversion disorder (unconcerned about symptoms).
  • Phobic stimuli are avoided despite the person knowing their fear is irrational.
  • Panic sensitivity involves fear of anxiety symptoms themselves.
  • Agoraphobia is triggered in situations that are otherwise neutral but are perceived as difficult to escape from.

questions.text: Mrs. Nandini, a 52-year-old woman from Hyderabad, presents with deformity of her hands which is shown below. She also reports progressive shortness of breath. Chest radiography reveals bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, and further evaluation raises concern for pulmonary complications associated with her condition. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interstitial lung disease

 

  • Scleroderma can lead to pulmonary hypertension due to interstitial lung disease (ILD), where progressive fibrosis and scarring of the lung tissue increase pulmonary vascular resistance. 
  • This is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in scleroderma patients. 
  • ILD often presents with bilateral lower lobe infiltrates on imaging and is commonly associated with dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Recurrent pulmonary embolism: While pulmonary embolism can cause pulmonary hypertension, there is no clinical evidence of embolic events in this patient.

 

Option C. Left ventricular systolic dysfunction: This would cause pulmonary congestion but is not directly linked to scleroderma-related pulmonary hypertension.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Leads to chronic cough and sputum production but is not a typical pulmonary manifestation of scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In scleroderma, pulmonary hypertension commonly results from interstitial lung disease or pulmonary arterial hypertension. 
  • Early recognition and management of ILD are crucial to improving outcomes in these patients.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis presents to the clinic after experiencing a new episode of weakness and sensory loss. Her past medical history is significant for multiple relapses of vision loss and difficulty walking, each of which improved with corticosteroid therapy. During this visit, you suspect a potential relapse. Which of the following immunopathological findings is most likely to be present in the acute phase of this patient's disease, contributing to her symptoms?

 

  1. Activation of autoreactive CD4+ T cells against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG)
  2. Presence of aquaporin-4 antibodies binding to the astrocytic foot processes
  3. A shift toward Th1 helper T cell differentiation leading to increased interferon-gamma secretion
  4. Increased expression of glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) within the spinal cord
  5. Elevated interleukin-10 levels promoting B-cell differentiation into plasma cells
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 only

 

2. Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against aquaporin-4 (AQP4), a water channel protein found on the astrocytic foot processes. These antibodies lead to the destruction of astrocytes and subsequent demyelination of the optic nerves and spinal cord, which manifest as optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. This finding is pivotal in diagnosing NMO, especially during acute relapses.

 

Other Options:


1. Activation of autoreactive CD4+ T cells against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG): This is more typical of MOG antibody-associated encephalomyelitis, not NMO.

 

3. A shift toward Th1 helper T cell differentiation leading to increased interferon-gamma secretion: This shift is seen in other autoimmune diseases, but it is not a hallmark of NMO.

 

4. Increased expression of glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP): GFAP is a marker for astrocytes and is typically associated with reactive gliosis, not the autoimmune attack seen in NMO.

 

5. Elevated interleukin-10 levels promoting B-cell differentiation into plasma cells: IL-10 is involved in B-cell differentiation and suppression of inflammatory responses, but it is not directly related to the pathophysiology of NMO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In neuromyelitis optica, the presence of aquaporin-4 antibodies is a key diagnostic marker and plays a significant role in the pathophysiology of the disease.

     

Note –

 

Management of acute attacks:

 

  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Plasma exchange.

 

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses:

 

  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Rituximab
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Azathioprine.

questions.text: 6-year-old child presents with fever, pancytopenia, generalized weakness, and weight loss. On examination, the child is pale and has generalized lymphadenopathy. A peripheral smear is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

 

  • The peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts, which are immature cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm. 
  • These findings, along with pancytopenia, are diagnostic of ALL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML): Incorrect. JMML presents with features like leukocytosis, monocytosis, and splenomegaly, which are not present here.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia: Incorrect. Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia but no lymphoblasts or lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Incorrect. AML presents with myeloblasts, which have cytoplasmic granules, Auer rods, and a lower nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio compared to lymphoblasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ALL presents with lymphoblasts, pancytopenia, and systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy, requiring a high index of suspicion in pediatric patients.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about eating disorders:

 

Statement 1: Body image disturbance is essential for diagnosing anorexia nervosa

 

Statement 2: Binge eating disorder has the highest prevalence among eating disorders

 

Statement 3: Bulimia nervosa is characterized by a better prognosis compared to anorexia nervosa

 

Statement 4: Night eating syndrome is classified under Other Specified Feeding and Eating Disorders

 

Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Statement 1: Body image disturbance is essential for diagnosing anorexia nervosa: Correct. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by intense fear of gaining weight, persistent behaviors leading to significantly low body weight, and body image disturbance (distorted perception of body weight or shape). This disturbance is a core diagnostic criterion in the DSM-5.

 

Statement 2: Binge eating disorder has the highest prevalence among eating disorders. Correct: Binge Eating Disorder (BED) is the most common eating disorder, with a higher prevalence than anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. Unlike bulimia, BED does not involve compensatory behaviors (e.g., purging, excessive exercise).

 

Statement 3: Bulimia nervosa is characterized by a better prognosis compared to anorexia nervosa: Correct. Bulimia nervosa is characterized by higher rates of recovery (partial and full) compared to anorexia nervosa.  

 

Statement 4: Night eating syndrome is classified under Other Specified Feeding and Eating Disorders (OSFED): Correct. Night Eating Syndrome (NES) is classified under Other Specified Feeding and Eating Disorders (OSFED) in DSM-5. It involves excessive nighttime eating, morning anorexia, and sleep disturbances. Unlike binge eating disorder, it has a distinct circadian pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Body image disturbance is required for anorexia nervosa, binge eating disorder is the most prevalent eating disorder, bulimia has a better prognosis compared to anorexia nervosa, and night eating syndrome is part of OSFED.

questions.text:
A health response team is implementing measures to prevent further spread of infectious diseases in the aftermath of a massive earthquake. These measures are focused on improving food safety, water supply, and controlling vectors. In which phase of the disaster cycle would these measures most likely be implemented? 

 

  1. Primary phase
  2. Secondary phase 
  3. Tertiary phase
  4. Mitigation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

2. The secondary phase (6-24 hours) focuses on disease prevention through sanitation, waste disposal, and medical interventions, which align with early food safety and water purification efforts. 

 

3. The tertiary phase (1-60 days) involves rehabilitation and rebuilding, ensuring sustainable public health measures, including long-term vector control and stable food/water supplies.

 

Other Options:

 

1. The primary phase is focused on immediate response, such as first aid, triage, and initial emergency care.

 

4. Mitigation aims to prevent future disasters, rather than manage the current disaster's immediate health and safety needs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of a Disaster Cycle

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements: 

 

  1. Tranexamic acid reduces the risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases
  2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury
  3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients with trauma
  4. Damage control surgery is done only in unstable patients in trauma
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 4

 

Based on the given statements, let's identify the correct ones regarding the management of trauma patients:

 

2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury: This statement is correct. The CRASH-2 trial also indicated that tranexamic acid is beneficial when administered within 3 hours of injury to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage or shock.

 

4. Damage control surgery is done only in unstable patients in trauma: Damage control surgery is done only in unstable patients in trauma. This is correct, as only unstable patients with ongoing hemorrhage following complex injuries are candidates.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases This statement is incorrect. Tranexamic acid has been shown to reduce the risk of mortality from bleeding in both penetrating and blunt trauma cases, as evidenced by the CRASH-2 trial.

 

3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma This statement is incorrect. In severely hypovolemic trauma patients, blood and blood products are preferred to restore circulating volume and oxygen-carrying capacity. Crystalloids can be used temporarily while awaiting blood products but are not the resuscitation fluid of choice in severe hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The key points in trauma management include administering tranexamic acid within 3 hours to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage, using blood and blood products for the resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients, and controlling life-threatening hemorrhage as a first step in the primary survey of trauma patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes and hyperlipidemia presents with eruptive xanthomas. His lipid panel reveals markedly elevated triglycerides. Genetic testing suggests a defect in the apoprotein responsible for activating lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Which of the following apoproteins is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apoprotein C-II

 

  • ApoC-II is required to activate LPL, which hydrolyzes triglycerides from chylomicrons and VLDL. 
  • A deficiency in ApoC-II leads to severe hypertriglyceridemia, causing conditions like familial chylomicronemia syndrome, which presents with eruptive xanthomas, pancreatitis, and lipemia retinalis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apoprotein A-I: Incorrect. ApoA-I is the main structural protein of HDL and an activator of LCAT (lecithin–cholesterol acyltransferase), which helps in cholesterol esterification. It does not play a role in LPL activation or triglyceride metabolism.

 

Option B. Apoprotein B-100: Incorrect. ApoB-100 is a structural component of VLDL, IDL, and LDL. It is important for LDL receptor binding but has no role in LPL activation.

 

Option D. Apoprotein E: Incorrect. ApoE is involved in remnant lipoprotein clearance by mediating uptake via hepatic LDL receptors. It is not directly involved in LPL activation or triglyceride metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ApoC-II deficiency leads to severe hypertriglyceridemia due to defective LPL activation, causing complications like pancreatitis and xanthomas.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man from Chennai presents with progressive memory loss, confusion, and difficulty performing daily activities over the past year. His family reports frequent forgetfulness and episodes of getting lost in familiar places. Neurological examination reveals no motor deficits, but cognitive testing confirms significant short-term memory impairment. MRI shown below. What cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) finding is most consistent with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased beta-amyloid 42, elevated tau protein

 

  • In Alzheimer’s dementia, CSF analysis typically reveals decreased beta-amyloid 42 due to its deposition as amyloid plaques in the brain, and elevated tau protein levels reflecting neuronal damage and neurofibrillary tangles. 
  • These biomarkers aid in diagnosis and monitoring disease progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated protein, normal glucose: Suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome, not Alzheimer’s.

 

Option C. Elevated WBCs, decreased glucose: Indicates bacterial or fungal meningitis, not neurodegeneration.

 

Option D. Increased beta-amyloid 42, elevated tau protein: Increased beta-amyloid is not seen in Alzheimer’s; it is characteristically decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alzheimer’s dementia is marked by decreased CSF beta-amyloid 42 and elevated tau proteins, which are critical biomarkers for confirming the diagnosis and tracking disease progression.

choices.text: Overstimulation of D1 receptors leading to excessive renal vasodilation
Dopamine-induced β1 stimulation causing tachycardia and myocardial ischemia
Vasoconstriction from α1 receptor activation reducing peripheral blood flow
Direct negative inotropic effect of dopamine reducing cardiac output

questions.text: A critically ill patient receiving high-dose dopamine infusion (>10 mg/kg/min) for severe hypotension shows signs of worsening peripheral perfusion. What is the most likely explanation for this clinical observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vasoconstriction from α1 receptor activation reducing peripheral blood flow

 

  • At doses greater than 10 mg/kg/min, dopamine primarily stimulates α1-adrenergic receptors, leading to systemic vasoconstriction. 
  • This effect can reduce peripheral blood flow despite increasing systemic blood pressure, potentially exacerbating conditions like limb ischemia or contributing to worsening organ perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overstimulation of D1 receptors leading to excessive renal vasodilation: Incorrect as D1 receptor stimulation, which promotes renal vasodilation, occurs at lower doses.

 

Option B. Dopamine-induced β1 stimulation causing tachycardia and myocardial ischemia: Incorrect although β1-related tachycardia can occur, the primary issue at this dose is α1-mediated effects.

 

Option D. Direct negative inotropic effect of dopamine reducing cardiac output: Incorrect because dopamine generally has a positive inotropic effect, not a negative one, though high doses primarily affect vascular tone via α1 receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Identify the consequences of high-dose dopamine infusion, particularly the risks associated with excessive α1 receptor activation, and its impact on peripheral and organ perfusion in critically ill patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents with new-onset bruising and joint pain. Laboratory workup shows a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), but her prothrombin time (PT) and bleeding time are normal. A mixing study is performed, where the patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma. The PTT remains prolonged after mixing. Further tests reveal decreased factor VIII activity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor VIII inhibitor

 

  • This patient presents with a prolonged PTT and a mixing study that fails to correct the PTT. 
  • This suggests the presence of an inhibitor, rather than a deficiency in clotting factors. 
  • The decreased factor VIII activity and failure of the mixing study to normalize the PTT point toward a factor VIII inhibitor as the cause of the coagulopathy.
  • Factor VIII inhibitor is an acquired antibody against factor VIII, often presenting with a prolonged PTT that does not correct on mixing studies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilia A: Hemophilia A causes factor VIII deficiency but typically corrects with a mixing study.

 

Option B. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC): DIC leads to prolonged PT, PTT, and decreased platelets, but this patient has normal PT and bleeding time.

 

Option D. Vitamin K deficiency: Vitamin K deficiency leads to deficiencies in factors II, VII, IX, and X, but this would affect both PT and PTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acquired hemophilia (Factor VIII inhibitors) should be suspected in adults with sudden-onset bleeding, prolonged PTT, and no prior history of bleeding disorders.
  • The mixing study is crucial to differentiate between factor deficiencies (e.g., Hemophilia A, which corrects) and factor inhibitors (which do not correct).
  • Patients with Factor VIII inhibitors require immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., corticosteroids, rituximab) to reduce antibody production.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of pelvic trauma following a road traffic accident. He has blood at the urethral meatus, a high-riding prostate, and inability to void. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde urethrogram

 

  • Retrograde urethrogram confirms the diagnosis of posterior urethral injury, avoiding further damage from catheterization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urethral catheterization: Catheterization risks worsening the injury.

 

Option C. Suprapubic catheter placement: Suprapubic catheter placement is done after confirming the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Immediate exploratory laparotomy: Laparotomy is unnecessary without evidence of intra-abdominal injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior urethral injuries require confirmation via retrograde urethrogram before any further intervention.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of progressive pain and swelling in both knees. The pain is particularly aggravated by activity, and he has noticed a decrease in range of motion in the joint. On physical examination, there is moderate effusion and tenderness over the joint line. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synovial Chondromatosis

 

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a rare benign condition where the synovial membrane of joints forms multiple cartilaginous nodules. 
  • These nodules can become free-floating bodies within the joint, and over time, they may undergo calcification or ossification.
  • It results from the metaplasia of the synovial lining, leading to the formation of cartilaginous nodules, which may later calcify or ossify. 
  • These free-floating nodules can cause pain, joint effusion, and limited range of motion, as the synovium becomes inflamed and irritated.
  • X-rays typically reveal multiple, well-defined, round or oval-shaped calcified bodies within the joint, which may be free-floating or fixed to the synovial lining. 
  • The classic "popcorn" appearance on imaging is a hallmark of synovial chondromatosis.
  • Pain, swelling, stiffness, and a decreased range of motion are common due to irritation of the synovium, along with mechanical symptoms from free-floating bodies in the joint.
  • Most commonly affects large joints like the knee, hip, or elbow, and it can involve both unilateral and bilateral joints. 
  • The knee is a very common site of involvement.
  • Surgical excision of the nodules is the treatment of choice, and the prognosis is generally good once the nodules are removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Synovial Sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a malignant soft tissue tumour that often arises near large joints, usually in the deep tissues of the limbs. It can occur in younger adults, commonly affecting the knee or elbow. It is a malignant tumour that arises from synovial tissue or surrounding soft tissues. Synovial sarcoma is typically characterized by a complex chromosomal translocation (t(X;18)), which leads to abnormal gene expression. Synovial sarcoma may present as a soft tissue mass near the joint. X-ray may show a well-circumscribed mass or calcifications within the soft tissue, but the tumour itself is often better seen on MRI or CT. These masses can be heterogeneous and irregular in shape, often extending into the joint or surrounding structures. Symptoms are usually related to the mass effect of the tumour. Patients may present with a palpable mass, pain, swelling, and decreased joint mobility due to the tumour’s involvement of the soft tissues around the joint. Pain often worsens with activity. Synovial sarcoma can be diagnosed with imaging studies (MRI is most helpful) and confirmed with biopsy to detect characteristic histological features. Treatment usually involves surgical resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy may be necessary depending on the stage.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour that often arises in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee. It is more common in adolescents and young adults. Osteosarcoma arises from the osteoblasts and typically produces bone or osteoid. It can be associated with a genetic mutation (e.g., in the TP53 gene), and it often occurs in the metaphysis of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus). X-rays often show a destructive bone lesion with an aggressive appearance. There is typically an ill-defined periosteal reaction, which may result in the formation of a "Codman's triangle" (a raised periosteum seen on the edge of a tumour). There may also be bone fragmentation or a mixed lytic and sclerotic pattern in the lesion. Osteosarcoma typically presents with localized pain, swelling, and, in some cases, a palpable mass. The pain often worsens over time, and there may be a history of injury that exacerbates the pain. It often presents in the younger population, typically between ages 10 and 30. Imaging studies (X-ray, MRI) and biopsy are used for diagnosis. CT scans or PET scans may be performed to evaluate for metastasis, as osteosarcoma commonly metastasizes to the lungs. Treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy and surgical resection of the tumour.

 

 

Option D. Giant Cell Tumour: Giant cell tumour (GCT) is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumour that commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee. Giant cell tumours are composed of multinucleated giant cells and are typically found in the epiphyseal region of long bones. Although they are benign, they can cause significant local bone destruction and may recur after surgery. X-rays often show a lytic, expansile lesion in the epiphysis of long bones, commonly affecting the distal femur, proximal tibia, or radius. The lesion has a "soap bubble" appearance, with well-defined borders but an expansile, destructive nature. Giant cell tumours typically present with pain, swelling, and a decrease in range of motion, especially in weight-bearing joints. However, it is usually a solitary lesion and not typically associated with multiple nodules or calcifications in the joint space. Imaging studies and biopsy are used to confirm the diagnosis. MRI is helpful to determine the extent of the tumour, and biopsy confirms the presence of multinucleated giant cells. Treatment involves curettage and bone grafting, although recurrence is common. In some cases, surgical resection or joint replacement may be required.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While giant cell tumours can cause pain and swelling in the knee, they typically do not present with multiple calcified bodies in the joint space. 
  • The radiographic appearance would be more characteristic of a lytic lesion rather than the calcified nodules of synovial chondromatosis.

questions.text: The colonies shown in the image, is most likely associated with which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mucormycosis

 

  • The lid-lifting colony formation of black-white wooly colonies is a distinctive feature of Mucor species, which are the causative agents of mucormycosis.
  • This opportunistic fungal infection commonly affects immunocompromised individuals, especially those with diabetes and neutropenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic candidiasis:  Typically presents with creamy, pasty colonies rather than wooly colonies.

 

Option B. Pulmonary aspergillosis: It is associated with greenish colonies, not the wooly appearance typical of Mucor.

 

Option D. Dermatophytosis: It causes powdery colonies and does not produce the distinctive wooly colonies seen in Mucor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucormycosis, caused by Mucor species, is characterized by black-white wooly colonies and a lid-lifting growth pattern.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Patients with dystocia dystrophica syndrome often have difficult labor.


Reason (R): They have an android pelvis and frequently experience deep transverse arrest.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

  • Dystocia dystrophica syndrome is characterized by an android pelvis, which predisposes patients to deep transverse arrest, leading to difficult labor. This explains the assertion that labor is often challenging in these patients.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Android pelvis and deep transverse arrest are hallmark features of dystocia dystrophica syndrome, often leading to difficult labor.

choices.text: The cells are senescing due to an accumulation of DNA mutations during replication.
The cells are senescing due to critical telomere shortening, as indicated by the Hayflick limit.
The cells are undergoing apoptosis due to excessive oxidative stress.
The cells are undergoing transformation into a cancerous state, bypassing the Hayflick limit.

questions.text: In an experiment studying human cell division, a scientist observes that a cultured normal human fetal cell population divides 50 times before entering senescence. What is the most likely explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The cells are senescing due to critical telomere shortening, as indicated by the Hayflick limit.

 

  • Normal human fetal cells can divide between 40 and 60 times in culture before entering senescence, which is due to telomere shortening. 
  • Once the telomeres reach a critical length, further division stops, leading to senescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The cells are senescing due to an accumulation of DNA mutations during replication: Incorrect. DNA mutations may accumulate with age but are not the primary cause of the Hayflick limit.

 

Option C. The cells are undergoing apoptosis due to excessive oxidative stress: Incorrect. Oxidative stress can lead to apoptosis, but this is not the main cause of senescence due to the Hayflick limit.

 

Option D. The cells are undergoing transformation into a cancerous state, bypassing the Hayflick limit: Incorrect. Cancer cells can bypass the Hayflick limit, but normal cells do not undergo transformation to become cancerous due to telomere shortening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Normal human fetal cells divide between 40 and 60 times before entering senescence, primarily due to telomere shortening, a phenomenon known as the Hayflick limit.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female who was started on an antidepressant 2 weeks ago for major depression presents to emergency with confusion, diaphoresis, tremors, and myoclonus. On examination, she has hyperreflexia, temperature 38.2°C, pulse 112/min, BP 160/95 mmHg. On further questioning, she reveals that she is using over-the-counter cough syrup containing dextromethorphan for her recent cold. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serotonin Syndrome

 

  • The patient presents with confusion, diaphoresis, tremors, myoclonus, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability (hypertension, tachycardia), and fever, which are characteristic of serotonin syndrome. 
  • The recent use of an antidepressant (likely an SSRI) and dextromethorphan (a serotonergic agent) increases the risk of serotonin toxicity.

 

Key Features of Serotonin Syndrome:

 

  • Neuromuscular excitability → Tremors, myoclonus, hyperreflexia, clonus
  • Autonomic instability → Diaphoresis, hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia
  • Altered mental status → Confusion, agitation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anticholinergic toxicity: Incorrect. Features dry skin (rather than diaphoresis), mydriasis, urinary retention, decreased bowel sounds, and delirium, which are absent here.

 

Option B. Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS): Incorrect. NMS presents with lead-pipe rigidity (not hyperreflexia), altered mental status, autonomic instability, and fever but lacks myoclonus and hyperreflexia.

 

Option D. Malignant Hyperthermia. Incorrect: Triggered by anesthetic agents, causing severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, and metabolic acidosis, which are not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serotonin syndrome is a life-threatening condition due to serotonergic excess, often caused by combining SSRIs, MAOIs, SNRIs, dextromethorphan, linezolid, tramadol, or MDMA. 

 

 

Management includes discontinuation of serotonergic agents (most crucial), supportive car, and cyproheptadine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of recurrent, severe menorrhagia due to uterine fibroids is treated with EACA to manage her bleeding during her menstrual cycles. She presents to the clinic complaining of sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. A CT pulmonary angiogram reveals a pulmonary embolism (PE). Which aspect of EACA's mechanism of action is most likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Competitive inhibition of plasminogen.

 

  • EACA's primary mechanism, the competitive inhibition of plasminogen, prevents its conversion to plasmin, which is crucial in fibrin clot breakdown. 
  • By inhibiting this pathway, EACA not only reduces bleeding but also increases the risk for thrombotic events such as PE, especially in predisposed individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of platelet aggregation: Incorrect as EACA does not directly affect platelet aggregation.

 

Option B. Stabilization of fibrin clots: Incorrect because while it stabilizes fibrin clots, this answer does not directly link to the mechanism causing PE.

 

Option C. Reduction in blood viscosity: Incorrect as EACA does not reduce blood viscosity; it may actually increase the risk of thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Understand the complications associated with the antifibrinolytic activity of EACA, highlighting the increased risk of thromboembolic events.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with acute bloodstream infection in the form of septicemia, following a traumatic injury while working in a paddy field. His clinical features also include fever, chills, and generalized muscle aches. A microbiological culture from the wound grows colonies, as shown in the image. What virulence factor is most likely contributing to the pathogenicity of this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III secretion system

 

  • The type III secretion system is a critical virulence factor for Burkholderia pseudomallei and is responsible for injecting toxins into host cells to promote infection. 
  • This pathogen’s ability to produce wrinkled purple colonies on Ashdown’s medium is a further clue. B. pseudomallei has a long latency period and can lead to severe infections such as septicemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polysaccharide capsule: While this is important in some pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae, B. pseudomallei relies more on its type III secretion system for virulence.


Option B. Type IV pili: These pili are involved in adhesion, but B. pseudomallei utilizes its type III secretion system for a more aggressive pathogenic mechanism.


Option D. Siderophore for iron acquisition: While iron acquisition is important, B. pseudomallei's virulence is more associated with its type III secretion system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The type III secretion system is a major virulence factor of Burkholderia pseudomallei, contributing to its pathogenicity in melioidosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, cough, and a characteristic maculopapular rash. A biopsy from a lymph node is performed, and the following histopathological image is observed. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with these cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculosis

 

  • Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are typically associated with measles, Kimura disease, and HIV-associated lymphadenopathy, but are not a feature of tuberculosis. 
  • Tuberculosis usually presents with granulomas and caseous necrosis, not multinucleated giant cells like those seen in measles or Kimura disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles: Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic for measles.

 

Option B. Kimura disease: This is a rare disorder of unknown etiology, often associated with eosinophilia and Warthin-Finkeldey cells in the lymph nodes.

 

Option C. HIV-associated lymphadenopathy: Can present with Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in the lymph nodes, particularly in the context of opportunistic infections

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are found in conditions like measles, Kimura disease, and HIV-associated lymphadenopathy but are not characteristic of tuberculosis.

 

Diseases Associated with Warthin-Finkeldey Cells:

 

1. Measles (Rubeola) – Classical association

 

  • Most characteristic setting
  • Found in lymphoid tissue (e.g., tonsils, lymph nodes)
  • Early appearance before the rash
  • Accompanied by necrosis and paracortical hyperplasia

 

2. HIV-associated lymphadenopathy

 

  • WFCs have been reported in reactive hyperplasia in HIV
  • Believed to be part of immune dysregulation
  • However, not pathognomonic and less frequent than in measles

 

3. Kimura disease

 

  • Rarely reported, likely due to florid immune response
  • Not a classic feature, but giant cells may be seen in inflammatory background

 

4. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

 

  • Occasionally seen in lymph nodes showing "lupus lymphadenitis"
  • Represents part of an exaggerated immune response

 

5. Post-vaccination lymphadenitis (especially MMR vaccine)

 

  • Measles component of MMR vaccine can trigger appearance of WFCs

choices.text: A patient receiving chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
A pregnant woman in her second trimester
A 60-year-old healthy individual receiving the flu vaccine
A 15-year-old girl receiving the MMR vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be most at risk for complications due to receiving a live vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A patient receiving chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

  • Patients who are immunosuppressed, such as those receiving chemotherapy, are at high risk for complications from live vaccines due to their weakened immune systems. 
  • Live vaccines can cause severe reactions in immunocompromised patients. Pregnant women are also at risk but the yellow fever vaccine is one exception, and vaccines such as MMR are generally contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A pregnant woman in her second trimester: Incorrect, as pregnant women are typically advised to avoid live vaccines, especially in the first trimester.

 

Option C. A 60-year-old healthy individual receiving the flu vaccine: Incorrect, as the flu vaccine is inactivated and is safe for healthy individuals.

 

Option D. A 15-year-old girl receiving the MMR vaccine: Incorrect, as the MMR vaccine is safe for healthy children and not contraindicated in this age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immunocompromised patients (e.g., those on chemotherapy) are at high risk for complications from live vaccines. 
  • Pregnant women should avoid live vaccines, with few exceptions.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about AMTSL are correct?

 

  1. Uterotonic agents should be given within 1 minute of delivery.
  2. Fundal massage is performed immediately after delivery of the baby.
  3. Controlled cord traction is an essential step.
  4. Routine fundal massage before placental delivery is mandatory.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3 only

 

Statement 1: Uterotonic agents should be given within 1 minute of delivery. (Correct)

 

  • Explanation: Administration of uterotonic agents (e.g., oxytocin 10 IU IM or IV infusion) within 1 minute of delivery helps stimulate uterine contractions and reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Importance: Timely administration reduces the risk of uterine atony, which is the most common cause of PPH.

 

 Statement 3: Controlled cord traction is an essential step. (Correct)

 

  • Explanation: Controlled cord traction (CCT) is an essential component of AMTSL to facilitate placental expulsion while preventing uterine inversion.
  • Steps in CCT:
    • One hand supports the uterus above the symphysis pubis.
    • The cord is gently pulled downward with steady traction.
    • If the placenta does not descend, no forceful pulling should be applied to avoid uterine inversion.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Fundal massage is performed immediately after delivery of the baby. (Incorrect)

 

  • Explanation: Fundal massage should be performed after placental delivery, not immediately after the baby is born.
  • Reason: If done before placental separation, it can lead to incomplete separation, increasing the risk of retained placenta and hemorrhage.
  • Correct Practice: Fundal massage is done after placenta delivery to enhance uterine tone and prevent atony.

 

Statement 4: Routine fundal massage before placental delivery is mandatory. (Incorrect)

 

  • Explanation: Fundal massage before placental delivery is not mandatory and is not part of the standard AMTSL protocol.
  • Correct Approach:
    • Fundal massage should only be done after placental expulsion to promote uterine contraction and reduce blood loss.
    • Routine pre-delivery fundal massage can cause premature placental separation, increasing complications.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • AMTSL is a key strategy to reduce postpartum hemorrhage and includes:
    1. Timely administration of uterotonic agents within 1 minute of delivery.
    2.  Controlled cord traction to aid placental expulsion while preventing uterine inversion.
    3.  Fundal massage after placental delivery , not immediately after the baby is born to promote uterine contraction.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with oral thrush. Microscopic findings is shown in the image below. Which of the following fungi is most likely responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

  • Candida albicans produces blastoconidia as part of its asexual reproduction, and it is the most common cause of oral thrush in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes mellitus.
  • Blastoconidia are a characteristic asexual spore type of Candida.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Produces conidiospores, not blastoconidia.
 

Option C. Trichosporon: It can also produce arthrospores but not blastoconidia.


Option D. Rhizopus: It is a zygomycete that produces sporangia and not blastoconidia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida albicans is characterized by the production of blastoconidia during its asexual reproduction and is a common cause of oral thrush.

choices.text: Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow increases to meet metabolic demands.
Coronary circulation decreases due to sympathetic vasoconstriction.
Cutaneous blood flow initially decreases and later increases to aid heat dissipation.
CNS blood flow significantly increases due to enhanced neural activity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about blood flow changes during exercise is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cutaneous blood flow initially decreases and later increases to aid heat dissipation.

 

Explanation:

 

  • During exercise, cutaneous blood flow is initially reduced due to sympathetic vasoconstriction as the body prioritizes blood flow to muscles. As exercise progresses and body temperature rises, cutaneous blood flow increases significantly to dissipate heat through sweat and evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow increases to meet metabolic demands: Incorrect. Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow decreases during exercise due to sympathetic vasoconstriction as these organs are not prioritized for oxygen delivery during physical activity.

 

Option B. Coronary circulation decreases due to sympathetic vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Coronary circulation actually increases during exercise to meet the heightened metabolic demands of the heart muscle. Sympathetic stimulation causes vasodilation in the coronary vessels.

 

Option D. CNS blood flow significantly increases due to enhanced neural activity: Incorrect. CNS blood flow remains relatively constant during exercise due to autoregulation, ensuring the brain maintains its function regardless of systemic changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood flow redistribution during exercise prioritizes muscles, heart, and heat dissipation while reducing flow to non-essential organs.

choices.text: Pulsatile to stimulate a natural rise and fall in gonadotropins.
Continuous to induce receptor desensitization and decrease gonadotropin release.
High-dose bolus once a month to maximize receptor stimulation.
Low-dose intermittent to gently suppress gonadotropin levels.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is diagnosed with central precocious puberty. The endocrinologist decides to initiate treatment with a GnRH agonist. Which administration strategy of GnRH agonist is most appropriate to achieve the therapeutic goal in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continuous to induce receptor desensitization and decrease gonadotropin release.

 

  • In central precocious puberty, the goal is to suppress premature gonadotropin secretion to halt early sexual maturation. 
  • Continuous administration of GnRH agonists leads to receptor desensitization on the pituitary gland, effectively decreasing the release of LH and FSH, thus preventing early puberty progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsatile to stimulate a natural rise and fall in gonadotropins: Incorrect as pulsatile administration would mimic the natural secretion pattern and potentially exacerbate the condition.

 

Option C. High-dose bolus once a month to maximize receptor stimulation: Incorrect because a high-dose bolus might initially stimulate gonadotropin release before achieving desensitization, potentially worsening symptoms temporarily.

 

Option D. Low-dose intermittent to gently suppress gonadotropin levels: Incorrect as intermittent low doses do not reliably induce the necessary receptor desensitization for therapeutic effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Apply knowledge of GnRH receptor pharmacodynamics to select appropriate therapy regimens for conditions like central precocious puberty, aiming for effective suppression of premature gonadotropin secretion.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason correctly explains the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason does not explain the Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion: Periodic echocardiography is essential for monitoring patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).


Reason: DMD patients are at increased risk of developing dilated cardiomyopathy due to dystrophin deficiency in myocardial tissue.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason correctly explains the Assertion.

 

  • DMD-associated dystrophin deficiency leads to myocardial fibrosis and cardiomyopathy, necessitating echocardiographic surveillance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

DMD-associated dystrophin deficiency leads to myocardial fibrosis and cardiomyopathy

questions.text: The following coronal section of the abdomen is showing the relations of epiploic foramen. What structure forms its superior boundary as indicated in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudate lobe of liver

 

  • The epiploic foramen (also known as the foramen of Winslow) connects the greater sac and the lesser sac of the abdominal cavity. 
  • It is bounded by critical structures that are essential for understanding abdominal anatomy.

 

Boundaries of the Epiploic Foramen:

 

  1. Anterior:
    • Right free border of the lesser omentum containing:
      • Bile duct
      • Hepatic artery (vertical part)
      • Portal vein (posterior to duct and artery)
  2. Posterior:
    • Inferior vena cava (IVC)
    • Right suprarenal gland
  3. Superior:
    • Caudate process of the caudate lobe of the liver
  4. Inferior:
    • First part of the duodenum
    • Horizontal part of the hepatic artery

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • The epiploic foramen is of great importance in surgeries involving the liver or pancreas as it provides access to the lesser sac. Structures within its boundaries are prone to injury during abdominal surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lesser omentum: Incorrect. The lesser omentum forms part of the anterior boundary, not the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option B. Inferior vena cava: Incorrect. The IVC forms the posterior boundary of the epiploic foramen, lying posterior to the portal vein.

 

Option C. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum forms the inferior boundary of the epiploic foramen, specifically the first part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boundaries of the Epiploic Foramen:

 

  1. Anterior:
    • Right free border of the lesser omentum containing:
      • Bile duct
      • Hepatic artery (vertical part)
      • Portal vein (posterior to duct and artery)
  2. Posterior:
    • Inferior vena cava (IVC)
    • Right suprarenal gland
  3. Superior:
    • Caudate process of the caudate lobe of the liver
  4. Inferior:
    • First part of the duodenum
    • Horizontal part of the hepatic artery

questions.text: A 19-year-old man, Rohan from Delhi, with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, vomiting, and confusion. His capillary blood glucose is 520 mg/dL. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following drugs should be used immediately to manage hyperglycemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Regular insulin

 

  • The patient is likely experiencing diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a life-threatening complication of type 1 diabetes. 
  • Immediate treatment involves fluid resuscitation and IV Regular insulin, which has a rapid onset and allows for precise titration to correct hyperglycemia and ketosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subcutaneous Regular insulin: Not preferred in DKA due to delayed absorption and less predictable pharmacokinetics.

 

Option C. IV NPH: NPH is an intermediate-acting insulin and is not suitable for acute management.

 

Option D. IV Glargine: Glargine is long-acting and not administered IV; it is unsuitable for managing acute hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In diabetic ketoacidosis, IV Regular insulin is the treatment of choice to rapidly lower blood glucose and correct acidosis. 
  • Early and appropriate insulin therapy is critical to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. The histopathology of the resected gallbladder revealed Stage T1a gallbladder carcinoma. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) No further treatment

 

  • T1a gallbladder carcinoma is defined as a tumor that invades the lamina propria but does not extend into the muscle layer. 
  • Standard cholecystectomy is considered curative in such cases, provided that the surgical margins are clear, and there is no evidence of perineural, lymphatic, or vascular invasion.
  • No further treatment is required for T1a lesions with negative margins, as the risk of recurrence is negligible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perform extended cholecystectomy: Extended cholecystectomy, which involves resection of the liver bed and lymphadenectomy, is recommended for T1b tumors or higher (tumor invades the muscular layer or beyond). It is not necessary for T1a tumors with negative margins.

 

Option C. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is not indicated for T1a gallbladder carcinoma as it is an early-stage tumor with an excellent prognosis after curative cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Radiation: Radiation therapy has no role in the management of early-stage gallbladder cancer, including T1a lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T1a gallbladder carcinoma is limited to the lamina propria and has an excellent prognosis following simple cholecystectomy, provided the margins are clear. 
  • No additional treatment is necessary in these cases.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a thyroid nodule and undergoes a fine-needle aspiration biopsy. The histology shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalks and single-layered cuboidal cells with clear nuclei. The biopsy also shows concentric calcified spherules in the stroma. Which of the following features best differentiates this from other thyroid malignancies?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psammoma bodies

 

  • Psammoma bodies, which are small, concentric, calcified spherules, are characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. 
  • This feature helps differentiate papillary carcinoma from other thyroid malignancies. 
  • Psammoma bodies are rarely found in other types of thyroid cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Solid sheets of undifferentiated cells: Solid sheets of undifferentiated cells are more characteristic of anaplastic carcinoma, not papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Presence of amyloid deposits: Amyloid deposits are seen in medullary carcinoma due to C-cell hyperplasia, not in papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Follicular pattern with colloid-filled follicles: Follicular pattern with colloid-filled follicles is characteristic of follicular carcinoma, not papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies are a hallmark feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, helping to differentiate it from other thyroid malignancies.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions can lead to Hyperphenylalaninemia?

 

  1. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency 
  2. Phenylalanine hydroxylase overactivity 
  3. Dihydrobiopterin reductase deficiency 
  4. Tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency 
  5. Defect in dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 5

 

  • Hyperphenylalaninemia can result from defects in the metabolic pathway of phenylalanine due to:

 

1. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency: This enzyme is crucial for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine. Its deficiency leads to an accumulation of phenylalanine.

 

3. Dihydrobiopterin reductase deficiency: This enzyme is necessary for the recycling of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), a cofactor for phenylalanine hydroxylase. Its deficiency leads to a decrease in BH4, impairing phenylalanine hydroxylation.

 

5. Defect in dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis: Problems in the biosynthesis of BH4 also lead to reduced cofactor availability for phenylalanine hydroxylase, contributing to elevated phenylalanine levels.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Incorrect: Includes Phenylalanine hydroxylase overactivity, which would theoretically lower phenylalanine levels.

 

4. Incorrect: Includes Tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency, which affects dopamine synthesis but not directly phenylalanine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary causes of hyperphenylalaninemia are defects in the metabolism of phenylalanine, which can be due to deficiencies in phenylalanine hydroxylase, dihydrobiopterin reductase, or defects in dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis. 
  • Understanding these deficiencies helps in diagnosing conditions such as phenylketonuria (PKU) and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)-deficiency disorders.

questions.text: During Napoleon’s ill-fated march to Moscow, the bulk of his army faced significant losses not due to battle, but from a different cause. Which of the following diseases was responsible for the maximum casualties among Napoleon’s troops?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Typhus

 

  • The maximum damage to Napoleon's army during the 1812 march to Moscow was caused by typhus, a highly contagious disease spread by lice. 
  • The poor sanitary conditions, overcrowded camps, and harsh weather conditions facilitated the rapid spread of typhus among the soldiers, leading to widespread illness and death. 
  • Typhus significantly weakened the army, contributing to its eventual defeat.
  • While plague, diarrhea, and typhoid also affect military units, typhus was the primary cause of mass casualties during this campaign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plague: It is caused by the Yersinia pestis bacterium and can lead to widespread death, but there is no major historical record of the plague being the primary cause of death during Napoleon's campaign in Russia.

 

Option C. Diarrhea: It is a common affliction in wartime due to poor sanitation, but it was typhus, not diarrhea, that caused the most significant casualties during Napoleon’s march.

 

Option D. Typhoid: It is caused by Salmonella typhi and leads to gastrointestinal symptoms, but it did not cause the massive death toll experienced from typhus during Napoleon's campaign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During Napoleon’s march to Moscow, typhus was the leading cause of casualties, resulting in significant losses due to its rapid transmission and high mortality rate in the poor conditions the soldiers endured.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with acute myeloid leukemia is undergoing induction chemotherapy. Within 48 hours, he develops nausea, vomiting, oliguria, and severe flank pain. Laboratory results reveal hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and a markedly elevated uric acid level. The oncologist prescribes a medication that rapidly converts uric acid into allantoin for renal excretion. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rasburicase

 

  • The patient presents with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS), a condition characterized by the rapid release of intracellular contents, including potassium, phosphate, and uric acid, following chemotherapy. 
  • TLS leads to acute kidney injury due to uric acid crystal deposition in the renal tubules. 
  • Rasburicase is the drug of choice because it catalyzes the enzymatic breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, a more water-soluble metabolite that is easily excreted by the kidneys, thereby preventing renal damage. 
  • It acts much faster than xanthine oxidase inhibitors such as allopurinol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allopurinol: Incorrect. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, preventing the formation of uric acid but does not degrade existing uric acid. It is used for long-term urate management but is ineffective for rapidly lowering uric acid levels in TLS.

 

Option B. Febuxostat: Incorrect. Febuxostat, like allopurinol, is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents uric acid formation but does not break down pre-existing uric acid. It has no immediate effect in acute TLS.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Incorrect. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that promotes diuresis but does not specifically lower uric acid levels. It is not the preferred treatment for TLS-associated hyperuricemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rasburicase is the preferred treatment for tumor lysis syndrome because it directly degrades uric acid into allantoin, preventing renal complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man, Arjun from Bengaluru, experiences a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, and blurred vision while trekking at an altitude of 5000 meters in the Himalayas. Which of the following indicates the development of high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered mental status

 

  • High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE) is a severe form of acute mountain sickness (AMS) characterized by:
    • Altered mental status (confusion, disorientation, or coma).
    • Ataxia (difficulty walking or coordinating movements).
  • HACE occurs due to hypoxia-induced vasodilation and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) at altitudes >2500 meters. 
  • Progression from AMS to HACE often happens over 12 hours to 3 days. Immediate treatment includes:
    1. Descent to lower altitude
    2. Administration of dexamethasone
    3. Supplemental oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desaturation: Common at high altitudes but not specific to HACE.

 

Option C. Increased blood pressure: May occur as a physiological response to hypoxia but is not a diagnostic feature of HACE.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: Often seen at high altitudes but is not exclusive to HACE and occurs in asymptomatic individuals as well.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Altered mental status and ataxia are hallmarks of HACE, requiring immediate descent and medical intervention to prevent fatal complications.

choices.text: Treatment with vancomycin and removal of catheter
Treatment with topical antibiotics at the catheter site

questions.text: A 63-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for lung cancer presents with a fever of 38.3°C (100.9°F) and erythema at the exit site of a tunnelled central venous catheter in his neck. The tunnel itself is neither tender nor red. Blood cultures are negative at 48 hours, and his neutrophil count is 1550/μL. What is the best approach to the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Treatment with vancomycin alone

 

  • This patient has an exit site infection associated with his tunneled central venous catheter. 
  • Exit site infections present with localized erythema, tenderness, or discharge at the catheter exit site, without signs of tunnel or systemic infection. 
  • The absence of tunnel tenderness or systemic involvement (negative blood cultures) suggests a localized infection.
  • Vancomycin is recommended to cover gram-positive organisms, especially Staphylococcus aureus, which are the most common pathogens associated with catheter-related infections. 
  • The catheter does not need to be removed unless the infection progresses, there are signs of tunnel or bloodstream infection, or symptoms do not improve with antibiotic therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Removal of catheter alone: Catheter removal is not necessary in the absence of systemic infection or tunnel involvement.

 

Option B. Treatment with vancomycin and removal of catheter: This is excessive management in a patient with a localized infection without systemic involvement.

 

Option C. Treatment with topical antibiotics at the catheter site: Topical antibiotics are insufficient for treating catheter-related infections, as systemic antibiotics are needed to address potential deep-seated infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized exit site infections in tunneled central venous catheters can often be managed with systemic antibiotics (e.g., vancomycin). 
  • Catheter removal is reserved for refractory, systemic, or complicated infections.

questions.text: A clinical psychologist is developing a new scale to assess patient satisfaction with healthcare services. After administering the scale to a large sample of patients, the psychologist calculates Cronbach’s alpha to determine the underlying concept. Which of the following describes the primary focus of Cronbach’s alpha in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal consistency

 

  • Cronbach’s alpha is a measure of internal consistency, which assesses how well the individual items of a test or questionnaire measure the same underlying construct. 
  • In this case, the psychologist is evaluating whether all items on the patient satisfaction scale are consistent in measuring patient satisfaction, which is the intended construct. 
  • A high value of Cronbach’s alpha (usually above 0.7) indicates good internal consistency, meaning the items are reliably measuring the same concept.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Criterion validity: It measures how well a test or scale correlates with an external criterion or outcome, but it does not assess the internal consistency of a set of items.


Option C. Test-retest reliability: It refers to the consistency of test results when administered at different times, not how well the items of a test measure the same construct.


Option D. Construct validity: It assesses whether a test truly measures the concept it is intended to measure, but it focuses on the overall validity of the test, not internal consistency of the items.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cronbach’s alpha is a measure of internal consistency, evaluating whether all items in a questionnaire or test reliably measure the same underlying construct.
